questions.text:
Mechanical nociceptors and its response to a probe with blunt object, pinprick and toothed forceps with serrations is recorded as an output of a force transducer coupled to the stimulator. What could be inferred from this?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: There are no responses from the nociceptors when stimulated by blunt forceps
Pinching with toothed forceps cause stimulation of mechanonociceptors but no pain
Pricking with a needle does not stimulate nociceptors
Sharp pain sensation is carried by C fibres

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) There are no responses from the nociceptors when stimulated by blunt forceps

 

Explanation:

  • Mechanical nociceptors respond to high-threshold mechanical stimuli, such as pinpricks and strong pressure, but not to non-noxious blunt stimuli.
  • Blunt forceps do not generate sufficient force to activate nociceptors, as they primarily stimulate low-threshold mechanoreceptors responsible for touch.

Classification of Nerve Fibers in Pain Transmission

Fiber Type

Function

Speed

Example

Aδ fibers

Sharp, localized pain

Fast (myelinated)

Needle prick, pinching

C fibers

Dull, burning pain

Slow (unmyelinated)

Persistent pain, heat

Pinching with toothed forceps causes stimulation of mechanonociceptors but no pain (Option B): Incorrect because nociceptors, when activated, do generate pain.

Pricking with a needle does not stimulate nociceptors (Option C): Incorrect because pricking is a strong mechanical stimulus that activates nociceptors.

Sharp pain sensation is carried by C fibers (Option D): Incorrect because sharp pain is carried by Aδ fibers, while C fibers transmit slow, burning pain.

questions.text:
Choose the correct options from the given statements of the enteric nervous system?

 

1. Vagus is the only afferent from gut

2. Functions independent of brain and SC

3. Myenteric plexus in the lamina propria

4. Exclusively under the influence of nerves

5. Parasympathetic connects enteric to CNS
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2

 

Explanation:

  • The enteric nervous system (ENS) is a self-regulating system that can function independently of the brain and spinal cord (SC), controlling gut motility, secretion, and blood flow.
  • Vagus is not the only afferent from the gut; the gut also has spinal afferents that carry pain and reflex information.
  • The myenteric plexus (Auerbach's plexus) is located between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers, not in the lamina propria.

Auerbach plexus between two sets of muscles

  • The ENS is influenced by hormones and local factors, not exclusively by nerves.
  • The parasympathetic nervous system (via vagus and pelvic nerves) connects the ENS to the CNS, modulating its activity.

Components of the Enteric Nervous System

Component

Function

Location

Myenteric Plexus (Auerbach)

Controls motility and peristalsis

Between muscle layers

Submucosal Plexus (Meissner)

Regulates secretion and blood flow

In submucosa

Autonomy

Functions independently but modulated by CNS

Entire gut wall

1,2,3 (Option A): Incorrect because the vagus is not the only afferent, and the myenteric plexus is not in the lamina propria.

1,4 (Option B): Incorrect because ENS is not exclusively under neural influence; hormones and local factors also regulate it.

1,3 (Option C): Incorrect because both vagus-only afferent and myenteric plexus location statements are wrong.

questions.text: Identify the marked blood vessel in this MR Angiogram.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Superficial temporal artery

Explanation:

 

  • This MR Angiogram highlights an extracranial artery marked by the arrow, which runs along the lateral aspect of the skull.
  • The superficial temporal artery (STA) is a branch of the external carotid artery, supplying the scalp, temporalis muscle, and forehead.
  • It is commonly seen in angiographic imaging due to its superficial location and prominent branching pattern.

 

Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA)

There are various types of MR angiograms based on different principles and can be classified into non-contrast and contrast enhanced methods.

Non-contrast MRA

Contrast enhanced (CE) MRA

Time-of-flight (TOF) imaging:

  • It is the most prevalent method for Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) in clinical practice.

Phase-contrast MRA:

  • It is more sensitive for identifying slow blood flow and useful for imaging cerebral veins (MR venography or MRV).
  • Effective for detecting dural venous sinus thrombosis and venous stenoses.
  • MRA combined with gadolinium-based contrast agents is called contrast-enhanced (CE) MRA.
     
  • Excellent for quickly visualizing the carotid and vertebral arteries where a large field of view (FOV) is necessary.
     
  • Reduces artifacts caused by turbulent or slow flow.
     
  • Useful for assessing arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), aneurysms, and intracranial stenosis.
  • Two types are:
    • Elliptical-centric
    • Multiphase techniques

questions.text: IOC for Ureteric calculi is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) NC-CT

Explanation:

 

  • Non-contrast CT (NC-CT) KUB is the investigation of choice (IOC) for ureteric calculi due to its high sensitivity (>95%) and specificity (>98%) in detecting even small stones.
  • It provides detailed anatomical visualization without requiring contrast, making it the gold standard for urinary calculi evaluation.

Radiographic Investigations:

  1. X-ray KUB:
    • Detects 90% of calculi (radiopaque).
    • Radiolucent stones (TIXU): Triamterene, Indinavir, Xanthine, Uric acid.
  2. Ultrasound (USG):
    • Screening tool for hydronephrosis and stones in the collecting system.
  3. Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP):
    • Early films (1 & 5 min): Assesses contrast excretion & obstructions.
    • Delayed films: Identifies the cause of delayed excretion.
  4. Non-contrast Spiral CT (NCCT) – Gold Standard:
    • Most sensitive test for renal/ureteric calculi.
  5. Retrograde Pyelogram (RGP):
    • Better anatomical delineation, especially for the distal ureter.
    • Helps detect additional stones & coexisting ureteric diseases (e.g., strictures).

 

USG (Option A):
First-line for pregnant women and children, but misses small ureteric stones and lacks sensitivity for ureteral evaluation.

 

CE-CT (Contrast-Enhanced CT) (Option C):
Contrast can obscure stones, making it less effective for detecting calculi.

 

Ureteroscopy (Option D):
Used for diagnosis and treatment, but not the first-line investigation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with an inability to bear weight following a trivial trauma. X-rays of the pelvis and thigh reveal lytic lesions with cortical destruction. She has a history of weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Metastasis

Explanation:

  • Metastatic bone disease is the most common cause of lytic bone lesions in elderly patients with a history of weight loss.
  • The femur and pelvis are common sites for metastatic deposits, especially from primary malignancies like breast, lung, prostate, and renal cell carcinoma.
  • Pathological fractures following trivial trauma are characteristic.
  • The X-ray shows focal bony destruction of the acetabulum, causing abnormal joint orientation, but the femoral articular surface remains normal, suggesting a bone lesion rather than joint pathology.

 

Metastatic Tumors to Bone

Common Metastatic Tumors
  • Lung carcinoma (male)
  • Breast carcinoma (female)
  • Prostate carcinoma (Osteoblastic)
  • Thyroid carcinoma

Clinical Features
  • Known Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain (common in spine, ribs, extremities)
    • Pathological fracture (common in spine)
 
  • Unknown Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain leading to destructive lesion diagnosis
    • Pathological fracture due to weakened bone

Malignancies Presenting with Silent Primary
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Bladder carcinoma

Common Sites of Metastasis
  • Vertebral bodies
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis
  • Humerus
  • Femur
  • Uncommon distal to elbow and knee

 

Eosinophilic Granuloma (Option A): Primarily affects children, commonly involving the skull and vertebral bodies, not typical in elderly patients.

 

Disseminated TB (Option B): Typically involves the hip joint (Tuberculous arthritis), leading to joint space narrowing and articular surface destruction, which is not seen here.

 

Brown Tumor (Option C): Seen in hyperparathyroidism, with multiple lytic lesions and associated systemic features, which are not mentioned in the case.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic patient presents with fever, malaise, and productive cough. Which of the following is an incorrect statement?

choices.text: Patchy infiltrates are seen in pyogenic pneumonia
Interstitial infiltrates are seen in Mycoplasma pneumonia
Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrates is seen in malignancy
Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the posterior segment of the upper lobes and superior segment of the lower lobes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Patchy infiltrates are seen in pyogenic pneumonia
 

Explanation:

  • The most common cause of community-acquired pyogenic pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus).
  • The most common imaging pattern seen on a chest X-ray for pneumococcal pneumonia is lobar consolidation; meaning a homogeneous consolidation affecting one or more lobes of the lung
  • Patchy infiltrates are not typical for pyogenic pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Classification of Pneumonia Based on Imaging Pattern:

  1. Lobar Pneumonia:
    • Unifocal consolidation, most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.
    • In children under 8 years, may appear as “Round Pneumonia” with ill-defined margins.
    • Air bronchograms are common due to patent airways and minimal volume loss.
  2. Bronchopneumonia (Lobular Pneumonia):
    • Multifocal distribution, centered around distal airways.
    • Heterogeneous scattered opacities along airway course, coalescing in severe cases.
    • Air bronchogram absent due to airway involvement.
  3. Atypical Pneumonia:
    • Features distinct from lobar or bronchopneumonia (discussed in the table below).

 

Causative Agent

Specific Imaging Features

Streptococcus pneumoniae

Most common cause of community-acquired lobar pneumonia in adults.

Staphylococcus aureus
  • Common in debilitated patients / superinfection in influenza / secondary to IV drug abuse.
  • Cavitation common in later radiographs.
  • Pneumatoceles (seen in children during recovery phase).

Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • Occurs in elderly and alcoholics, usually involves the right upper lobe (RUL).
  • Bulging of fissures due to increased involved lung volume.

Legionnaire’s disease (Legionella pneumophila)
  • Rapidly spreading pneumonia from contaminated water sources (ACs, coolers, showers).
  • Also presents with diarrhea, mental confusion (hyponatremia), and shock.

Actinomycosis
  • Can mimic bronchogenic carcinoma.
  • Soft tissue/bone involvement (periostitis) – key differentiating feature.
  • CT: Peripheral homogeneous consolidation with central low attenuation and pleural thickening (diagnostic feature).

Atypical pneumonia (Most common cause: Mycoplasma pneumoniae)
  • Atypical organism (lacks cell walls, resistant to penicillins).
  • Fine reticular/nodular shadows in perihilar region early, which may progress to consolidation (rare lobar involvement).
  • WBC count usually normal.
  • Presents with non-productive cough, absent/minimal sputum.
  • Not aspiration-related.
  • Common in poorly maintained air-conditioned areas.
  • Other viral causes: Influenza A & B, RSV, Adenovirus, Chlamydia psittaci, Coxiella burnetii (Q fever).

Varicella pneumonia
  • Predominantly nodular opacities (5–10 mm).
  • If persistent, may calcify, leading to miliary shadows on CXR.

 

Interstitial infiltrates are seen in Mycoplasma pneumonia (Option B):

  • Mycoplasma pneumonia typically causes atypical pneumonia, with interstitial infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrates is seen in malignancy (Option C):

  • Lung cancer, especially small cell carcinoma and lymphoma, commonly presents with hilar lymphadenopathy along with parenchymal lung infiltrates.

Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the posterior segment of the upper lobes and superior segment of the lower lobes (Option D):

  • Aspiration pneumonia classically affects the dependent lung segments, particularly the posterior segment of the upper lobes and the superior segment of the lower lobes, especially in supine patients.

questions.text: Not seen in decompression sickness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hemodilution

 

Explanation:

  • Decompression sickness (DCS) is caused by nitrogen bubble formation due to rapid ascent from high-pressure environments.
  • Vision loss can occur due to air embolism affecting the retinal circulation.
  • Hearing loss can result from inner ear barotrauma or vestibulocochlear involvement.
  • Coagulopathy occurs due to vascular injury and activation of coagulation pathways.
  • Hemodilution is not seen in DCS because the condition primarily leads to dehydration, not plasma volume expansion.

Pathophysiology of Decompression Sickness

System Affected

Manifestations

Neurological

Vision loss, confusion, vertigo, paralysis

Otorhinolaryngologic

Hearing loss, tinnitus, dizziness

Cardiovascular

Coagulopathy, gas embolism, shock

Pulmonary

Dyspnea, chest pain ("chokes")

 

Vision loss (Option A): Incorrect because air embolism can cause retinal artery occlusion.

Hearing loss (Option B): Incorrect because inner ear barotrauma and nitrogen bubbles can affect hearing.

Coagulopathy (Option D): Incorrect because bubble-induced endothelial damage triggers clotting abnormalities.

questions.text: Which receptor contributes to static 2 point discrimination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Merkel cell

 

Explanation:

  • Merkel cells are responsible for static two-point discrimination due to their slowly adapting nature and high spatial resolution.
  • Meissner corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors that detect light touch and dynamic changes rather than static discrimination.
  • Pacinian corpuscles are specialized for vibration and deep pressure, not fine touch discrimination.
  • All of them is incorrect because only Merkel cells contribute to static two-point discrimination.

Anatomy of Cutaneous Mechanoreceptors

Receptor

Adaptation

Function

Location

Merkel cells

Slow-adapting

Static touch, two-point discrimination

Fingertips, lips, hair follicles

Meissner corpuscles

Rapid-adapting

Light touch, dynamic touch

Fingertips, palms, soles

Pacinian corpuscles

Rapid-adapting

Vibration, deep pressure

Deep dermis, joints, ligaments

Meissner corpuscle (Option B): Incorrect because it responds to dynamic touch rather than static discrimination.

Pacinian corpuscle (Option C): Incorrect because it detects vibration and not fine touch resolution.

All of them (Option D): Incorrect because only Merkel cells contribute to static two-point discrimination, not the others.

questions.text:
Identify the marked ones in sarcomere?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: A- Z line B- A band C-I band D-H band
A-Z line B- I band C- A band D- H band
A-M line B-I band C-H band D-I band
A-M line B-I band C- A band D- H band

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A-Z line B- I band C- A band D- H band

 

Explanation:

  • A (Z line): Dark vertical line marking the boundary between sarcomeres and anchoring actin filaments.
  • B (I band): Light region containing only thin actin filaments; shortens during contraction.
  • C (A band): Dark region containing thick myosin filaments, with actin overlapping; remains unchanged in length.
  • D (H band): Lighter central part of A band with only myosin filaments; disappears during contraction.

Sarcomere Structural Components

Region

Description

Z line

Defines sarcomere boundary, actin attachment

I band

Actin-only region, shortens during contraction

A band

Myosin-containing region, remains constant

H band

Myosin-only zone in A band, disappears in contraction

questions.text: An elderly man presents with a 7-month history of progressive dysphagia and bad breath. An image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zenker diverticulum

Explanation:

 

  • The given image is a barium swallow radiograph showing a posterior outpouching at the pharyngoesophageal junction, characteristic of Zenker's diverticulum.
  • Zenker diverticulum is a pharyngoesophageal diverticulum that develops due to weakness in the Killian's triangle (between the inferior pharyngeal constrictor and cricopharyngeus muscle).

Zenker Diverticulum:

  • False pulsion diverticulum as it protrudes posteriorly above the cricopharyngeal sphincter through the dehiscence of Kilian between the oblique and horizontal fibres of the inferior pharnygeal constrictor.
  • It is due to loss of coordination between pharyngeal contraction and opening of the upper esophagal sphincter.

 

Clinical features

  • When the diverticulum is small, symptoms largely reflect desynchronization of swallowing with pharyngeal dysphagia.
  • As the pouch enlarges:
    • The fundus descends into the mediastinum.
    • Regurgitation of trapped food can occur and lead to aspiration.
    • Main symptom is halitosis and regurgitation.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Barium Swallow Study (Esophagram): To visualize the esophagus and identify the presence of a diverticulum.

 

  • Esophagal Manometry
  • MRI
  • Endoscopy

 

Surgical treatment :

  • Diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeus myotomy
  • Diverticular suspension: The diverticulum is dissected and absence of a suture line lessens the chance of a postoperative leak.
  • Cricopharyngeus myotomy
  • Newer techniques: Transoral introduction of a linear stapler.

Achalasia (Option A):

  • Typically presents with dysphagia to both solids and liquids from the onset due to impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter.
  • Barium Swallow Finding: Classic "bird’s beak" appearance, showing a dilated esophagus with tapering at the lower esophageal sphincter.

 

Carcinoma esophagus (Option B):

  • Presents with progressive dysphagia (first to solids, then liquids) along with weight loss and possible odynophagia.
  • The provided image does not show an irregular mass or luminal narrowing typical of malignancy.

 

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option D):

  • Characterized by intermittent, non-progressive dysphagia and chest pain, often relieved by nitrates or calcium channel blockers.
  • The imaging here does not show the classic "corkscrew esophagus" seen in esophageal spasm.

questions.text:
Match the following Hormones with their receptors?

 


	
		
			
			A. Insulin-Receptor
			
			
			1. JAK/STAT
			
		
		
			
			B. Acetylcholine
			
			
			2. Nuclear Receptor
			
		
		
			
			C. Growth Hormone
			
			
			3. Tyrosine Kinase
			
		
		
			
			D. Thyroxine
			
			
			4. Ligand gated
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

Explanation:

  • Insulin → Tyrosine Kinase (A-3)
    • Binds to insulin receptor, leading to autophosphorylation and activation of PI3K/AKT and MAPK pathways for glucose uptake and metabolism.
  • Acetylcholine → Ligand-Gated Ion Channel (B-4)
    • Nicotinic receptors function as ligand-gated ion channels, allowing Na⁺ and K⁺ influx upon binding.
  • Growth Hormone → JAK/STAT (C-1)
    • Binds to growth hormone receptor, activating JAK kinases, which phosphorylate STAT proteins to regulate gene transcription.
  • Thyroxine → Nuclear Receptor (D-2)
    • T₄/T₃ enters the cell, binds thyroid hormone receptor (TR) in the nucleus, and regulates gene transcription for metabolism control.

Hormone Receptor Signaling Mechanisms

Hormone

Receptor Type

Mechanism

Insulin

Tyrosine Kinase

Activates PI3K/AKT & MAPK pathways, leading to glucose uptake and metabolic effects.

Acetylcholine

Ligand-Gated Ion Channel

Nicotinic receptors allow Na⁺ and K⁺ influx, leading to rapid depolarization.

Growth Hormone

JAK/STAT

Binds cytokine receptor, activates JAK, leading to STAT phosphorylation and gene transcription.

Thyroxine (T₄)

Nuclear Receptor

T₄/T₃ binds nuclear receptors, modulating transcription of metabolic genes.

questions.text:
The O2 saturation with respect to PO₂ is marked as A. What happens to the Oxygen Hb dissociation curve upon transfusion of stored RBC?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) B

 

Explanation:

  • Stored RBCs have reduced 2,3-BPG levels due to metabolic depletion during storage.
  • 2,3-BPG normally promotes oxygen unloading by decreasing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.
  • With low 2,3-BPG, hemoglobin binds oxygen more tightly, leading to a leftward shift (Curve B) in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.
  • This results in impaired oxygen delivery to tissues, as hemoglobin holds onto oxygen more strongly.

Effects of Stored RBC Transfusion on the Dissociation Curve

Factor

Effect on O₂ Dissociation Curve

Impact

Low 2,3-BPG

Leftward shift (B)

Increased O₂ affinity, reduced unloading

Acidosis

Rightward shift

Enhances oxygen unloading

Alkalosis

Leftward shift

Increases oxygen binding

Hypercapnia (↑ CO₂)

Rightward shift

Enhances oxygen release

Hypothermia

Leftward shift

Decreases oxygen unloading

 

C (Option B): Incorrect because stored RBCs initially reduce oxygen unloading (left shift) rather than increasing it.

D (Option C): Incorrect because a linear curve does not reflect the physiological response to stored RBC transfusion.

E (Option D): Incorrect because increased cooperativity does not explain the primary effect of stored RBC transfusion.

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypoxia

 

Explanation:

  • Peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid and aortic bodies) primarily respond to low arterial oxygen (PaO₂).
  • They are activated when PaO₂ falls below 60 mmHg, increasing ventilation to restore oxygen levels.
  • While they also respond to hypercapnia and acidosis, the central chemoreceptors in the medulla are more sensitive to CO₂ and pH changes.

Peripheral Chemoreceptors and Their Sensitivity

Stimulus

Effect on Peripheral Chemoreceptors

Hypoxia (↓ PaO₂)

Strongest stimulus, leading to increased ventilation.

Hypercapnia (↑ PaCO₂)

Weak response; central chemoreceptors dominate.

Acidosis (↓ pH)

Peripheral response occurs, but central chemoreceptors are more significant.

Alkalosis (↑ pH)

Minimal effect; detected mainly by central chemoreceptors.

Hypercapnia (Option A): Incorrect because central chemoreceptors primarily regulate CO₂ levels, while peripheral chemoreceptors have a weaker response.

Acidosis (Option C): Incorrect because although peripheral chemoreceptors detect acidosis, central chemoreceptors play a dominant role.

Alkalosis (Option D): Incorrect because alkalosis does not significantly stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Decrease in Glomerular coefficient

 

Explanation:

  • Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) depends on filtration surface area and membrane permeability, both represented by the glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf).
  • A decrease in Kf occurs due to glomerular damage, thickening of the basement membrane, or mesangial cell contraction, leading to reduced filtration.
  • Conditions like chronic kidney disease (CKD) and diabetic nephropathy reduce Kf, thereby decreasing GFR.

Factors Affecting GFR

Factor

Effect on GFR

Glomerular coefficient (Kf)

↓ Kf → ↓ GFR (e.g., glomerular disease, fibrosis).

Glomerular oncotic pressure (πG)

↑ πG → ↓ GFR (e.g., dehydration, increased plasma proteins).

Glomerular hydrostatic pressure (PGC)

↑ PGC → ↑ GFR (e.g., hypertension).

Bowman’s hydrostatic pressure (PBS)

↑ PBS → ↓ GFR (e.g., urinary obstruction).

Decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure (Option B): Incorrect because lower oncotic pressure would increase filtration, thereby increasing GFR.

Increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure (Option C): Incorrect because higher hydrostatic pressure in the glomerulus promotes filtration, increasing GFR.

Decrease of Bowman's hydrostatic pressure (Option D): Incorrect because a lower Bowman’s capsule pressure would reduce resistance to filtration, leading to an increase in GFR.

questions.text: Physiological dead space?

choices.text: Is lesser than anatomical dead space

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Represents inadequately perfused alveoli

 

Explanation:

  • Physiological dead space includes both anatomical dead space (conducting airways) and alveolar dead space (alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused).
  • It occurs when some alveoli receive air but lack sufficient blood flow, leading to inefficient gas exchange.
  • It is calculated using Bohr’s equation, which considers the difference between arterial and expired CO₂ levels.

Physiological Dead Space

Concept

Description

Anatomical Dead Space

Conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs (e.g., trachea, bronchi).

Alveolar Dead Space

Alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused, contributing to wasted ventilation.

Physiological Dead Space

Sum of anatomical and alveolar dead space; reflects ineffective ventilation.

Can be measured by spirometry (Option A): Incorrect because spirometry measures lung volumes but cannot differentiate dead space ventilation.

Is lesser than anatomical dead space (Option B): Incorrect because physiological dead space is always equal to or greater than anatomical dead space.

Represents inadequately ventilated alveoli (Option C): Incorrect because it is related to perfusion failure, not ventilation failure (which occurs in shunt physiology).

questions.text:
What contributes to the latent period of muscle twitch?

 

1. Neuromuscular transmission

2. Excitation contraction coupling

3. Reuptake of calcium back into sarcoplasmic reticulum

4. Transmission impulse from nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,2,4

 

Explanation:

  • Neuromuscular transmission initiates muscle contraction by releasing acetylcholine (ACh) at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Excitation-contraction coupling propagates the action potential along the T-tubules and triggers Ca²⁺ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Transmission impulse from the nerve carries the action potential along the motor neuron to stimulate the muscle.

Latent Period of Muscle Twitch

Process

Role in Latent Period

Neuromuscular transmission

ACh release at the neuromuscular junction triggers muscle fiber depolarization.

Excitation-contraction coupling

Action potential spreads through T-tubules, leading to Ca²⁺ release.

Nerve impulse transmission

Action potential travels along the motor neuron to reach the muscle.

1, 2 (Option A): Incorrect because nerve impulse transmission is a crucial step before neuromuscular transmission and excitation-contraction coupling.

1, 2, 3 (Option B): Incorrect because reuptake of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum occurs during the relaxation phase, not the latent period.

1, 4 (Option C): Incorrect because excitation-contraction coupling is essential for Ca²⁺ release, and without it, contraction cannot occur.

questions.text:
Which of these systems do not require ATP?

 

1. Paracellular

2. Simple diffusion

3. Facilitated diffusion

4. Antiport (Na/K ATPase)

5. Symport
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1,2,3

 

Explanation:

  • Paracellular transport occurs through tight junctions between cells and does not require ATP.
  • Simple diffusion is the passive movement of molecules across the lipid bilayer, driven by a concentration gradient.
  • Facilitated diffusion involves carrier proteins or channels but moves substances passively down their concentration gradient.
  • Antiport (Na/K ATPase) is an active transport system that requires ATP to function.
  • Symport relies on secondary active transport, which is indirectly powered by ATP.

Transport Mechanisms in the Body

Transport Type

Mechanism

ATP Requirement

Example

Paracellular transport

Movement of substances between cells via tight junctions

No

Ion movement in renal tubules

Simple diffusion

Passive movement down a concentration gradient

No

Oxygen, carbon dioxide transport

Facilitated diffusion

Carrier or channel-mediated passive transport

No

GLUT-mediated glucose transport

Antiport (Na/K ATPase)

Active transport pumping ions in opposite directions

Yes (Primary active transport)

Na⁺/K⁺ pump in all cells

Symport

Cotransport of two molecules in the same direction

Yes (Secondary active transport)

Na⁺/Glucose cotransport in intestines

Paracellular (Option 1): Correct because it allows passive movement of ions between epithelial cells without ATP.

Simple Diffusion (Option 2): Correct because it relies on the natural concentration gradient and does not need energy.

Facilitated Diffusion (Option 3): Correct because it uses transport proteins for movement down the gradient but does not consume ATP.

Antiport (Na/K ATPase) (Option 4): Incorrect because it is an active transport mechanism that requires ATP to pump Na⁺ and K⁺ against their gradients.

Symport (Option 5): Incorrect because it relies on secondary active transport, which uses ATP indirectly via the Na/K ATPase pump.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of back pain, stiffness, and recurrent episodes of eye pain with redness. On examination, they are found to have anterior uveitis and sacroiliitis. Which of the following HLA is commonly involved
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) HLA B27

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of back pain, stiffness, anterior uveitis and sacroiliitis.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)
 

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

 

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)
 

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

 

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint

 
  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae

 
  • Bamboo spine

 
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign

 
  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

 

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test
 

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test


 

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance
 

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)
 

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

questions.text: A 45-year old female met with an accident and was brought to trauma centre and X-ray pelvis was performed and image is given below shows Intracapsular fracture NOF. What is the management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Open reduction+ Internal fixation

Explanation:

The best course of management in an Intracapsular neck of femur fracture in a 45 year old female is open reduction and internal fixation, due to higher risk of avascular necrosis.

Neck of femur fractures and intertrochanteric fractures

 

Aspect

Neck of Femur Fracture

Intertrochanteric Fracture

Location

Intracapsular (within the joint capsule)

Extracapsular (outside the joint capsule)

Age Group

Typically after 50 years

Typically after 60 years

Sex

Female > Male

Male > Female

Common Patient Demographics

Elderly (low-energy trauma like falls)

Elderly (low-energy trauma); rare high-energy trauma in younger patients

Mechanism of Injury

Trivial, low-energy trauma (osteoporotic)

Low-energy trauma in elderly; usually requires significant trauma in younger patients

Stability

Less stable, especially if displaced

Generally unstable due to muscle forces and location

Ability to Walk

May be possible in impacted fractures

Walking is not possible due to the instability

External Rotation Deformity

Less than 45º

More than 45º

Shortening

Less than 1 inch

More than 1 inch

Blood Supply Involvement

High risk of avascular necrosis (medial circumflex artery disruption)

Lower risk of avascular necrosis

Blood Loss

Less blood loss due to intracapsular location

More blood loss due to the involvement of surrounding vascular structures

Pain, Severity, and Tenderness

Mild to moderate pain localized to the groin/hip region. Tenderness is typically felt in Scarpa’s triangle.

Severe pain, more generalized around the hip with marked tenderness over the greater trochanter. Weight-bearing is difficult or impossible.

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced: Internal fixation (Option D) (e.g., cannulated screws)
  • Displaced: Surgical fixation (hemiarthroplasty (Option B ruled out), total hip replacement)

Almost always requires internal fixation (e.g., dynamic hip screws, intramedullary nails)

Complications

High risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis

Malunion is more common than nonunion
 

Closed reduction (Option A) is not done because there is a high risk of avascular necrosis and non union of fracture

Open + Closed reduction (Option C) cannot be done at the same time and is not the best course of action.

questions.text: Fracture after trivial fall in elderly patient. Identify the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Bone metastasis

Explanation:

Bony metastasis is the most common cause of pathological fracture in elderly.

Metastatic Tumors to Bone

Common Metastatic Tumors
  • Lung carcinoma (male)
  • Breast carcinoma (female)
  • Prostate carcinoma (Osteoblastic)
  • Thyroid carcinoma

Clinical Features
  • Known Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain (common in spine, ribs, extremities)
    • Pathological fracture (common in spine and hip)
 
  • Unknown Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain leading to destructive lesion diagnosis
    • Pathological fracture due to weakened bone

Malignancies Presenting with Silent Primary
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Bladder carcinoma

Common Sites of Metastasis
  • Vertebral bodies
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis (Option A)
  • Humerus
  • Femur
  • Uncommon distal to elbow and knee

TB hip (Option B) generally causes chronic symptoms such as pain, swelling, and stiffness, and may eventually lead to deformity of the hip joint.

  • TB hip would present with more severe symptoms prior to a fracture.

A brown tumour (Option C) is associated with hyperparathyroidism, which causes bone resorption and weakening.

  • They are typically associated with chronic conditions like primary hyperparathyroidism or secondary hyperparathyroidism

Eosinophilic granuloma (a form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis) (Option D) is a rare condition more commonly seen in children or young adults.

questions.text: FRAX is
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Fracture Risk assessment tool

Explanation:

FRAX (Fracture Risk assessment tool):

  • Purpose:
    • Predicts the 10-year risk of major osteoporotic fractures and hip fractures.
    • Helps guide treatment decisions in osteoporosis management.
  • Parameters Used:
    • Age: Older age increases fracture risk.
    • Sex: Women generally have a higher risk due to lower bone density.
    • Height and weight
    • Previous fracture: A history of previous fractures, especially after the age of 50, increases the risk.
    • Parental hip fracture: A family history of hip fractures in a parent increases the risk.
    • Smoking history: Smoking is a risk factor for lower bone density and higher fracture risk.
    • Glucocorticoid use: Long-term use of corticosteroids weakens bones, increasing fracture risk.
    • Rheumatoid arthritis: This autoimmune condition is associated with increased fracture risk due to both inflammation and the use of medications like steroids.
    • Alcohol consumption: Excessive alcohol intake (more than 3 drinks per day) increases fracture risk.
    • Bone mineral density (BMD): If available, a BMD measurement at the femoral neck or spine can be included to refine risk. A lower BMD increases the risk of fractures.
  • BMD in calculation:
    • Without BMD: FRAX can calculate the fracture risk using only the clinical risk factors.
    • With BMD: FRAX provides a more accurate risk estimate by combining clinical factors with the actual BMD value (T-score).
  • Output:
    • The FRAX tool generates a percentage probability of having a major osteoporotic fracture or a hip fracture in the next 10 years, also provides both absolute risk and relative risk compared to the general population.

questions.text: Jackson Rees circuit is used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pediatric anaesthesia

 

Explanation:

  • Type of Circuit: The Jackson-Rees circuit is a modification of the Mapleson F system.
  • Patient Population: It is commonly used in pediatric anesthesia, particularly in infants and small children.

Jackson-Rees Circuit in Pediatric Anesthesia

Feature

Details

Circuit Type

Modification of Mapleson F circuit

Common Usage

Pediatric anesthesia

Ventilation Mode

Both controlled and spontaneous ventilation

Dead Space

Low, making it suitable for neonates and infants

Advantages

Low resistance, ease of use, and good control over ventilation

Components

Fresh gas flow, reservoir bag, expiratory limb with an open end

Cardiac anaesthesia (Option B): Incorrect because the Jackson-Rees circuit is mainly used in pediatrics, whereas cardiac anesthesia typically requires closed-circuit ventilation with controlled settings.

 

Neuro anaesthesia (Option C): Incorrect because neuroanesthesia patients require precise ventilation control, often achieved with mechanical ventilators.

 

Obstetric anaesthesia (Option D): Incorrect because obstetric anesthesia mainly involves spinal, epidural, or general anesthesia with different breathing circuits.

questions.text: A female following an RTA injured her chest. On X-ray, fracture of 3rd to 5th ribs was noted. Pain was not responsive to analgesics. Which block will be given to reduce the pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thoracic epidural block

 

Explanation:

  • Pain Origin: The patient has rib fractures (3rd to 5th ribs), leading to severe pain that is not relieved by analgesics.
  • Best Pain Management: A thoracic epidural block provides excellent analgesia for rib fractures by blocking intercostal nerves at multiple levels.
  • Mechanism: It involves injecting local anesthetics and opioids into the thoracic epidural space, leading to segmental pain relief without systemic opioid side effects.
  • Indications: Used for rib fractures, thoracic surgeries, and trauma-related pain management.

Thoracic Epidural Block in Rib Fractures

Feature

Details

Indication

Rib fractures, thoracic surgeries, trauma pain

Mechanism

Blocks intercostal nerves via epidural space

Level of Block

Usually T4-T8, depending on rib injury

Drugs Used

Local anesthetics (e.g., bupivacaine) + opioids (e.g., fentanyl)

Advantages

Superior pain control, reduces respiratory complications, prevents opioid overuse

Complications

Hypotension, motor blockade, infection (rare)

 

Cervical block (Option A): Incorrect because cervical plexus blocks are used for neck surgeries, not rib fractures.

 

Supra-clavicular block (Option C): Incorrect because it targets the brachial plexus and is used for upper limb anesthesia, not chest pain.

 

Lumbar epidural block (Option D): Incorrect because lumbar epidurals are used for lower body surgeries and labor analgesia, not rib fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes adrenal suppression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Etomidate

 

Explanation:

  • Etomidate inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, an enzyme essential for cortisol synthesis in the adrenal glands.
  • Single-dose administration can cause transient adrenal suppression, and prolonged use can lead to critical illness-related corticosteroid insufficiency (CIRCI).
  • It is often avoided in septic and critically ill patients due to the risk of adrenal insufficiency.
  • Despite minimal cardiovascular depression, its use is limited in critically ill patients due to its endocrine effects.

Etomidate and Adrenal Suppression

Feature

Details

Drug Class

Intravenous anesthetic

Mechanism of Adrenal Suppression

Inhibition of 11β-hydroxylase

Effect Duration

Lasts 6-24 hours after a single dose

Clinical Impact

Reduces cortisol production, leading to adrenal insufficiency

Contraindications

Sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, critically ill patients

Advantages

Minimal cardiovascular depression, rapid onset

 

Thiopental (Option A): Incorrect because it does not inhibit cortisol synthesis and has no significant adrenal suppression effects.

 

Ketamine (Option B): Incorrect because ketamine does not affect adrenal function; it increases sympathetic tone and is often used in shock.

 

Propofol (Option D): Incorrect because it does not cause adrenal suppression, though it can cause hypotension due to vasodilation.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding thiopentone?

choices.text: It achieves maximum concentration in the brain after an IV infusion
Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen
Rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

 

Explanation:

  • Thiopentone is a highly lipid-soluble barbiturate, allowing rapid penetration into the brain.
  • Peak brain concentration occurs quickly after IV administration due to high cerebral perfusion.
  • Redistribution from the brain to muscle and adipose tissue leads to a rapid decline in anesthetic effect within minutes.
  • Termination of action is due to redistribution, not renal excretion. Renal elimination is slow and plays a minimal role in terminating its effect.

Pharmacokinetics of Thiopentone

Feature

Details

Drug Class

Barbiturate

Solubility

Highly lipid-soluble

Onset of Action

Rapid (within 30 seconds IV)

Termination of Effect

Redistribution to muscle and fat

Metabolism

Hepatic metabolism (slow clearance)

Excretion

Primarily renal but not responsible for rapid effect decline

Clinical Uses

Induction of anesthesia, status epilepticus, neuroprotection

 

It is lipid soluble (Option A): Correct because thiopentone is highly lipid-soluble, allowing rapid CNS penetration.

It achieves maximum concentration in the brain after an IV infusion (Option B): Correct because peak brain levels occur within seconds after IV injection.

Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen (Option C): Correct because redistribution accounts for rapid recovery from anesthesia rather than metabolism or excretion.

Rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion (Option D): Incorrect because the effect declines due to redistribution, not renal clearance.

questions.text: Which of the following must be avoided in post cardiac arrest resuscitation care?

choices.text: Revascularisation procedure if patient develops ST elevation post resuscitation
Bring the body temperature down to below 32 degrees, therapeutic hypothermia if unresponsive

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bring the body temperature down to below 32 degrees, therapeutic hypothermia if unresponsive

 

Explanation:

  • Targeted Temperature Management (TTM) is recommended between 32–36°C, but below 32°C is not advised due to potential risks like arrhythmias and coagulopathies.
  • Therapeutic hypothermia (TTM) should be maintained at 32–36°C for at least 24 hours in comatose patients after cardiac arrest to reduce neurological damage.
  • Excessive cooling (<32°C) increases complications such as bradycardia, electrolyte imbalances, and impaired coagulation.

Post-Cardiac Arrest Care

  • Post-cardiac arrest care focuses on stabilizing the patient, preventing secondary organ damage, and optimizing neurological outcomes.
  • It includes hemodynamic management, targeted temperature management (TTM), oxygenation, and coronary intervention when indicated.

Aspect

Key Considerations

Hemodynamic Support

Maintain MAP ≥ 65 mmHg with fluids and vasopressors if needed to ensure adequate cerebral and organ perfusion.

Oxygenation & Ventilation

Target SpO₂ between 94–98% to prevent hypoxia and hyperoxia-related injury. Avoid excessive ventilation (PaCO₂ should be maintained at 35–45 mmHg).

Targeted Temperature Management (TTM)

Maintain temperature at 32–36°C for at least 24 hours in comatose patients to reduce neurological injury. Cooling below 32°C is not recommended due to increased risks of arrhythmias and coagulopathies.

Coronary Revascularization

Patients with ST elevation post-resuscitation should undergo urgent PCI to improve outcomes. Coronary angiography may also be considered in select non-ST elevation cases.

Neurological Monitoring

Continuous EEG and serial neurological assessments are crucial to detect seizures and assess prognosis.

Glucose Control

Maintain blood glucose between 140–180 mg/dL to prevent hyperglycemia-induced neuronal damage.

 

Maintain MAP over 65 (Option A): Correct because maintaining adequate perfusion pressure (MAP ≥ 65 mmHg) is essential to prevent organ hypoxia.

 

Maintain SpO₂ above 94% (Option B): Correct because post-resuscitation oxygenation should be between 94–98% to avoid both hypoxia and hyperoxia toxicity.

 

Revascularisation procedure if patient develops ST elevation post resuscitation (Option C): Correct because emergency PCI should be done in post-cardiac arrest patients with STEMI to improve survival.

questions.text: Ambu aura 40 is an example of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 1

 

Explanation:

  • Ambu Aura 40 is a second-generation supraglottic airway device designed for improved airway protection and ventilation.
  • It includes a gastric drainage channel, which helps reduce the risk of aspiration, a key feature of second-generation devices.
  • Better sealing pressure compared to first-generation devices, allowing for effective positive pressure ventilation.
  • Commonly used in elective and emergency airway management.

 

Generations of Supraglottic Airways (SGAs)

  • Supraglottic airway devices are classified into generations based on their features.
  • Higher generations offer improved airway protection and better ventilation control.

Generation

Features

Examples

Generation 1

No gastric drainage, basic airway management

LMA Classic, Ambu Aura Once

Generation 2

Gastric drainage channel, better seal, aspiration protection

Ambu Aura 40, LMA Supreme, ProSeal LMA

Generation 3

Dual-lumen design, advanced sealing, integrated bite block

LMA Protector

Generation 4

Smart/intelligent airway control, integrated real-time monitoring

(Still under research)

 

Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 1 (Option A): Incorrect because first-generation devices lack a gastric drainage tube, while Ambu Aura 40 has one.

 

Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 3 (Option C): Incorrect because third-generation SGAs have more advanced sealing and monitoring features, which Ambu Aura 40 lacks.

 

Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 4 (Option D): Incorrect because fourth-generation SGAs are not yet widely available, and Ambu Aura 40 does not belong to this category.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best study design as per hierarchy of evidence?
questions.solution:
• Hierarchy of Evidence: Meta-analysis ranks at the top of the evidence hierarchy as it synthesizes data from multiple high-quality studies.
  • Combines Results: It pools results from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) or observational studies, increasing statistical power and reliability.
  • Best for Decision-Making: Used in evidence-based medicine (EBM) to guide clinical practice by summarizing large amounts of data.
  • Higher Level than RCTs: While RCTs provide strong evidence, a meta-analysis of multiple high-quality RCTs offers even stronger conclusions.

Hierarchy of Evidence in Clinical Research

In evidence-based medicine, study designs are ranked based on their reliability in guiding clinical decision-making.

Level

Study Design

Strength of Evidence

1a

Meta-analysis of RCTs

Highest - Combines data from multiple studies for stronger conclusions.

1b

Large RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial)

Strong - Best for causality, but single studies may have limitations.

2a

Cohort Study

Moderate - Observational, used for prognosis and risk factor assessment.

2b

Case-Control Study

Weaker - Retrospective, useful for rare diseases.

3

Cross-sectional & Case Series

Weak - Descriptive, no causal inference.

4

Expert Opinion & Case Reports

Weakest - No statistical comparison, potential bias.

 

Case control study (Option B): Incorrect because case-control studies are retrospective and prone to bias, ranking lower in the hierarchy.

 

Cohort study (Option C): Incorrect because while prospective cohort studies provide stronger evidence than case-control studies, they are inferior to RCTs and meta-analyses.

 

Large RCT (Option D): Incorrect because while RCTs are the gold standard for individual studies, a meta-analysis of multiple RCTs provides even higher-quality evidence.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of experimental study -

 


	Blinding
	Randomization
	Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria
	Statistical analysis
questions.solution:
Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria (Step C)

  • Establishes the study population by selecting appropriate participants.

Randomization (Step B)

  • Assigns participants into different groups (e.g., treatment vs. control) to reduce bias.

Blinding (Step A)

  • Ensures that patients, investigators, or data analysts are unaware of group assignments to prevent bias.

Statistical analysis (Step D)

  • After data collection, statistical tests are applied to determine the significance of results.

Therefore, C → B → A → D
(Defining criteria → Randomization → Blinding → Statistical analysis)

This sequence ensures a methodologically sound experimental study that minimizes bias and improves validity.

Steps in an Experimental Study

Experimental studies, such as randomized controlled trials (RCTs), follow a structured process to ensure validity and minimize bias.

Step

Description

1. Defining Inclusion & Exclusion Criteria

Determines which participants are eligible for the study, ensuring a uniform population.

2. Randomization

Randomly assigns participants into groups (e.g., treatment vs. control) to eliminate selection bias.

3. Blinding

Conceals group allocation from participants, investigators, or both to reduce bias.

4. Intervention Implementation

The experimental treatment is administered while maintaining study protocols.

5. Data Collection

Outcome measures are recorded systematically for further analysis.

6. Statistical Analysis

Data is processed using statistical tests to evaluate the treatment effect.

7. Interpretation & Reporting

Findings are interpreted, conclusions are drawn, and results are published.

 

B → C → A → D: Incorrect because randomization cannot occur before defining the study population.

 

A → B → C → D: Incorrect because blinding happens after randomization and selection of participants.

 

C → A → B → D: Incorrect because randomization must occur before blinding to ensure unbiased group assignment.

questions.text: You have gone to a village for screening where people have diabetes and hypertension. What type of screening is done for family members of these patients who show up in large numbers?
questions.solution:
• High-risk screening targets individuals at increased risk due to family history, occupation, or exposure.
  • In this case, family members of diabetic and hypertensive patients are at a higher genetic and lifestyle risk of developing these conditions.
  • This approach optimizes resources by focusing on a subgroup with a greater probability of disease, improving early detection and intervention.

Types of Screening in Public Health

Screening programs are classified based on population coverage and purpose.

Type of Screening

Description

Example

Mass screening

Testing entire populations, regardless of risk.

Screening all adults in a village for hypertension.

High-risk screening

Targeting individuals with known risk factors.

Screening family members of diabetics for early detection.

Multiphasic screening

Conducting multiple tests in one session to detect various diseases.

Screening for diabetes, hypertension, and cholesterol simultaneously.

Anonymous screening

Testing where participants' identities remain unknown.

HIV screening in high-risk populations without recording names.

 

Multiphasic screening (Option A): Incorrect because this involves testing multiple diseases in one go, rather than focusing on a high-risk group.

 

Mass screening (Option B): Incorrect because mass screening includes everyone, not just high-risk individuals.

 

Anonymous screening (Option D): Incorrect because identity is not concealed in this scenario; screening is based on family history.

questions.text: Which of the following groups is not included in the high-risk core population for HIV transmission?

choices.text: Men who have sex with men

questions.solution:
• High-risk core population refers to groups with a direct and sustained role in HIV transmission due to high-risk behaviors.
  • IV drug users (IDUs), female sex workers (FSWs), and men who have sex with men (MSM) are considered core populations because they have higher transmission rates and can spread the virus efficiently within and beyond their networks.
  • Long-distance truck drivers (LDTD) are part of the bridge population—individuals who connect the core population to the general population but are not themselves a core group.

High-Risk Core Populations for HIV Transmission

HIV transmission risk groups are classified into core populations (highest risk) and bridge populations (who facilitate wider spread).

Group

Category

Rationale

IV drug users (IDUs)

Core

High HIV risk due to needle sharing and risky sexual behavior.

Female sex workers (FSWs)

Core

Engage in frequent unprotected sex, increasing exposure.

Men who have sex with men (MSM)

Core

Higher prevalence of unprotected anal sex, a major HIV transmission route.

Long-distance truck drivers (LDTD)

Bridge

They interact with core populations (FSWs, IDUs) and spread HIV to the general population but are not core transmitters themselves.

 

IV drug users (Option A): Incorrect because needle sharing and risky behaviors place them in the core group.

 

Female sex workers (Option B): Incorrect because FSWs have a high number of sexual partners, making them a key core group.

 

Men who have sex with men (Option C): Incorrect because MSM have a high prevalence of HIV due to unprotected sex, placing them in the core group.

questions.text: Malaria detection on the field is done by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• HRP2 antigen-based Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT) is the preferred method for malaria detection in field settings due to its quick results (15–20 minutes), ease of use, and minimal technical expertise requirement.
  • RDTs detect Plasmodium falciparum-specific HRP2 antigen or Plasmodium lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) for all species.
  • Unlike microscopy (thick/thin smear), RDTs do not require a microscope or trained personnel, making them ideal for remote and resource-limited areas.

Malaria Detection Methods

Method

Principle

Best Used In

Limitations

Thick smear

Concentrates parasites for better detection

Diagnosis in labs with microscopy

Requires staining and expertise

Thin smear

Used to identify species and parasite morphology

Differentiating Plasmodium species

Less sensitive in low parasitemia

HRP2 antigen / RDT

Detects malarial antigens (HRP2 or pLDH)

Field settings, rapid diagnosis

Cannot detect low parasitemia or HRP2-deleted strains

Quantitative Buffy Coat (QBC)

Fluorescent staining of parasites in WBC fraction

High-sensitivity lab settings

Expensive, requires specialized equipment

 

Thick smear (Option A): Incorrect because, while sensitive, it requires staining, microscopy, and expertise, making it impractical for field use.

 

Thin smear (Option B): Incorrect because it is primarily used for species identification, not rapid detection in the field.

 

Quantitative Buffy Coat (Option D): Incorrect because it requires specialized equipment and is not feasible in field settings.

questions.text: Dr. Sarah made a presentation on Infectious diseases. She spoke about prevention and treatment of Zika virus. Which of the following is true with respect to the prevention of Zika virus?

choices.text: Purified, inactivated FDA approved vaccine is found to be helpful in prevention
Sexual abstinence, using condoms, delaying pregnancy is helpful in controlling the disease
Immunoglobulin and plasmapheresis is used in the treatment of Zika

questions.solution:
• Zika virus spreads primarily through Aedes mosquito bites and sexual transmission.
  • Sexual transmission is well-documented, hence abstinence, condom use, and delaying pregnancy help prevent spread.
  • No FDA-approved vaccine is available for Zika virus prevention.
  • Symptomatic treatment is given, but NSAIDs are avoided initially due to the risk of hemorrhagic complications in dengue co-infection.
  • Immunoglobulin and plasmapheresis are not standard treatments for Zika virus.

 

Zika Virus – Epidemiology, Prevention, and Control

Overview of Zika Virus

Zika virus is a Flavivirus transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes (A. aegypti and A. albopictus). It causes mild flu-like illness, but severe complications include congenital Zika syndrome (microcephaly) and Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Modes of Transmission

  • Mosquito bites – Primary mode of spread.
  • Sexual transmission – Virus persists in semen, vaginal fluids.
  • Maternal-fetal transmission – Can cause congenital defects.
  • Blood transfusion – Rare but possible.

Prevention Strategies for Zika Virus

Prevention Method

Effectiveness

Mechanism

Mosquito control

Highly effective

Elimination of breeding sites, insecticide use

Personal protection

Effective

Wearing long sleeves, using insect repellents

Sexual abstinence/condoms

Effective

Prevents sexual transmission of the virus

Delaying pregnancy

Advised in endemic areas

Reduces risk of congenital Zika syndrome

Vaccination

Not available

No FDA-approved vaccine exists yet

NSAIDs for treatment

Initially avoided

Risk of bleeding if dengue co-infection is present

Immunoglobulin & plasmapheresis

Not standard treatment

No proven benefit in Zika virus management

Why No Vaccine Yet?

  • Zika virus is structurally similar to dengue virus, leading to concerns about antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE).
  • Several vaccines are under development, but no FDA-approved vaccine exists.

Symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs (Option A): Incorrect because NSAIDs are avoided initially due to the risk of bleeding in possible dengue co-infection.

 

Purified, inactivated FDA-approved vaccine (Option B): Incorrect because no FDA-approved vaccine exists for Zika virus prevention.

 

Immunoglobulin and plasmapheresis (Option D): Incorrect because they are not used in routine Zika virus treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not recommended after 65 years?
questions.solution:
• HPV vaccine is not routinely recommended after 26 years and is generally not given after 45 years, as older individuals are less likely to benefit.
  • Influenza, Pneumococcal, and Herpes Zoster vaccines are strongly recommended for adults ≥65 years to prevent severe infections.
  • HPV vaccination is primarily for younger individuals to prevent cervical and other HPV-related cancers.
  • Older adults have likely been exposed to HPV already, reducing vaccine efficacy.

Adult Vaccination Recommendations (≥65 Years)

Aging individuals face an increased risk of respiratory infections, viral reactivation, and opportunistic infections due to immune decline. Vaccination is a critical preventive strategy.

Recommended Vaccines for Adults ≥65 Years

Vaccine

Purpose

Recommended After 65?

Influenza

Prevents seasonal flu complications

Yes, annually

Pneumococcal (PCV15/PCV20, PPSV23)

Prevents pneumonia, bacteremia, meningitis

Yes, once or as per schedule

Herpes Zoster (Recombinant Zoster Vaccine - RZV)

Prevents shingles and postherpetic neuralgia

Yes, 2 doses after 50 years

Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis (Tdap/Td)

Prevents tetanus and pertussis

Yes, booster every 10 years

COVID-19

Reduces risk of severe COVID-19

Yes, as per updated recommendations

HPV

Prevents cervical and other cancers

Not recommended after 45 years

Why is the HPV Vaccine Not Given After 65?

  • Most individuals are already exposed to HPV by this age.
  • Vaccine efficacy is highest in younger populations (9-26 years).
  • No added benefit in older adults, as HPV-related cancer risk decreases.

Influenza (Option A): Incorrect because annual flu vaccination is recommended to prevent severe complications.

 

Herpes Zoster (Option B): Incorrect because shingles risk increases with age, so vaccination is advised after 50 years.

 

Pneumococcal (Option C): Incorrect because pneumococcal vaccine is recommended after 65 years to prevent pneumonia and invasive infections.

questions.text: All are live vaccines except:
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a live vaccine.

Live vaccines contain attenuated (weakened) pathogens that induce a strong immune response.

Rotavirus, Measles, and Varicella vaccines are all live attenuated vaccines.

Hepatitis B vaccine contains HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) and is inactivated.

 

Live vs. Inactivated Vaccines

Vaccines can be classified into live attenuated vaccines and inactivated vaccines based on their mechanism of inducing immunity.

Live Attenuated Vaccines (LAVs)

  • Contain weakened versions of the pathogen.
  • Provide strong, long-lasting immunity with fewer doses.
  • Not given to immunocompromised individuals due to risk of reactivation.

Examples of Live Vaccines:

Vaccine

Disease Prevented

Rotavirus

Rotavirus gastroenteritis

Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR)

Measles, Mumps, Rubella

Varicella

Chickenpox

Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV)

Poliomyelitis

Yellow Fever

Yellow Fever

BCG

Tuberculosis

Inactivated Vaccines

  • Contain killed or non-infectious components of the pathogen.
  • Require booster doses for sustained immunity.
  • Safer for immunocompromised patients.

Examples of Inactivated Vaccines:

Vaccine

Disease Prevented

Type

Hepatitis B

Hepatitis B

Recombinant subunit

Polio (IPV)

Poliomyelitis

Inactivated

Rabies

Rabies

Inactivated

Influenza (Injectable)

Influenza

Inactivated

COVID-19 (Covaxin, Sinopharm)

COVID-19

Inactivated

 

Rotavirus (Option A): Incorrect because it is a live oral vaccine used to prevent severe rotavirus diarrhea.

 

Measles (Option C): Incorrect because it is part of the MMR vaccine, which is live attenuated.

 

Varicella (Option D): Incorrect because it is a live attenuated vaccine used to prevent chickenpox.

questions.text: A pus swab has been sent for microbiological examination to your lab. After testing the sample how will you discard it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Yellow


Explanation:

  • Pus swabs are considered infectious waste and must be discarded in the appropriate biomedical waste bin.
  • According to BMW (Biomedical Waste) guidelines, highly infectious waste, including cultures, swabs, and dressings, must be discarded in yellow bins.
  • The yellow bin is meant for anatomical, pathological, and infectious waste that requires incineration or deep burial.
  • Other color-coded bins are used for different types of waste (e.g., sharps in white, plastics in red, glass in blue, general waste in black).

 

Biomedical Waste Disposal

Proper segregation and disposal of biomedical waste are essential to prevent infections and environmental contamination.

Biomedical Waste Color Coding & Disposal Methods

Color Bin

Waste Type

Example

Disposal Method

Yellow

Infectious waste, human anatomical waste, microbiological waste

Pus swabs, cultures, dressings, placenta

Incineration or deep burial

Red

Contaminated recyclable waste

IV sets, gloves, syringes without needles

Autoclaving/shredding

Blue

Glassware

Broken vials, slides, ampoules

Disinfection & recycling

Black

General non-infectious waste

Office waste, packaging material

Municipal disposal

White (Puncture-proof)

Sharps waste

Needles, scalpels

Autoclaving & shredding

 

Red (Option A): Incorrect because it is for plastic biomedical waste like IV tubes, gloves, and catheters, not infectious swabs.

 

Blue (Option C): Incorrect because it is used for glass waste like vials and slides, not pus swabs.

 

Black (Option D): Incorrect because it is for general waste like office and household waste, not biohazardous materials.

questions.text: ICER is a unit for which of the following economical analysis?
questions.solution:
• ICER (Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio) is a key metric used in cost-effectiveness analysis (CEA).
  • ICER is calculated as:

ICER= Change in Effectiveness/ Change in Cost​

  • Cost is measured in monetary units (e.g., dollars).
  • Effectiveness is measured in health outcomes (e.g., life-years gained, reduction in disease incidence).
  • CEA helps policymakers compare healthcare interventions based on cost per unit of health benefit.
  • ICER is commonly used in health economics to decide whether a new treatment is worth its cost.

Economic Analysis in Healthcare

Health economic evaluations help determine the best use of resources by comparing costs and benefits of different interventions.

Type of Analysis

Measure Used

Unit of Benefit

Example

Cost-Effectiveness Analysis (CEA)

ICER

Natural health units (e.g., life-years gained, infections prevented)

Comparing two drugs for hypertension based on BP reduction

Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA)

Net Monetary Benefit (NMB)

Money

Assessing whether a vaccination program saves more money than it costs

Cost-Utility Analysis (CUA)

Cost per QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year)

QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year)

Comparing cancer treatments based on survival & quality of life

Cost-Minimization Analysis (CMA)

Lowest Cost Option

No effectiveness measure (assumes equal outcomes)

Choosing between two equivalent generic drugs based on price

 

Cost-benefit (Option B): Incorrect because CBA measures outcomes in monetary terms, not effectiveness per cost unit (ICER).

 

Cost-utility (Option C): Incorrect because CUA uses QALY, not ICER, to compare interventions.

 

Cost margin (Option D): Incorrect because "cost margin" is not a standard term in health economic analysis.

questions.text: Universal health coverage (UHC) means that all people and communities receive the quality health services they need, without financial hardship. Which of the following are the challenges to implementing UHC?

choices.text: Inequalities in the distribution, adequate support and access to quality assured products only in low income setting
The purpose of UHC is to find a balance between countries' income, health provision and financial burden
To provide healthcare to everyone regardless of the countries' income
UHC only deals with financial aspect of health and cannot cover health provision to all

questions.solution:
• Universal Health Coverage (UHC) aims to ensure that all individuals receive essential healthcare services without financial hardship, irrespective of their country’s income.
  • Challenges arise in low- and middle-income countries due to financial constraints, infrastructure gaps, and workforce shortages.
  • Providing healthcare to everyone requires balancing resource allocation, government policies, and international support.
  • Countries with lower incomes struggle with financing UHC, requiring external aid, innovative financing, and efficient healthcare systems.
  • While UHC is an ideal goal, the feasibility of full coverage for all remains a major challenge globally.

Universal Health Coverage (UHC)- A Global Challenge

UHC is a key goal of global health initiatives, ensuring access to essential healthcare services without financial hardship for all individuals, regardless of their economic background.

Principles of UHC

Principle

Explanation

Equitable Access

Everyone should receive healthcare regardless of socioeconomic status.

Financial Protection

Out-of-pocket expenses should not cause financial hardship.

Quality Care

Services should be effective, safe, and patient-centered.

Sustainability

Health systems should be designed for long-term viability.

Challenges in Implementing UHC

Challenge

Reason

Limited Financial Resources

Low-income countries struggle to fund universal healthcare.

Healthcare Workforce Shortage

Lack of trained professionals, especially in rural areas.

Infrastructure Gaps

Inadequate hospitals, equipment, and medical supply chains.

Political and Policy Barriers

Differences in government commitment to UHC implementation.

Global Strategies to Overcome UHC Challenges

Strategy

Description

Innovative Financing

Public-private partnerships, health insurance schemes, and global funding.

Technology Integration

Telemedicine and digital health solutions to expand access.

International Support

WHO and global organizations aiding low-income countries.

 

"Inequalities in the distribution, adequate support, and access to quality-assured products only in low-income settings" (Option A): Incorrect because inequalities exist globally, not just in low-income settings.

 

"The purpose of UHC is to find a balance between countries' income, health provision, and financial burden" (Option B): Incorrect because UHC aims to provide healthcare to all, not just balance economic factors.

 

"UHC only deals with the financial aspect of health and cannot cover health provision to all" (Option D): Incorrect because UHC includes both financial protection and healthcare service expansion.

questions.text: A student went on a trip to Jaisalmer, where the temp was 40 degrees, and relative humidity was 20%. What will the mechanism of heat loss be?
questions.solution:
• At high temperatures (40°C), radiation and conduction contribute less to heat loss since the surrounding environment is also hot.
  • Relative humidity is low (20%), which allows for efficient evaporation of sweat from the skin.
  • Evaporation is the most effective cooling mechanism in dry and hot climates, as sweat evaporates quickly, carrying away body heat.
  • Radiation works best when the surrounding environment is cooler than the body, which is not the case here.
  • Conduction requires direct contact with a cooler surface, which is not significant in this scenario.

Mechanisms of Heat Loss in the Human Body

The body regulates temperature through four primary heat loss mechanisms:

Mechanism

Description

Effectiveness in a Hot, Dry Climate

Evaporation

Heat loss through sweat evaporation

Most effective (low humidity allows efficient sweat evaporation)

Radiation

Emission of infrared heat waves to cooler surroundings

Less effective (ambient temp is high, reducing heat gradient)

Conduction

Direct heat transfer through contact with a cooler object

Minimal (air and objects in the desert are also hot)

Convection

Heat transfer via air movement

Limited (unless there is strong wind aiding heat dissipation)

In hot and dry environments like Jaisalmer, evaporation is the dominant mechanism for heat loss, as sweat evaporates efficiently due to low humidity.

Radiation (Option B): Incorrect because radiative heat loss is minimal when ambient temperature is high (40°C).

 

Conduction with air (Option C): Incorrect because air is a poor conductor of heat, and in desert conditions, it is already warm.

 

Conduction with objects (Option D): Incorrect because objects like sand and rocks in Jaisalmer absorb heat and are usually hotter than the body.

questions.text: Which is not a part of Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme?
questions.solution:
he Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) Programme is structured around six key components:

  • 6 Beneficiaries- Target groups include children, adolescents, pregnant and lactating women, and women of reproductive age.
  • 6 Interventions- Includes iron supplementation, deworming, BCC (Behavior Change Communication), dietary diversification, testing, and treatment.
  • 6 Institutional Mechanisms- Ensures effective program implementation through policies, supply chain management, training, etc.
  • However, there is no mention of "6 health functionaries" in the official framework, making it the incorrect option.

Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme

Component

Details

Launch Year

2018

Objective

Reduce anemia prevalence across different population groups

6 Beneficiaries

Children (6-59 months, 5-9 years), Adolescents (10-19 years), Pregnant & Lactating women, Women of reproductive age

6 Interventions

Iron supplementation, Deworming, Delayed cord clamping, BCC, Testing & treatment, Dietary diversification

6 Institutional Mechanisms

Political commitment, Supply chain management, Training & capacity building, Monitoring, Convergence, Research & Innovation

Target

Reduce anemia prevalence by 3% per year

 

6 Beneficiaries (Option A): Correct because AMB targets 6 specific groups.

 

6 Interventions (Option B): Correct as AMB includes 6 strategies to combat anemia.

 

6 Institutional Mechanisms (Option C): Correct since it ensures the smooth implementation of AMB.

questions.text: Which of the following is the 1st to be formed by the migration of the epiblast along the primitive streak?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endoderm

 

Explanation:

  • During gastrulation, epiblast cells migrate through the primitive streak to form the three germ layers.
  • The first cells to migrate displace the hypoblast and form the endoderm.
  • Subsequent migration leads to mesoderm formation, while non-migrating epiblast cells remain as ectoderm.

Gastrulation and Germ Layer Formation

Stage

Description

Primitive Streak Formation

Forms along the midline of the epiblast, marking the site of cell migration.

Endoderm Formation

The first wave of migrating epiblast cells replaces the hypoblast to form the definitive endoderm, which later gives rise to the gut and associated organs.

Mesoderm Formation

Subsequent migration of epiblast cells forms the mesoderm, which differentiates into structures like the cardiac mesoderm and notochord.

Ectoderm Formation

Epiblast cells that do not migrate remain as ectoderm, which later forms the epidermis and neural structures.

Cardiac mesoderm (Option B): Incorrect because it arises from the mesoderm, which forms after the endoderm.

Epidermis (Option C): Incorrect as it originates from ectoderm, which forms last.

Neural groove (Option D): Incorrect since it arises from the ectoderm later during neurulation, after gastrulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Retinal pigment epithelium

 

Explanation:

  • Neural crest cells (NCCs) give rise to a wide variety of structures, including components of the peripheral nervous system, connective tissue, and pigment cells.
  • The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), however, arises from the neural ectoderm, not from neural crest cells.
  • The RPE is derived from the outer layer of the optic cup, which forms from the neural tube.

Derivatives of Neural Crest Cells

Structure

Neural Crest Origin

Ciliary muscles

Derived from neural crest

Ciliary ganglion

Derived from neural crest

Melanocytes

Derived from neural crest

Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

Derived from neural ectoderm

Ciliary muscles (Option A): incorrect because they arise from neural crest cells, forming part of the intraocular muscles.

Ciliary ganglion (Option C): incorrect because it is a parasympathetic ganglion derived from neural crest cells.

Melanocytes (Option D): incorrect because melanocytes originate from neural crest cells, contributing to pigmentation in various tissues.

questions.text:
Identify the marked structure:
 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Primitive streak

 

Explanation:

The primitive streak is the first structure to form during gastrulation, appearing as a linear midline thickening in the epiblast. It acts as the site of cell migration, leading to the formation of the three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm).

Primitive Streak and Its Role in Gastrulation

Stage

Description

Formation

Appears on day 15 of development as a linear thickening in the epiblast of the bilaminar disc.

Function

Acts as a site for epiblast cell migration, which forms the mesoderm and endoderm.

Regression

By the end of the 4th week, the primitive streak regresses, leaving behind the notochord and mesoderm.

Clinical Significance

If it fails to regress, it may lead to sacrococcygeal teratoma (tumor with all three germ layers).

Notochord (Option B): Incorrect because the notochord forms after the primitive streak from mesodermal cells.

Neural Groove (Option C): Incorrect because the neural groove forms later during neurulation, as the neural plate invaginates.
