Secondary Neural Plate (Option D): Incorrect because it is involved in secondary neurulation (formation of the caudal neural tube), not in early gastrulation.

questions.text:
The marked structure serves as a surface landmark for which anatomical structure?


 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stem of lateral sulcus

 

Explanation:

  • The stem of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) serves as a key surface landmark in the brain.
  • It separates the frontal and temporal lobes and extends posteriorly towards the insular cortex.
  • It is an important landmark for neurosurgical approaches and neurovascular structures.
  • The middle cerebral artery (MCA) runs within the lateral sulcus, supplying a major portion of the cerebral cortex.



 

Lateral Sulcus (Sylvian Fissure) and Its Anatomical Importance

Feature

Description

Location

Separates the frontal and temporal lobes

Extends to

Insular cortex and parietal lobe

Contains

Middle cerebral artery (MCA)

Functions

Landmark for neurosurgery, cortical mapping

Related Clinical Importance

MCA strokes affect motor, sensory, and language functions

Pineal gland (Option A): Incorrect because the pineal gland is located near the posterior midline of the brain, not associated with the lateral sulcus.

Wernicke’s area (Option B): Incorrect because Wernicke’s area is found in the posterior superior temporal gyrus, although related to the lateral sulcus, it is not its direct landmark.

Internal carotid artery siphon (Option D): Incorrect because the ICA siphon is an S-shaped bend in the cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery, located near the base of the skull, not directly related to the lateral sulcus.

questions.text:
Identify the marked structure



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Superficial temporal artery

 

Explanation:

  • The superficial temporal artery (STA) is a terminal branch of the external carotid artery.
  • It runs superficially over the zygomatic arch, making it a visible and palpable landmark on the lateral aspect of the head.
  • It supplies the scalp, temporalis muscle, and part of the face.
  • It is commonly involved in temporal arteritis (Giant Cell Arteritis), where biopsy of this artery helps in diagnosis.

Superficial Temporal Artery and Its Significance

Feature

Description

Origin

Terminal branch of the external carotid artery

Course

Runs over the zygomatic arch towards the scalp

Branches

Frontal and parietal branches

Supplies

Scalp, temporalis muscle, face

Clinical Relevance

Temporal arteritis, used in microvascular surgery

Posterior auricular artery (Option B): Incorrect because it arises from the external carotid artery and runs behind the ear, supplying the auricle and scalp, not over the temporal region.

Middle meningeal artery (Option C): Incorrect because it is a branch of the maxillary artery and enters the skull through the foramen spinosum, supplying the dura mater, not the scalp.

Occipital artery (Option D): Incorrect because it arises from the external carotid artery and supplies the posterior scalp and occipital region, not the lateral temporal region.

questions.text:
The posterior end of the marked structure is present at the level of which of the following?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Eustachian tube

 

Explanation:

  • The structure in question is likely the inferior turbinate or the nasal cavity.
  • The posterior end of the inferior nasal meatus, where the inferior turbinate terminates, is near the opening of the Eustachian tube in the nasopharynx.
  • The Eustachian tube connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, allowing pressure equalization.
  • It is located at the level of the posterior end of the inferior turbinate, around the level of the soft palate.

Eustachian Tube and Its Anatomical Relations

Feature

Description

Location

Connects middle ear to nasopharynx

Opening Level

Posterior to the inferior nasal meatus

Function

Equalizes middle ear pressure with the external environment

Relations

Posterior to the inferior turbinate, anterior to the torus tubarius

Clinical Relevance

Dysfunction can lead to otitis media and barotrauma

Sphenopalatine foramen (Option B): Incorrect because it is located in the posterior part of the nasal cavity, transmitting the sphenopalatine artery and nerves, not related to the posterior end of the marked structure.

Odontoid process (Option C): Incorrect because the odontoid process (dens) is a part of the axis (C2 vertebra), far from the nasal cavity.

Sphenoidal sinus (Option D): Incorrect because the sphenoidal sinus is located superiorly in the nasal cavity, draining into the sphenoethmoidal recess, not at the level of the posterior end of the marked structure.

questions.text:
Identify the nerve passing through the marked structure?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Oculomotor nerve

 

Explanation:

  • The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the midbrain and enters the orbit via the superior orbital fissure.
  • It supplies the majority of the extraocular muscles:
    • Superior rectus, Inferior rectus, Medial rectus, Inferior oblique
    • Also levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) for eyelid elevation
  • It carries parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion, which control pupillary constriction.
  • The marked structure is located in the superior orbital fissure, where CN III travels.

Oculomotor Nerve and Its Functions

Feature

Description

Cranial Nerve

CN III

Origin

Midbrain (interpeduncular fossa)

Course

Passes through the cavernous sinus, then through the superior orbital fissure

Muscles Supplied

Superior rectus, Inferior rectus, Medial rectus, Inferior oblique, Levator palpebrae superioris

Parasympathetic Function

Pupil constriction (via ciliary ganglion)

Clinical Importance

CN III palsy causes ptosis, down-and-out gaze, and pupil dilation

Abducens nerve (Option B): Incorrect because CN VI innervates only the lateral rectus muscle and is located more medially in the superior orbital fissure.

Trochlear nerve (Option C): Incorrect because CN IV innervates only the superior oblique muscle, and it is the smallest cranial nerve, running more laterally.

Ophthalmic division (Option D): Incorrect because the ophthalmic division of CN V (V1) is a sensory nerve, not involved in eye muscle movement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male recovering from facial nerve palsy complains of food getting stuck between the cheek and teeth while eating. What is the muscle affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Buccinator

 

Explanation:

  • The buccinator muscle is responsible for compressing the cheek against the teeth, preventing food from accumulating in the vestibule of the mouth.
  • It is innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII) and is often affected in facial nerve palsy.
  • Damage to this muscle leads to difficulty in controlling food while chewing, causing food to get stuck between the cheek and teeth.
  • The buccinator also helps in blowing air out (whistling) and articulation of speech sounds.

Buccinator Muscle and Its Function

Feature

Description

Location

Forms the muscular layer of the cheek

Origin

Alveolar processes of maxilla and mandible, pterygomandibular raphe

Insertion

Blends with fibers of orbicularis oris

Innervation

Facial nerve (CN VII)

Function

Compresses cheek against teeth, aids in chewing and speech

Clinical Relevance

Dysfunction leads to food trapping in the vestibule, difficulty in blowing air

Levator labii superioris (Option B): Incorrect because this muscle elevates the upper lip, contributing to facial expressions but not affecting food trapping.

Zygomaticus major (Option C): Incorrect because it is a smiling muscle, pulling the angle of the mouth superiorly and laterally, unrelated to chewing.

Orbicularis oris (Option D): Incorrect because it closes and puckers the lips, playing a role in speech and whistling, but not in preventing food accumulation in the cheek.

questions.text: Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve leads to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Loss of extension of digits

 

Explanation:

  • The posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) is a branch of the radial nerve, arising from the deep branch after passing through the supinator muscle.
  • It supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm except for the brachioradialis, extensor carpi radialis longus, and anconeus.
  • Injury to the PIN leads to inability to extend the fingers (digits) at the MCP joints while wrist extension is relatively preserved (due to intact ECRL).
  • Sensory function is not affected as the PIN is purely motor.

Posterior Interosseous Nerve Palsy

Feature

Description

Origin

Deep branch of radial nerve (after supinator)

Motor Supply

Extensor digitorum, extensor pollicis longus & brevis, extensor indicis, ECU

Sensory Supply

None (purely motor)

Clinical Features

Weak finger extension, wrist extension intact (via ECRL)

Common Causes

Radial tunnel syndrome, trauma, compression at the arcade of Frohse

 

Loss of extension of wrist (Option B): Incorrect because wrist extension is not completely lost, as the extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL) (innervated by the radial nerve before the PIN) is still functional.

Loss of supination (Option C): Incorrect because supination is mainly performed by the biceps brachii, with some contribution from the supinator (which is innervated by the PIN but has redundant function from the biceps).

Wrist drop (Option D): Incorrect because wrist drop occurs in a proximal radial nerve injury, affecting all extensors, while PIN lesions primarily affect finger extension with wrist extension relatively spared.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy underwent splenectomy for immune thrombocytopenic purpura. During the procedure, the surgeon noticed bleeding while separating the spleen from the stomach. Which vessel is most likely implicated in this bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Short gastric vessels

 

Explanation:

  • The short gastric vessels arise from the splenic artery and drain into the splenic vein.
  • These vessels run within the gastrosplenic ligament, connecting the fundus of the stomach to the spleen.
  • During splenectomy, when the spleen is being separated from the stomach, these vessels must be ligated to prevent bleeding.
  • Since the short gastric arteries lack a collateral blood supply, their injury can lead to fundal ischemia.

Blood Supply of the Stomach and Its Surgical Relevance

Arterial Supply

Origin

Left gastric artery

Branch of the celiac trunk, supplies the lesser curvature

Right gastric artery

Branch of the proper hepatic artery, supplies the lesser curvature

Short gastric arteries

Branches of the splenic artery, supply the fundus

Right gastroepiploic artery

Branch of the gastroduodenal artery, supplies the greater curvature

Left gastroepiploic artery

Branch of the splenic artery, supplies the greater curvature

Left gastric vessels (Option A): Incorrect because these supply the lesser curvature of the stomach and are not directly involved in splenic separation.

Gastroepiploic vessels (Option C): Incorrect because these supply the greater curvature and are located in the gastrocolic ligament, away from the spleen.

Splenic vessels (Option D): Incorrect because these are major vessels supplying the spleen itself, but they do not cause significant bleeding when separating the spleen from the stomach.

questions.text: During walking, the hip bone on the side of the suspended leg is raised by the action of which muscle present in the supporting leg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gluteus medius

 

Explanation:

  • The gluteus medius is the primary muscle responsible for hip abduction and stabilization of the pelvis during walking.
  • During the stance phase, when one leg is on the ground and the other is lifted, the gluteus medius of the supporting leg contracts to prevent pelvic drop on the opposite side.
  • This mechanism is known as the Trendelenburg mechanism, and dysfunction leads to a Trendelenburg gait.

Gluteus Medius and Hip Stability

Feature

Description

Origin

Ilium (between anterior and posterior gluteal lines)

Insertion

Greater trochanter of femur

Innervation

Superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1)

Function

Hip abduction, pelvic stabilization during gait

Clinical Relevance

Weakness leads to Trendelenburg sign/gait, seen in superior gluteal nerve injury

 

Action of the Hip joint, corresponding muscles and their innervation:

 

Action

Muscles

Nerve supply


 

Flexion
  • Psoas major (chief flexor)

Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3
  • Iliacus (chief flexor)
  • Sartorius
  • Rectus femoris
  • Pectineus

Femoral nerve (L2, L3)
 

Extension
  • Gluteus maximus (chief extensor)

Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Hamstring muscles

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)
 

Abduction
  • Gluteus medius and minimus (chief abductors)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)


 

Adduction
  • Adductor longus
  • Adductor brevis
  • Adductor magnus (chief adductors)
  • Gracilis

Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Pectineus

Double nerve supply (Femoral nerve and obturator nerve)
 

Medial rotation
  • Anterior fibres of gluteus minimus and medius (chief medial rotators)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)





 

Lateral rotation
  • Piriformis

Ventral rami of S1, S2
  • Obturator externus

Posterior division of obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Obturator internus and
  • Associated gemelli,
  • Quadratus femoris (These muscles are generally termed short rotators)

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

 

Gluteus maximus (Option B): Incorrect because it primarily functions in hip extension (e.g., rising from a seated position) rather than stabilizing the pelvis.

Obturator internus (Option C): Incorrect because it mainly functions as a lateral rotator of the hip, not in pelvic stabilization.

Quadratus femoris (Option D): Incorrect because it is a lateral rotator of the hip, not involved in abduction or pelvic stability.

questions.text:
Match the following amino acid with derivatives:

 


	
		
			
			1. Histidine
			
			
			a.Catecholamines
			
		
		
			
			2. Tyrosine
			
			
			b. Histamine
			
		
		
			
			3. Tryptophan
			
			
			c. Glutathione
			
		
		
			
			4. Cysteine
			
			
			d. Melatonin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Explanation:

Amino Acid

Derivative

Function/Importance

Glutamine

Glutamate

Neurotransmitter

Tyrosine

Dopamine

Neurotransmitter

Norepinephrine

Neurotransmitter

Epinephrine (Adrenaline)

Hormone

Tryptophan

Serotonin

Neurotransmitter

Melatonin

Hormone

Phenylalanine

Tyrosine

Precursor to dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.

Histidine

Histamine

Involved in immune response, regulates gastric acid secretion, and neurotransmission.

Glutamic Acid

GABA (Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid)

Inhibitory neurotransmitter

Arginine

Nitric Oxide

Signaling molecule, involved in vasodilation, immune response, and neurotransmission.

Cysteine

Glutathione

Methionine

S-Adenosylmethionine (SAM)

Methyl donor, involved in methylation reactions, DNA synthesis, and regulation of gene expression.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used in diagnosing aneuploidy?

1. FISH

2. Cytogenetics

3. Sangers

4. PCR
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

All of these methods can be used to detect aneuploidy

FISH

Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization: uses fluorescent probes to bind specific DNA regions.

Cytogenetics (Karyotyping)

Visual examination of chromosomes under a microscope.

Sanger Sequencing

Sequencing of DNA to detect mutations at the nucleotide level.

PCR

Amplification of DNA regions; includes variants like qPCR and MLPA.

questions.text:
Enzymes used in recombinant DNA technology are:

1. Isomerase

2. Phosphatase

3. Terminal transferase.

4. CRISPR CASS
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2,3,4

 

Explanation:

Phosphatase, terminal transferase, and CRISPR CASS are used in rDNA technology

 

Phosphatase

Removes phosphate groups from the 5' ends of DNA to prevent self-ligation of vectors during cloning.

Terminal Transferase

Adds nucleotides to the 3' ends of DNA molecules, enabling the creation of sticky or blunt ends for cloning.

CRISPR-CASS

Precisely cuts DNA at specific sequences using a guide RNA, enabling targeted genome editing and manipulation.

 

Steps of recombinant DNA Technology

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't inhibit Cytochrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nitric oxide

 

Explanation:

Electron transport chain Complex IV contains cytochrome a and cytochrome a3

Inhibitors:

  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide
  • Azide
  • Hydrogen sulfide

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with high VLDL due to the combination of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) High HSL, low LPL

 

Explanation:

  • HSL (Hormone-Sensitive Lipase): This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of stored triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol.
  • In a diabetic patient, increased levels of HSL can contribute to higher levels of free fatty acids, which can promote VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein) synthesis in the liver.
  • LPL (Lipoprotein Lipase): LPL is responsible for the hydrolysis of triglycerides in VLDL and chylomicrons, converting them into free fatty acids and glycerol.
  • A low level of LPL activity would impair the clearance of VLDL from the bloodstream, leading to high VLDL levels.
  • In diabetes, high HSL activity and low LPL activity both contribute to increased levels of VLDL.
  • High HSL promotes the production of triglycerides in the liver, while low LPL reduces the breakdown of these triglycerides in the bloodstream, resulting in elevated VLDL levels.

questions.text: Which amino acid donates nitrogen to sodium benzoate when given for urea cycle disorders?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glycine

 

Explanation:

Sodium benzoate:

  • It reacts with glycine in the liver to form hippuric acid, which is then excreted in the urine, reducing the availability of glycine.
  • Reducing the availability of glycine shifts the equilibrium to favour glycine formation.
  • Ammonia is used to produce glycine, therefore reducing blood ammonia levels.

questions.text: Deficiency of copper which is necessary for lysyl oxidase is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Menke's disease

 

Explanation:

Menke’s disease:

Genetic Basis

X-linked defect (affects only male children)

Cause

Mutation in the ATP7A gene (absence of intracellular copper binding ATPase)

Presentation
  • Dietary copper is absorbed from the GI tract but cannot be transported to blood
  • Copper cannot be mobilized from intestinal and other tissue cells
  • Copper accumulates within cells due to the inability to export it
  • Defective cross-linking of connective tissue, affecting vascular and connective tissues
  • Typically fatal in infancy due to severe connective tissue and vascular defects

questions.text: Which of the following drugs binds to CD4 and has both CXCR4 & CCR5 activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ibalizumab

 

Explanation:

  • Ibalizumab (monoclonal antibody) is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to the CD4 receptor and blocks HIV's interaction with both CCR5 and CXCR4 co-receptors, preventing viral entry into T cells.

 

Maraviroc (Option A) is a CCR5 antagonist that specifically binds to the CCR5 co-receptor on the surface of T cells.

  • Blocking CCR5 prevents the HIV virus from being used as a co-receptor for entry into the host cell.

 

Dolutegravir (Option C) is an integrase inhibitor.

  • It prevents the integration of the viral DNA into the host cell genome by inhibiting the HIV integrase enzyme.
  • This step occurs after the virus has entered the host cell.

 

Tenofovir (Option D) is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI).

  • It inhibits the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is crucial for converting viral RNA into DNA during the early stages of the HIV replication cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes modulation of voltage-gated sodium channels by selectively enhancing slow inactivation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lacosamide

 

Explanation:

Lacosamide selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, inhibiting high-frequency neuronal firing and reducing seizure activity.

 

Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels:

  • Voltage-gated sodium channels play a key role in generating and propagating action potentials in neurons.
  • These channels open in response to membrane depolarization, allowing Na⁺ to flow into the cell, leading to further depolarization.
  • Fast Inactivation Modulators:
    • Phenytoin (Option B)
    • Carbamazepine
  • Slow Inactivation Modulators:
    • Lacosamide

 

Lamotrigine (Option C) primarily affects sodium channels by inhibiting their ability to recover from both fast and slow inactivation.

  • It is not as selective for enhancing slow inactivation, and while it reduces high-frequency firing, its primary action is broader, affecting both types of inactivation.

 

Ethosuximide (Option D) does not act on sodium channels.

  • It primarily targets T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which are involved in the generation of absence seizures.
  • It does not directly modulate sodium channel inactivation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of breast cancer is a PARP inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rucaparib

 

Explanation:

Rucaparib is a PARP (Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase) inhibitor used in the treatment of certain types of breast cancer, particularly those with BRCA mutations.

 

Rucaparib:

  • It is an oral PARP1–3 inhibitor approved in 2016 for advanced ovarian cancer with BRCA mutations, used in maintenance after platinum-based chemotherapy.
  • It is also indicated for BRCA-mutated metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer after endocrine and taxane therapy.
  • It shares safety concerns with olaparib, including risks of MDS and AML.
  • It is primarily metabolized by CYP2D6 and affects the metabolism of drugs like warfarin.
  • The mean half-life is 25.9 hours.

 

PARP inhibitors work by blocking the repair of DNA damage, leading to the death of cancer cells.

  • Olaparib
  • Rucaparib
  • Niraparib
  • Talazoparib

 

Palbociclib (Option B) is a CDK4/6 inhibitor used in the treatment of HR-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer.

  • It does not inhibit PARP and is not used as a PARP inhibitor.

 

Vemurafenib (Option C) is a BRAF inhibitor, specifically targeting BRAF V600E mutations in cancers like melanoma.

  • It does not affect PARP or its associated pathways.

 

Gemcitabine (Option D) is a chemotherapy agent that inhibits DNA synthesis by interfering with nucleotides.

  • It is not a PARP inhibitor and is used to treat various cancers like pancreatic cancer and non-small cell lung cancer.

questions.text:
A patient who has recently had a myocardial infarction (MI) presents for a follow-up. His cholesterol levels are as follows: total cholesterol 238 mg/dL, triglycerides 125 mg/dL, and HDL 50 mg/dL. He is currently taking atorvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin. Which of the following medications should be added to his regimen?


	Ezetimibe
	Bempedoic acid
	Evolocumab
	Gemfibrozil
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1,2,3

 

Explanation:

Gemfibrozil is mainly used to treat high triglycerides (Severe Hypertriglyceridemia) and low HDL cholesterol, but it is not the first-line agent for LDL cholesterol reduction in post-MI patients & also the patient has normal triglyceride levels.

 

Ezetimibe (1): Inhibits cholesterol absorption in the small intestine, reducing total cholesterol and LDL levels.

 

Bempedoic acid (2): Inhibits ATP-citrate lyase, which reduces cholesterol synthesis in the liver, leading to lower LDL levels.

 

Evolocumab (3): A PCSK9 inhibitor that binds to PCSK9, preventing it from degrading LDL receptors, thereby increasing the liver’s ability to clear LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Maximum oral dose of fosphenytoin causes cerebellar degeneration and brain atrophy.
High doses of fosphenytoin cause cardiotoxicity in elderly patients and nephrotoxicity in young patients
The safe dose of phenytoin is 250 mg/kg.
Fosphenytoin is given to all seizure patients in the ER regardless of CNS side effects and hypertension.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High doses of fosphenytoin cause cardiotoxicity in elderly patients and nephrotoxicity in young patients.

 

Explanation:

  • Fosphenytoin is a water-soluble prodrug of phenytoin used to treat seizures.
  • It is converted to active phenytoin in the body.
  • Fosphenytoin is typically administered intravenously (IV) or intramuscularly (IM) and is preferred over phenytoin in emergency settings due to its better solubility, allowing for faster administration.
  • Toxicity:
    • Symptoms of Acute Overdose:
      • Nystagmus can appear at doses as low as 20 µg/mL.
      • Lethargy and dysarthria manifest at 40 µg/mL.
      • Lethal dose is 2-5 grams in adults.
    • Fosphenytoin carries a black box warning due to its conversion to phenytoin.
    • Exceeding 150 mg of phenytoin equivalents per minute can lead to severe cardiac outcomes, including hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias.
    • Excessive IV infusion (>150 mg phenytoin equivalents per minute) can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, hypotension, and CNS depression.
    • Overdose symptoms include nystagmus, ataxia, and dysarthria. In severe cases, lethargy and coma may occur.
    • Formate and phosphate metabolites can cause metabolic acidosis and hypocalcemia in cases of overdose.
    • Nephrotoxicity in young patients, though rare, may occur due to its systemic effects and renal clearance.

questions.text: What is the half-life of digoxin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 36 hours

 

Explanation:

  • The half-life of digoxin is approximately 36 hours.
  • This means that it takes about 36 hours for the plasma concentration of digoxin to reduce by half in the body.
  • Since digoxin is primarily eliminated by the kidneys (about 80%), the half-life can be prolonged in patients with impaired renal function.

 

Digoxin:

  • Inotropic Action: Increases intracellular Ca²⁺, improving heart failure and causing arrhythmias in overdose.
  • Utility: Controls ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation (AF) and terminates reentrant arrhythmias, especially in heart failure patients.
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Toxicity: Common due to low therapeutic index. Symptoms include nausea, cognitive disturbances, blurred/yellow vision, and arrhythmias.
    • Arrhythmias: Includes atrial tachycardia with AV block, ventricular bigeminy, bidirectional VT, and AV block.
    • Severe Toxicity: Hyperkalemia, bradyarrhythmias, and potential unresponsiveness to pacing therapy.
  • Half-Life: 36 hours, with renal elimination as the primary route (80%).
  • Drug Interactions: Drugs like amiodarone, quinidine, and diuretics increase the risk of toxicity by altering digoxin clearance or causing electrolyte imbalances.

questions.text: Pretomanid is used in the treatment of which condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MDR TB

 

Explanation:

  • Pretomanid is an antibiotic primarily used in the treatment of multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).
  • It is part of a combination therapy for drug-resistant TB, often used alongside other medications like bedaquiline and linezolid.
  • Pretomanid works by inhibiting the bacterial cell wall and DNA processes, making it effective against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.


 

 

Mechanism of action

Side effects

Delamanid

Inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acid by nitric oxide production, an essential component of the cell wall of M.tuberculosis
  • Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, headache, and elevated liver enzymes.
  • QT prolongation, which can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias
  • Monitoring of liver function and ECG is recommended during treatment

Pretomanid

Inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid by disrupting the synthesis of fatty acids in the cell wall of M.tuberculosis
  • Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Acne


 

Second-line ATT drugs

Group A

Group B

Group C
  • Bedaquilin
  • Levofloxacin or Moxifloxacin
  • Linezolid
  • Cycloserine
  • Clofazimine
  • Delamanid
  • Amikacin
  • Meropenem or Imipenem-cilastatin
  • PAS
  • Ethionamide
  • Ethambutol
  • Pyrazinamide
