questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a serum calcium level of 12.8 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5–10.25 mg/dL) along with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. Ultrasound imaging reveals a 1.5 x 1.5 cm mass in the right lower lobe of the thyroid gland. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: MIBI followed by focussed parathyroidectomy to be done
Normal DEXA scan rules out the need for surgery
Only observation, no need for surgery
Creatinine clearance > 80 ml/min mandates the surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MIBI followed by focussed parathyroidectomy to be done

Explanation:

  • MIBI scan followed by focused parathyroidectomy is the recommended course of action for this patient.
  • This scenario suggests primary hyperparathyroidism, likely due to a parathyroid adenoma, given the elevated calcium and PTH levels, along with the thyroid mass that could be related to a parathyroid lesion.
  • Sestamibi scan is a type of nuclear medicine-based study that is most accurate for parathyroid lesion localisation.
  • Indications of parathyroidectomy include: (Option C ruled out)
    • Severe symptoms
    • Young age
    • Markedly reduced bone density
    • Serum calcium more than 11mg%
    • Urinary calculi
    • Neuromuscular symptoms
    • Urinary calcium more than 400mg/24 hour

Normal DEXA scan rules out the need for surgery (Option B) is not true because even if bone density is normal, elevated calcium and PTH levels indicate that the parathyroid adenoma should be addressed surgically.

Creatinine clearance > 80 ml/min mandates the surgery (Option D): Surgical intervention is primarily indicated based on the diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism and the presence of complications or symptoms, not just creatinine clearance.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and prior radiation therapy presents with a right-sided thyroid swelling. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) confirms papillary carcinoma with no evidence of lymph node involvement. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Hemi-thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Total thyroidectomy

Explanation:

  • The next step in the management of papillary thyroid carcinoma, especially in a patient with a history of radiation exposure, is Total thyroidectomy.
  • If lymph node enlargement or metastasis is present, then total thyroidectomy, along with the removal of an enlarged group of lymph nodes with or without ipsilateral modified radical neck dissection (MRND), is done. (Option C ruled out)
  • Hemithyroidectomy involves the removal of one lobe of the thyroid gland and isthmus; it would not be sufficient in this scenario due to the higher risk of multifocal disease and recurrence. (Options A & D ruled out)
  • A total thyroidectomy ensures that there is no residual thyroid tissue, making these post-surgical follow-up strategies more reliable.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of MEN2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Parathyroid hyperplasia

Explanation:

  • Parathyroid hyperplasia is associated with MEN2A, not MEN2B.
  • MEN is a group of genetic syndromes (Autosomal Dominant) characterised by the development of tumours in multiple endocrine glands.
  • Diagnostic criteria for MEN is
  • Clinical features of 2 or more associated tumours.
  • Notable Family history
  • Confirmation by genetic analysis.
  • MEN2B is also called as MEN type 3.

 

Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia
 

MEN Type I

MEN Type II

MEN Type III

MEN Type IV

Cause
  • Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation
  • Also called Wermer’s syndrome
  • Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene
  • Also called Sipple’s syndrome

Also called MEN II B, it is a variant of Type 2 MEN

Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene

Tumors

Included

Parathyroid adenoma

(most common)

  • It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism (↑ PTH and ↑ Ca)
  • All the four glands can be included.
  • Rx: Total/subtotal parathyroid resection

Parathyroid adenoma (most common, and calcium can be normal)

Medullary carcinoma thyroid (most common)

(Option A ruled out)

Parathyroid adenoma (Presents as hypercalcemia)

Pancreatic adenoma

  • Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
  • This leads to peptic ulcer disease in the duodenum, which is the leading cause of death in this type.

Pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure.

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

  • Calcitonin is the tumor marker present
  • Cold nodules are seen on the thyroid scan
  • Metastasis can be traced with PET scan
  • Visible neck mass, causing dysphagia
  • Rx- Prophylactic thyroidectomy

Reproductive tract tumors

  • Testicular tumours
  • Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix)

Associated conditions
  • Angioﬁbroma
  • Collagenoma
  • Adrenocortical tumor
  • Carcinoid tumors/Argentaﬃnoma
  • Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%)
  • Congenital aganglionosis,
  • Hirschsprung disease
  • Marfanoid habitus (Option C ruled out)
  • Medullated corneal nerve ﬁbers
  • Mucosal neuromas (Option B ruled out)
  • Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae

Occasionally with

  • Renal tumour
  • Adrenal tumour

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with occasional palpitations, high blood pressure, and headache. He is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma. What is the preferred initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 24 hours urine metanephrines

 

Explanation:
The preferred initial investigation in a patient suspected of having pheochromocytoma is a 24-hour urine collection for metanephrines, as it is a sensitive and specific test for detecting catecholamine-secreting tumours.

Pheochromocytoma

Definition
  • A catecholamine-secreting tumour that arises from the chromaffin cells of the abdominal sympathetic chain/ adrenal medulla
  • Co-exist with neurofibromatosis, VHL syndrome, MEN syndrome

Clinical features
  • Classical triad: Headache (most common), profuse sweating, palpitation and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent)
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia and Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor (due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction)
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight Loss

The rule of 10
  • 10% are bilateral
  • 10% are extra-adrenal
  • 10% are malignant
  • 25-33% are inherited
  • Symptomatic patients do not follow the Rule of 10’s

Diagnosis
  • Measurement of the plasma fractionated metanephrines is the most sensitive screening test; hence, the initial investigation is preferred.
  • Increase 24 hour urinary VMA(Vanillyl mandelic acid) and metanephrines (Option D)
  • MRI is the investigation of choice. (Option B ruled out)
  • Biopsy and CT contrast scans are contraindicated in order to avoid hypertensive crises

Treatment
  • Adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice
  • Size<5cm- Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha-blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment


USG-abdomen (Option A) may sometimes be used to assess abdominal masses, it is not the preferred initial investigation for pheochromocytoma, as it may not detect smaller tumours or those located in less accessible areas, such as the adrenal glands or retroperitoneal space.

 

MIBG (Option C) is specialised imaging studies used for further evaluation, especially in metastatic or multifocal cases, and are not used for initial biochemical confirmation after plasma testing.

questions.text: Which is the most lethal nerve injury during thyroid surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) B/L RLN (complete)

Explanation:

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is a crucial structure in thyroid surgery because it innervates the laryngeal muscles, which control vocal cord function.
  • Bilateral complete injury to the RLN is the most lethal nerve injury during thyroid surgery as it can cause paralysis of both vocal cords, leading to stridor, voice changes, breathing difficulties, and, in severe cases, airway obstruction.
  • Unilateral injury is generally less dangerous than bilateral injury because the contralateral vocal cord can compensate to a significant degree. (Options A & C ruled out)
  • The individual may experience hoarseness or aspiration of fluids through the glottis.
  • Partial injury typically does not lead to significant airway compromise. (Option B ruled out)

Reference:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with a history of a road traffic accident presents to the emergency department. His GCS is 8/15, oxygen saturation is 85%, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg and heart rate is 60 beats per minute. On examination, breath sounds are absent on the right side. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Start IV fluids, give atropine and secure airway
Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, secure IV line
Evaluate for head injury and do CT-head
﻿﻿﻿Administer IV dextrose followed by NCCT head

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, secure IV line

Explanation:

  • The patient has GCS 8/15, indicating a severe head injury and possible impaired consciousness. Therefore, securing the airway is the priority to prevent further deterioration.
  • Oxygen should be administered to address the low oxygen saturation (85%).
  • The absence of breath sounds on the right side raises concern for tension pneumothorax or large pneumothorax, which can lead to respiratory failure.
  • In this case, the next step is to insert an intercostal chest drain (ICD) to relieve any pneumothorax and re-expand the lung.
  • IV access should be secured for fluid resuscitation or medication administration, but airway and breathing take precedence.
  • We will follow a primary survey of A, B, C, D, and E to manage this patient, where A is securing the airway, B is giving oxygen and inserting ICD, and C includes IV line.
     

Start IV fluids, give atropine and secure airway (Option A):

  • Securing the airway is important, but giving atropine is not the priority here because the patient has a heart rate of 60 bpm, which is not significantly low and does not require atropine at this stage.

 

Evaluate for head injury and do CT-head (Option C):

  • The immediate concern is the airway and respiratory distress.
  • The absence of breath sounds on the right side suggests a life-threatening thoracic injury that should be managed first, with a CT scan of the head being considered later once the patient is stabilised.

 

Administer IV dextrose followed by NCCT head (Option D):

  • There is no indication that the patient is hypoglycemic or in need of IV dextrose at this moment.
  • The priority should be stabilising the airway and managing the potential pneumothorax.
  • The NCCT head can be done later if head injury is suspected after stabilizing the patient.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with flank pain and dysuria. The pain was temporarily relieved by intravenous analgesics administered at a nearby primary healthcare center. She is diagnosed with ureteric colic secondary to ureteric calculi. What is the most appropriate diagnostic modality in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) NCCT KUB

Explanation:

  • Non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) is considered the gold standard for diagnosing renal stones.
  • NCCT scans provide detailed images of the urinary tract and can identify both radiopaque (visible on X-rays) and radiolucent (not easily visible on X-rays) stones.

Investigations for renal stones:

Urinalysis
  • This is often the initial investigation performed. It can reveal the presence of blood (hematuria), white blood cells (pyuria), and crystals in the urine, all suggestive of a possible stone.
  • The pH of the urine can also give clues about the type of stone.

Kidney, Ureter, and Bladder (KUB) X-ray

It can detect some types of stones, particularly calcium-containing stones, which appear opaque on X-rays.

Ultrasound

(Option C ruled out)

It's particularly useful for detecting hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidney due to urine blockage) caused by stones and can be helpful during pregnancy when minimising radiation exposure is important.

Intravenous urogram (IVU)
  • It involves injecting a contrast dye into a vein.
  • The dye travels through the bloodstream to the kidneys, where it is filtered and excreted in the urine.
  • X-rays are taken as the dye passes through the urinary tract, outlining the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.
  • This test can reveal blockages in the urinary tract caused by stones.


СЕСТ (Option B) is usually not the first choice for stone detection because contrast can obscure small stones.

  • It should be avoided in suspected acute renal colic cases unless there are other indications.

 

Ureteroscopy (Option D) is invasive and typically performed as a therapeutic procedure to remove stones, not as a diagnostic tool.

  • It is used when stone extraction or biopsy is required but not for routine diagnosis.

questions.text: Identify the structure on prostate biopsy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Corpora amylacea

Explanation:

  • The laminated, round, basophilic bodies that can be seen in the prostate biopsy are Corpora amylacea.
  • They are composed of proteinaceous material often found in the prostatic acini and ducts.
  • They are believed to be precursors of prostatic calculi and are also commonly seen in BPH.


Psammoma bodies (Option A) are concentric, calcified structures commonly seen in certain tumours, like papillary thyroid carcinoma, serous ovarian carcinoma, or meningiomas.

  • They are not typically associated with prostate tissue or prostate biopsies.

Corpora arenacea (Option B), or brain sand, are calcified deposits in the pineal gland composed of calcium salts.

  • They are a common and typically benign finding in the brain, particularly in older individuals.

 

﻿﻿﻿Amyloid (Option D) deposits are abnormal proteins that can accumulate in tissues in various diseases, such as amyloidosis.

  • While it can sometimes be seen in prostate tissue in rare conditions, it is not a common finding on prostate biopsy and is not associated with the structure described in this case.

questions.text: During ward rounds, you encounter a patient who has been admitted with esophageal carcinoma. What is the most likely presentation for this patient?

choices.text: Dysphagia of liquids followed by solids
Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids

Explanation:

Esophageal carcinoma typically presents with dysphagia, initially to solids and later to liquids, as the tumour obstructs and narrows the esophagus.

 

Carcinoma Esophagus

Types
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
  • Adenocarcinoma

Risk Factors
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Smoking, Alcohol, Hot beverages, N-nitroso foods,
  • Adenocarcinoma: Obesity, Gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett's esophagus

Clinical Features
  • Progressive dysphagia (initially for solids followed by liquids), Anorexia, Weight loss, Odynophagia, and Regurgitation.
  • Advanced symptoms: Hoarseness, Aspiration, Choking, etc.

Investigation
  • Endoscopy: Tumor visualisation, Biopsies, Chromoendoscopy, NBI
  • Barium contrast study: Tumor as ulcerated/stenotic lesion
  • Bronchoscopy: Check airway spread
  • Endoscopic & Percutaneous Ultrasonography:
    • EUS for staging tumour (T stage) and para esophageal nodes Percutaneous ultrasound of cervical nodes with FNA
  • CT scan: Distant node assessment
  • FDG-PET scan: Detects nodes/metastases, not for tumour staging

 

Dysphagia of liquids followed by solids (Option A) is more typical of conditions like achalasia cardia, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing.

Chest pain (Option C) can occur in esophageal carcinoma; it is less common as an initial presentation compared to dysphagia.

  • Chest pain in esophageal cancer usually occurs in advanced stages or if there is tumour invasion into nearby structures.

 

Neck mass (Option D) can occur if the cancer metastasises to the lymph nodes in the neck (e.g., Virchow's node), but this is not the most common initial presentation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with peptic ulcer disease presents with persistent abdominal pain despite treatment at multiple hospitals. He has ulcers in the jejunum and ileum. His gastric pH is <2, and after discontinuing PPIs, his gastrin levels are 10 times higher than normal. What is the likely lesion, and what are the boundaries of the triangle containing it?

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Insulinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas
Gastrinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas
Gastrinoma; triangle formed by only common bile duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gastrinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas

Explanation:

  • This patient’s clinical presentation of persistent peptic ulcers, especially in the jejunal and ileal regions, combined with elevated gastrin levels (even after stopping PPIs) and a gastric pH <2, is highly suggestive of a gastrinoma.
  • Gastrinomas are tumours that secrete excess gastrin, commonly leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which causes multiple peptic ulcers due to high gastric acid production.
  • The gastrinoma triangle refers to a specific anatomical region in the pancreas where gastrinomas are most commonly located. (Pissaros triangle) this triangle is bordered by:
    • Junction between cystic duct and CBD (option D ruled out)
    • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum (D2-D3 junction)
    • Junction between the head and neck of the pancreas


 


Insulinoma; triangle formed (Option A):

  • Insulinomas are pancreatic tumours that secrete insulin, not gastrin.
  • They cause hypoglycemia rather than peptic ulcers, so this option doesn’t fit with the patient’s symptoms or diagnostic findings. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: An elderly male presents with foul-smelling breath and dysphagia. A barium swallow X-ray is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Zenker's diverticulum

Explanation:

  • The given barium swallow film shows a characteristic radiological finding known as a Pharyngeal pouch or Zenker's diverticulum, and the given symptoms also align with this diagnosis.
  • It is an outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa through a weak area in the posterior pharyngeal wall (Killian's dehiscence), which can trap food and cause bad breath.
     

Zenker's diverticulum

Clinical features:
  • Dysphagia is the most prominent feature appears when the pouch gets filled with food and presses on the oesophagus.
  • Gurgling sound is produced on swallowing.
  • Regurgitation at night from undigested food causes cough and aspiration pneumonia.
  • Halitosis (Chronic bad breathing)
  • Malnourished due to dysphagia.
  • Associated hiatus hernia
  • Rarely can a coma develop in long-standing cases of pharyngeal pouches.

Diagnosis:
  • Barium swallow provides information regarding the size, location, and character of the mucosal lining.

 

 

 
  • Endoscopy reveals fibrosis and pooling of food in the diverticulum.

Treatment:
  • Excision of the pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy was done through a cervical approach.
  • Dohlman’s procedure: The partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by diathermy through a weerda scope.
  • Endoscopic laser treatment: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by CO2 laser using an endoscope. This procedure is known to have fewer recurrences and faster improvement in symptoms.

 

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option A) usually presents with cough, vomiting, difficulty in breathing, regurgitation and cyanosis.

  • It is often seen in newborns or in patients with a history of oesophagal surgery or cancer.

Achalasia cardia (Option B) is a disorder where the lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax properly, leading to dysphagia and regurgitation.

  • Barium swallow shows dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance/ Pencil tip appearance/ Rat tail appearance).

Carcinoma esophagus (Option C) presents with narrowing or strictures in the esophagus due to tumour growth.

  • Whereas a pharyngeal pouch (Zenker's diverticulum) is a protrusion from the pharynx

questions.text: An intern assists in laparoscopic surgery, and the resident explains the instruments and operating ports. The surgeon then asks, "What is the angle between the camera port and the working port called?"
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Azimuth's angle

Explanation:

  • Azimuth's angle is the correct term for describing the angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery.
  • The ideal azimuth angle is between 30 - 45° for maximum productivity.

Angles of laparoscopy

Azimuth angle

It is the angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery; the ideal azimuth angle is between 30 - 45° to avoid clashing of the instruments.

Manipulation angle

It is the angle between two working ports, and the ideal angle for this is 60°.

Elevation angle

This term is more related to the vertical positioning of instruments or the camera in relation to the surgical field, not the angle between ports; the ideal angle for this is also 60°.

 

Crossing angle (Option C) is not a term specifically used to describe the angle between the camera port and the working port.

questions.text: What is the Truelove and Witts classification used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ﻿﻿﻿Acute severe ulcerative colitis

Explanation:

The Truelove and Witts classification is specifically used to assess the severity of ulcerative colitis (UC).

Truelove and Witts classification for Ulcerative Colitis

Severity

Stool Frequency

Systemic Symptoms and signs

Mild

<4 stools/day

No systemic signs of toxicity

Moderate

>4 stools/day

Fever, abdominal pain, Elevated ESR, CRP

Severe

>6 stools/day

Fever, tachycardia, anaemia, systemic illness, hypoalbuminemia, Elevated ESR, CRP

Fulminant

>10 stools/day

Continuous bleeding, fever, tachycardia, abdominal tenderness & distension, “Toxic megacolon” (progressive colonic dilation, an indication for emergency surgery) in severe cases


ARDS (Option B) is acute respiratory distress syndrome involving the lungs, and the Truelove and Witts classification is not used for this.

 

Acute encephalitis (Option C) is an inflammation of the brain, typically caused by infection, and the Truelove and Witts classification has no role here.

 

Acute pancreatitis (Option D) is an inflammation of the pancreas, and it is not evaluated using the Truelove and Witts classification.

questions.text:
Match the following diseases with their respective gene mutation:

 


	
		
			
			A. Familial adenomatous polyposis
			
			
			i. SMAD4
			
		
		
			
			B. Juvenile polyposis
			
			
			ii. STK11
			
		
		
			
			C. Tuberous sclerosis
			
			
			iii. APC gene
			
		
		
			
			D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
			
			
			iv. TSC1
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A-iii, B-i, C-iv, D-ii

Explanation:

A. Familial adenomatous polyposis

iii. APC gene

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by APC gene mutations on chromosome 5.
  • It is characterised by numerous intestinal polyps, which, if left untreated, have a high risk of developing colorectal cancer

B. Juvenile polyposis

i. SMAD4

  • It is also an autosomal dominant disorder that commonly affects children under 5 years of age,
  • It is characterised by pedunculated polyps, usually less than 3 cm in diameter.
  • It is linked to mutations in the SMAD4 and BMPR1A genes, part of the TGF-β signalling pathway.

C. Tuberous sclerosis

iv. TSC1

  • It is a neurocutaneous disorder resulting from mutations in the TSC1 (hamartin) or TSC2 (tuberin) genes.
  • Patients exhibit neurological symptoms like seizures, along with skin abnormalities.
  • The syndrome also includes hamartomatous polyps in the intestine.

D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

ii. STK11

  • It is also an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the STK11 gene.
  • It presents around 11 years of age and is characterised by
    • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine
    • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, and extremities).

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with acute epigastric pain and fever. He has a history of cholelithiasis. On examination, abdominal guarding and rigidity are noted. Laboratory results show elevated serum amylase and lipase levels, along with leukocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis for his condition?

choices.text: Serum amylase remains elevated even after 30 days of resolution of acute pancreatitis
﻿﻿﻿> 75 per cent of patients present with hypercalcemia
Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase
Increase in the level of serum lipase is directly proportional to the severity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis here is acute pancreatitis, given the acute epigastric pain, fever, history of cholelithiasis, abdominal guarding, rigidity, & elevated serum amylase and lipase levels along with leukocytosis.
  • Serum lipase is indeed more specific than amylase for diagnosing acute pancreatitis.
  • While both enzymes are elevated in pancreatitis, lipase tends to remain elevated longer and is more directly associated with pancreatic damage. (Option A ruled out)
  • Serum amylase levels can also be elevated in other acute abdominal conditions such as perforation, volvulus, and torsion.
  • If amylase remains elevated for more than a few weeks, it could indicate a chronic condition or other non-pancreatic diseases.

> 75 per cent of patients present with hypercalcemia (Option B):

  • Hypercalcemia is not a common feature of acute pancreatitis.
  • In fact, hypocalcemia is more commonly observed in acute pancreatitis, which happens due to the precipitation of calcium salts in the pancreatic tissue because of the saponification of fat.

Increase in the level of serum lipase is directly proportional to the severity (Option D):

  • Lipase and amylase do not directly correlate with the severity of the disease, and none of the commonly used scoring systems for grading pancreatitis directly rely on the values of amylase or lipase to assess the severity of the condition.

questions.text: An 84-year-old man who had a stroke 2 years ago and has been on extended bed rest, develops a pressure ulcer with partial skin thickness loss and a clean base. What is the grade of his pressure sore?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2

Explanation:
The pressure ulcer described in the scenario has partial skin thickness loss with a clean base, characteristic of a Grade 2 pressure sore.

Pressure sore stages

Stage I

(Option A ruled out)

Early superficial ulcer

Non blanchable erythema of the skin, without breach in the epidermis

Stage II

(Option B)

Late superficial ulcer

Partial thickness, less including epidermis + dermis

Stage III

(Option C ruled out)

Early deep ulcer

Full-thickness skin loss involving subcutaneous tissues but not through underlying fascia

Stage IV

(Option D ruled out)

Late deep ulcer

Full-thickness skin loss involving subcutaneous tissue, muscle, bone, joints or tendon.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male had surgery for an ileal perforation. Due to significant contamination, only the sheath was sutured, leaving the wound open. Daily wound irrigation was carried out, and the wound was closed on postoperative day 5. What type of wound-healing mechanism is occurring in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tertiary intention

 

Explanation:
The type of wound healing mechanism described in this scenario is tertiary intention (also known as (delayed primary closure).

Wound healing

Healing by primary intention

(Option A ruled out)

It occurs when the edges of a clean wound are brought together and secured with sutures, staples, or adhesives. Minimal scarring occurs.

Healing by secondary intention

(Option B ruled out)

The wound is left open to heal by granulation, contraction, and epithelialisation. This is common in wounds with significant tissue loss or contamination.

Healing by tertiary intention (delayed primary closure)

(Option C)

The wound is initially left open and then closed surgically after several days when it's clean and granulating. This is used for contaminated wounds to prevent infection.


Quaternary intention (Option D) is not a recognised term in wound healing.

  • The proper classification includes primary, secondary, and tertiary intention.

questions.text: A friend of yours is teaching you about enhanced recovery after surgery. Which of the following statements he makes is inaccurate?

choices.text: Epidural anaesthesia recommended in laparoscopic surgery for pain control
Reduction of hospital stay by 2-3 weeks
Beta-blockers are given after major surgery done under general anaesthesia to improve the outcome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ﻿﻿﻿Prolonged fasting is necessary

Explanation:

  • ERAS protocols emphasise reducing fasting times before surgery.
  • It allows a light meal up to six hours before surgery and clear fluids up to two hours prior.
  • It also includes carbohydrate-rich drinks up to two hours before the procedure as it helps reduce postoperative insulin resistance, preserve muscle mass, minimize protein loss, and alleviate preoperative thirst, hunger, and anxiety.
  • ERAS is a set of evidence-based guidelines aimed at improving recovery after surgery.
  • It focuses on optimising preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative care to speed up recovery, reduce complications, and shorten hospital stays.

Epidural anaesthesia recommended in laparoscopic surgery for pain control (Option B) is true because it is one of the main component of ERAS and it can be used for effective pain control in many types of surgery, including laparoscopic surgery. However, its use may depend on the type of surgery and the patient’s condition.

Reduction of hospital stay by 2-3 weeks (Option C) is correct as one of the key goals of ERAS is to reduce the length of hospital stay.

 

Beta-blockers are given after major surgery done under general anaesthesia to improve outcome (Option D) is true and is mainly given to improve cardiovascular outcome.


Reference:

questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with leg pain after walking 100 meters. On examination, there is an absent pulse in the bilateral dorsalis pedis, anterior tibial, and posterior tibial arteries, but no gangrene is noted. Intermittent claudication is suspected. Which of the following statements about this condition is correct?

choices.text: Pain is more at night and sleep
Pain aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward
Development of pain on the 1st step of walking
Pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest

 

Explanation:

  • Pain develops after walking some distance and relieved by rest is the correct description of intermittent claudication.
  • This is a classic symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD).
  • The pain is typically muscle pain, cramping, or aching, and it most commonly affects the calf muscles because of their large muscle mass and high demand for oxygen during activity.

Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication:

Grade

Description

Grade 0: Asymptomatic

No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise

Grade I: Mild claudication

Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade II: Moderate claudication

Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade III: Severe claudication

Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain

Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion

 

Pain is more at night and sleep (Option A): Night pain is more characteristic of rest pain in advanced PAD, not intermittent claudication.

 

Pain aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward (Option B): This description is more consistent with neurogenic claudication and is typical of lumbar canal stenosis, where pain worsens with standing or walking and is relieved by bending forward or sitting.

 

Development of pain on the 1st step of walking (Option C) is associated with osteoarthritis, whereas the pain in intermittent claudication develops after walking for a certain distance, not immediately when taking the first step.

questions.text: What is the T stage for this tumour in the oral cavity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ﻿﻿﻿T4a

 

Explanation:

The T stage is part of the TNM system to classify tumour extent. The image shows cancer involving both the lip and floor of the mouth, indicating invasion of adjacent structures, which is characteristic of T4a.

 

Staging of Oral Cavity Cancer (AJCC 8th Edition):

T (Primary Tumor):

Tx

Primary tumor cannot be assessed.

Tis

Carcinoma in situ.

T1

Tumor ≤2 cm, ≤5 mm depth of invasion (DOI).

T2

Tumor ≤2 cm, DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm; or tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm, and ≤10 mm DOI. (Option C ruled out)

T3

Tumor >4 cm; or any tumor >10 mm DOI. (Option A ruled out)

T4a

Moderately advanced local disease - Invades through cortical bone, deep/ extrinsic muscle of tongue, maxillary sinus, or skin of the face.

T4b

Very advanced local disease - Invades masticator space, pterygoid plates, skull base, or encases internal carotid artery. (Option D ruled out)

N (Regional Lymph Nodes):

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, ≤3 cm in greatest dimension.

N2
  • N2a: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral node, >3 cm but ≤6 cm in greatest dimension.
  • N2b: Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral nodes, all ≤6 cm).
  • N2c: Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, all ≤6 cm.

N3
  • N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm in greatest dimension, ENE(-).
  • N3b: Metastasis in any node(s) with clinically overt ENE(+).

M (Distant Metastasis):

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Introjection

 

Explanation:

  • Introjection refers to the unconscious adoption of the attitudes or behaviours of others, often discussed in the context of psychodynamic theory, not Beck's cognitive theory.
  • Thus, it is not a component of Beck's theory.

 

Psychosocial Theories of Depression:

 

Cognitive Theory

  • Depression arises from cognitive distortions known as depressogenic schemata.
  • Cognitive Triad (by Aaron Beck):
    • Worthlessness: Negative self-perception.
    • Helplessness: Perception of the environment as hostile and demanding.
    • Hopelessness: Expectation of suffering and failure in the future.
  • Therapy focuses on modifying these cognitive distortions.

 

Life Events and Environmental Stress

  • Stressful life events often precede the first episode of mood disorders.
  • Initial stress may lead to long-lasting biological changes, increasing the risk for future episodes even without further stressors.

 

Psychodynamic Theories

  • Early disturbances in the infant-mother relationship predispose to depression.
  • Depression is linked to real or imagined loss of significant objects.
  • Introjection of lost objects serves as a defense mechanism.
  • Feelings of love and hate toward the lost object result in self-directed anger.

 

Learned Helplessness

  • Developed from studies showing that exposure to uncontrollable stressors (e.g., electric shocks in dogs) leads to passive behaviour.
  • Humans may internalize helplessness and lose self-esteem after adverse events.
  • Improvement in depression involves learning a sense of control and mastery over one’s environment.

 

Evolutionary Theory

  • Depression is viewed as an adaptive response to perceived environmental threats.
  • Withdrawal from social situations and decreased activity may serve as protective mechanisms.

questions.text: What is the appropriate treatment for a patient who frequently experiences a sense of contamination in his hands and compulsively washes them, leading to distress and impaired performance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Exposure and Response Prevention

 

Explanation:

  • The patient is exhibiting symptoms typical of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), specifically contamination fears and compulsive washing.
  • The most effective treatment for OCD, especially in cases like this, is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP).
  • This technique involves exposing the patient to feared situations (e.g., touching something "contaminated") and preventing compulsive behaviour (e.g., hand washing).

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder:

  • The patient has recurrent obsessions and compulsions.
  • Recurrent obsessions or compulsions may cause severe distress or anxiety to the person.

 

Obsessions

Compulsions
  • Intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses.
  • Most common: Contamination
  • Repetitive actions or thoughts carried out in a strict, regulation-bound manner or reaction to obsessions
  • Performed to relieve anxiety or fear.
  • Most common: Checking

 

  • These are time-consuming (at least 1 hr/day) and significantly interfere with the person’s routine, occupational functioning, usual social activities, or relationships.
  • Patients can have only obsessions, only compulsions, or both obsessions and compulsions (most common).
  • The most common comorbidity associated with OCD is major depressive disorder (67%).

 

  • Major symptom patterns:

Contamination / Cleansing
  • Most common presentation.
  • An obsession with contamination followed by washing and avoidance of the presumably contaminated object.

Pathological doubt /checking
  • Second most common presentation.
  • Obsession of doubt, usually followed by compulsion of checking.

Intrusive/forbidden thoughts
  • Third most common presentation.
  • Obsessed with intrusive thoughts of aggressive or sexual acts without a compulsion.

Symmetry/ordering
  • Fourth most common presentation.
  • Patient needs symmetry/precision, which results in the compulsion of slowness.

Other symptoms
  • Religious obsessions and compulsive hoarding.

 

Symptom specifiers:

  • Tic related: current or prior history of tic disorder.
  • Patients may have good/fair insight.
  • Patient with poor insight.
  • Patient with absent insight/delusional beliefs.


 

Treatment:

Pharmacotherapy:

  • First line:
    • SSRIs (preferred) and Clomipramine
    • Treatment should be continued for 1-2 years
  • Augmenting agents:
    • Antipsychotics: Risperidone, Aripiprazole.
    • Others: Memantine, riluzole, ketamine, lamotrigine, and N-acetylcysteine (NAC).

Psychotherapy:

  • Cognitive Behaviour Therapy (CBT):
    • Exposure and response prevention (ERP)
    • Exposure to feared situations is given. The patient is asked not to engage in a compulsive response.
  • Other therapies are desensitization, thought-stopping, flooding, aversive conditioning, psychodynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy.
  • In younger patients, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is preferred first.
  • In more severe symptoms or comorbid depression, pharmacotherapy is preferred first.
  • A combination of CBT and pharmacotherapy is particularly useful.

Somatic Therapies:

  • Anterior cingulotomy and capsulotomy.
  • Deep brain stimulation with implantation of electrodes.

questions.text: What is the interpretation of the following PTA conducted on a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mixed hearing loss

Explanation:

 

Both air conduction (AC) and bone conduction (BC) are defective. However, AC and BC are not equally defective, as there is a significant air-bone gap (>15 dB). This confirms the presence of mixed hearing loss.


 

Pure Tone Audiometry:

  • AC & BC are tested with the help of pure tones produced by Audiometer
  • Charted in a graph called Audiogram
  • It is a subjective test that relies on patient feedback to determine hearing thresholds across various frequencies.
  • AC vs. BC (A-B Gap): Indicates the degree of conductive deafness.

 

Aspect

Air Conduction (AC)

Bone Conduction (BC)

Frequency Range

125 - 8000 Hz

250 - 4000 Hz

Indicates

Overall hearing sensitivity

Cochlear function

 

Normal Ear
  • Both AC and BC thresholds are within the normal range (Within 20db in all frequencies)
  • No significant A-B gap

Conductive Hearing Loss
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal.
  • BC Thresholds: Within normal limits.
  • A-B Gap (>20db): Significant

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL)
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated to the same degree as AC.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal or absent

Presbycusis


 
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated, particularly in high frequencies.
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated with greater loss in higher frequencies.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal
  • Downsloping

Meniere’s Disease
  • Upsloping
  • A-B Gap: Typically minimal

questions.text: Carhart's notch is seen in which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Otosclerosis

Explanation:

Carhart’s notch is a characteristic dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz seen in otosclerosis. It is an audiometric finding caused by stapes fixation, which affects the transmission of sound through the ossicular chain.


 

Feature

Otosclerosis

Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL)

Air Conduction

Loss, more pronounced at lower frequencies

-

Bone Conduction and Characteristic pattern

Normal, may show "Carhart's notch" at 2000 Hz (5-15 dB loss)

Typical notch at 4000 Hz in both air and bone conduction (Boiler's notch)

Hearing Loss

Mixed

Sensorineural
 

 

 

Ossicular Discontinuity (Option B): This typically presents with conductive hearing loss but does not show Carhart’s notch.

 

Oto Syphilis (Option C): This can cause sensorineural hearing loss due to cochlear involvement but does not present with Carhart’s notch.


Serous Otitis Media (Option D): This results in conductive hearing loss due to fluid in the middle ear, but it does not cause the characteristic Carhart’s notch.

questions.text: Which one of the following causes maximum hearing loss:

choices.text: Disrupted ossicular chain with intact tympanic membrane
Disrupted ossicular chain and disrupted tympanic membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Disrupted ossicular chain with intact tympanic membrane

Explanation:

 

Among the given options, ossicular discontinuity with an intact tympanic membrane leads to the highest hearing loss, around 55 dB.

 

Hearing Loss Degrees in Different Conditions:

  1. Tympanic Membrane (TM) perforation → 10–40 dB hearing loss
  2. Complete obstruction of External Auditory Canal (EAC) → 30–40 dB hearing loss
  3. TM perforation with ossicular discontinuity → 40 dB hearing loss
  4. Ossicular discontinuity with intact TM → 55 dB hearing loss
  5. Complete fixation of the footplate of the stapes (seen in otosclerosis) → 60 dB hearing loss

questions.text: Most common hearing test done in neonates for screening:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) OAE
 

Explanation:

 

OAE is the preferred screening test in neonates due to its ease of use, reliability, and non-invasiveness.

 

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE):

is a test in which emissions are generated by outer hair cells and are used to evaluate hearing in individuals with cognitive impairments.

  • OAEs are low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal.

  • Pathway:

  • The absence of OAE indicates damage in the outer hair cell (conditions like lesions of the cochlea, middle ear disorders, etc.).
  • Types:

  • Spontaneous OAEs involve emissions without any external stimulation (sound). They may be absent in 50% of the individuals.
  • Evoked OAEs require an external stimulus.
    • Transient evoked OAEs (TEOAEs): Evoked by clicks (mixture of various frequencies).
    • Distortion product OAEs: Two tones (specific frequencies) are simultaneously presented to the cochlea to produce distortion products.
  • Uses of OAE:
    • They are used as a screening test for neonates, uncooperative or mentally challenged individuals.
    • Differentiate between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss.
    • Helpful in early detection of noise-induced hearing loss.

 

Clap & Smile (Option A): This is an informal behavioral response test that is subjective and unreliable for neonatal hearing screening.

 

BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) (Option B): This is used for diagnostic confirmation in high-risk infants (ICU) but is not the first-line screening test due to its higher cost and complexity.

 

PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry) (Option D): This requires active patient participation, which is not possible in neonates.

questions.text: Marshall's triad (punctate lacerations, bruises, and abrasions) is seen in which type of blast injury?

choices.text:
Primary blast injury
B) Secondary blast injury
C) Tertiary blast injury
D) Quaternary blast injury

questions.solution:
Secondary blast injuries are Caused by flying debris and shrapnel propelled by the blast. This results in Marshall's triad: punctate lacerations, bruises, and abrasions, characteristic of injuries from high-velocity fragments.

 

Blast Injury: Blast injuries are complex physical traumas resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion, leading to sudden changes in atmospheric pressure.

 

 

Classification of Blast Injuries:

Type

Mechanism

Features

Primary Injury

(Option A ruled out)

It results from blast waves and is often internal with no external signs.
  • Ears: Tympanic membrane rupture or inner ear disruption.
  • Lungs: Alveolar-capillary membrane haemorrhage (blast lung), most common cause cause of death in survivors.
  • GIT: Injuries to gas-filled organs are more common in underwater blasts.

Secondary Injury

It is resulting from shrapnel, debris & flying objects (propelled by explosion).
  • Penetrating trauma.
  • The characteristic Marshall triad, which includes bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations, is evident.
  • Commonly cause severe thoracic injuries, including lacerations of the heart and great vessels.

Tertiary Injury

(Option C ruled out)

Victims are thrown against solid objects by blast winds.
  • Blunt/Penetrating trauma.
  • Includes bone fractures and coup-contrecoup injuries.

Quaternary Injury

(Option D ruled out)

Encompass all other injuries not classified above
  • Flash burns from extreme heat.
  • Crush injuries and falls due to explosions.
  • Respiratory injuries from toxic dust, gases, or radiation exposure.
  • Psychiatric issues, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), may affect individuals even if they are physically unharmed.

questions.text: The compound shown in the image can be used in the treatment of which of the following poisonings?

choices.text:
Aluminum Phosphide
B) Mercury
C) Phosphorus
D) Arsenic

questions.solution:
Copper sulfate acts as an oxidizing agent and converts elemental phosphorus into less toxic compounds. It is specifically used in phosphorus poisoning cases.

 

Aluminum Phosphide (Option A): Aluminum phosphide poisoning is treated with supportive care, magnesium sulfate, and antioxidants.

 

Mercury (Option B): Mercury poisoning is treated with chelating agents such as dimercaprol, succimer, or DMSA.

 

Arsenic (Option D): Arsenic poisoning is treated with chelators like dimercaprol or succimer.

questions.text: A student presents with shock, pulmonary edema, and a positive silver nitrate breath test after consuming an unknown substance. What is the antidote?
questions.solution:
• The silver nitrate breath test detects phosphine gas, confirming aluminum phosphide poisoning.
  • Aluminum phosphide poisoning releases phosphine gas, which causes severe mitochondrial dysfunction, circulatory collapse, and pulmonary edema.
  • Magnesium sulfate stabilizes myocardial membranes and helps counteract hypomagnesemia, a common complication.
  • Management includes supportive care (fluids, vasopressors, oxygen therapy), magnesium sulfate, and antioxidants.

Antidotes and their mechanisms

Poisoning Type

Antidote

Mechanism

Arsenic

BAL (Dimercaprol) (Option A ruled out)

IM, chelates arsenic for excretion.

Succimer (DMSA)

Oral chelation.

DMPS

IV, transitioned to oral chelation.

Copper

Potassium Ferrocyanide

Forms insoluble copper complexes, reducing absorption.

Penicillamine

Chelates copper.

Cyanide

Sodium Nitrite

Forms methemoglobin to bind cyanide.

Sodium Thiosulfate

Converts cyanide to thiocyanate for renal excretion.

Hydroxocobalamin

Binds cyanide, forming cyanocobalamin.

Dicobalt Edetate, Methylene Blue

Alternative antidotes.

Ethylene Glycol

Ethanol/Fomepizole

Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase to prevent toxic metabolites.

Iron

Desferrioxamine

Chelates iron for excretion.

Magnesium Hydroxide/Sodium Bicarbonate

 

Note: BAL should not be used in iron, cadmium, or selenium poisoning due to formation of toxic complexes.

Precipitate iron, reducing absorption.

Lead

Sodium/Magnesium Sulfate

Forms insoluble lead sulfate.

Calcium Chloride/Gluconate

Promotes bone deposition of lead.

CaNa2EDTA + BAL

Chelation therapy for lead elimination.

Mercury

Sodium Formaldehyde Sulfoxylate

Reduces toxic mercury ions.

BAL (Dimercaprol)

Traditional chelator; oral agents preferred.

Methanol

Ethanol/Fomepizole

Compete for alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing toxic metabolites.

Opium

Naloxone

Blocks opioid receptors, reversing opioid effects.

Organophosphate

Atropine (Option D ruled out)

Blocks muscarinic receptors to manage cholinergic symptoms.

Pralidoxime (2-PAM) (Option B ruled out)

Reactivates acetylcholinesterase.

Phenol

Magnesium Sulfate

Absorbs phenol in the stomach.

Phosphorus

Potassium Permanganate

Oxidizes phosphorus into harmless phosphates.

Strychnine

Barbiturates

Depress CNS, preventing seizures.

Thallium

Prussian Blue

Binds thallium in the intestine, preventing absorption.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of antidotes and toxicities is correctly matched?

choices.text:
Organophosphorus - Physostigmine
B) Atropine - L-carnitine
C) Benzodiazepine - Flumazenil
