questions.text: Which among the following is not seen in heat exhaustion?
questions.solution:
Loss of thermoregulatory control is a hallmark of heat stroke, not heat exhaustion. In heat exhaustion, the thermoregulatory mechanisms are intact but overwhelmed.

 

Condition

Cause

Clinical Features

Postmortem Findings

Heat Exhaustion

Prolonged strenuous activity with inadequate water/salt intake in a hot environment.
  • Nausea, vomiting, malaise, myalgia
  • CNS symptoms:(Option B ruled out) dizziness, fatigue, impaired judgment, psychosis (severe water depletion)
  • Moist skin, increased pulse, rectal temperature > 37.8°C

Non-specific

Heat Cramps (Miner’s/Stoker’s/Fireman’s Cramps)

Fluid and electrolyte depletion (dilutional hyponatremia), following vigorous activity and profuse sweating.
  • Sudden severe muscle cramps (arms, legs, abdomen)
  • Tender, hard, lumpy muscles
  • Flushed face, dilated pupils, dizziness, vomiting
  • Moist, cool skin, body temperature normal/slightly elevated

Non-specific

Heat Stroke


 

Failure of thermoregulation in extreme heat exposure

(Option A)
  • Sudden collapse-loss of consciousness
  • Skin hot, initially wet, then dry
  • Hyperventilation- tachycardia
  • Core temp > 40.5°C
  • Pupils contracted
  • Convulsions
  • Unconsciousness
  • Cerebral dysfunction
  • High fever
  • Absence of sweating
  • Congested lungs, intrathoracic petechiae (children)
  • Subendocardial hemorrhages
  • Brain congestion, flattened convolutions, petechiae in the 3rd/4th ventricle walls

Orthostatic hypotension (Option C): Due to dehydration and reduced plasma volume, orthostatic hypotension is a common feature of heat exhaustion.

 

 

Core body temperature below 105 °F (Option D): In heat exhaustion, the core body temperature typically remains below 105 °F (40.5 °C), distinguishing it from heat stroke where temperatures exceed this threshold.

questions.text: What is Anisometropia?

choices.text: Difference in refractive error between 2 eyes
Difference in the axial length of the eyeball
Difference in the size of the eyeball

questions.solution:
• Anisometropia is when total refraction of the two eyes is unequal.
  • The difference in power of two eyes is more than 2.5 diopters.
  • Anisometropia up to 2.5D is well tolerated and that between 2.5 and 4D can be tolerated depending upon the individual sensitivity.
  • However, if it is more than 4D, it is not tolerated and is a matter of concern.

 

Difference in visual acuity (Option A) could be caused by conditions like myopia, hypermetropia, astigmatism, and presbyopia.

Difference in axial length (Option C) of the eyeball is seen in axial myopia.

Difference in size of eyeball (Option D) is seen in conditions like Microphthalmia and Buphthalmos.

questions.text: A patient presents with a vision problem in the right eye. On examination, the intraocular pressure (IOP) of the right eye is 50 mmHg, while the IOP of the left eye is 16 mmHg. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye reveals flare cells in the anterior chamber and a cataractous lens. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text:
Phacolytic glaucoma
B) Malignant glaucoma
C) Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis
D) Phacomorphic glaucoma

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Glaucoma and the slit lamp image flare cells in the anterior chamber and a cataractous lens corresponds to secondary open-angle glaucoma called Phacolytic glaucoma.

 

Feature

Phacomorphic Glaucoma (Option D)

Phacolytic Glaucoma (Option A)

Pathogenesis
  • Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil.
  • this pushes the iris forward,
  • blocking the anterior chamber angle,
  • leading to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork. 

 

Causes
  • Intumescent cataract (mature cataract)
  • Anterior subluxation of lens
  • Spherophakia
  • Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract
  • Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Shallow anterior chamber.
  • Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible.
  • Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.
  • Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP.
  • Deep anterior chamber.
  • Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.

Management
  • Medical Treatment: IV mannitol, systemic acetazolamide, topical beta-blockers.
  • Laser Iridotomy: To relieve angle closure.
  • Surgical Treatment: Cataract extraction with PCIOL implantation.
  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract and PCIOL implantation.

Malignant glaucoma (Option B) shallowing of the anterior chamber is noticed and Seidel’s test is negative.

Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis (Option C), low-grade flare and cells, with stellate keratic precipitates and fine filaments may be seen but IOP is not very high as in the above case.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa?

choices.text:
ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b waves
B) Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy
C) Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
D) Night vision is lost late and rare
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night vision is lost late and rare

questions.solution:
Night Blindness is the characteristic and earliest feature of retinitis pigmentosa and may present several years before the visible changes in the retina appear.

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa:

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a dystrophy of rods and cones, initially, rods are affected.(Option B ruled out)
  • Most common hereditary fundus dystrophy.
  • It can be sporadic (40-50%) or hereditary.
  • If hereditary, autosomal dominant is the most common mode of inheritance followed by autosomal recessive (AR). X-linked recessive inheritance is the least severe form.

 

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Nyctalopia (night blindness) (Option D)
  • Peripheral visual field loss
  • Mid-peripheral superior scotoma leads to ring/ doughnut scotoma resulting in tubular/ tunnel vision. Central vision is affected in later stages (Option C ruled out)

Signs:

  • Triad of a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.
  • Tapetal reflex: shinning reflex at macula - seen in female carriers of XLR inheritance.

 

Atypical Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Atypical retinitis pigmentosa includes heterogeneous disorders that share clinical features with typical pigmentary retinal dystrophy.
  • Conditions included are:
  • RP sine pigmento - absence or paucity of pigment accumulation

 

  • Retinitis punctata albescens - scattered whitish-yellow spots with arteriolar attenuation, usually sparing the macula.

 

  • Sectoral RP - only inferior quadrants are involved.

 

Investigation of Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Electroretinography (ERG) is the investigation of choice - reduced scotopic rod in early disease and reduced photopic with progression.
  • EOG- subnormal- absence of light rise.
  • Perimetry: initially small mid-peripheral scotomas which gradually merge and may progress, leaving only a small island of residual central vision.
  • Electroretinography (ERG): There's a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.(Option A ruled out)
  • OCT- to identify cystoid macular edema (CME).
  • Dark adaptometry: Dark adaptation time is prolonged.
  • Decreased Arden ratio may be present.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field loss of vision for the past week. What is the most likely cause of this condition?

choices.text:
Branched retinal artery occlusion
B) Central retinal artery occlusion
C) Branched retinal vein occlusion
D) Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.solution:
• Branched retinal vein occlusion occurs as quadrantic occlusion due to occlusion at the level of AV crossing.
  • It is mostly seen in the superotemporal retinal as AV crossings are more in this area, so the chances of blockage are higher.
  • In this case, the patient is presenting with superior field loss of vision due to blockage in the inferior branch retinal vein.

 

Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO)

BRVO occurs when a single branch of the central retinal vein is occluded, causing retinal edema and hemorrhages localized to the area supplied by the blocked vein.

  • Visual Defects:
    • Visual loss is partial, superior or inferior field loss, depending on the location of the occlusion.
    • Prognosis for central vision is better unless the macula is involved, often seen in superior temporal vein occlusion.
  • Complications:
    • Neovascularization and secondary glaucoma are rare but can occur in cases of widespread capillary occlusion.
  • Diagnostic Features:
    • Fluorescein Angiography: Shows areas of hypofluorescence, incomplete perifoveal arcades, and capillary closure in poorly perfused areas.
    • Widespread capillary occlusion is associated with cotton-wool spots, delayed arteriovenous transit time, vessel leakage, and retinal edema.
  • Treatment:
    • No definitive treatment is effective once complete venous blockage occurs.
    • Panphotocoagulation or Cryotherapy: Used to prevent complications like neovascular glaucoma and rubeosis iridis in cases of widespread capillary occlusion.
    • Photocoagulation: Should only be performed after intraretinal blood absorption to address areas of poor perfusion, reducing edema and neovascularization risk.
    • Anti-VEGF Therapy: Intravitreal injections are now standard for improving visual recovery and preventing late complications.

Branched retinal artery occlusion (Option A) a cherry red spot in the retina is noticed due to the surrounding edema.

Central retinal artery occlusion (Option B) obstruction occurs at the level of the lamina cribrosa, causing sudden painless loss of vision within seconds.

Central retinal vein occlusion (Option D) there is a mild blurring of vision, which improves over the day.

questions.text: Which procedure is shown in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stapedotomy

Explanation:

  • The image depicts stapedotomy, a surgical procedure used to treat otosclerosis.
  • Procedure: A small hole is created in the stapes footplate, and a prosthesis is placed to restore the transmission of sound vibrations to the inner ear.
  • This procedure helps improve conductive hearing loss caused by stapes fixation.

Stapedotomy vs. Stapedectomy

 

Procedure

Description

Complications

Stapedotomy

A small opening made in the stapes footplate; a prosthesis is inserted.

Lower complication rates; preferred by many otologists.

Stapedectomy

Complete removal of the stapes bone; replaced with a prosthetic device.

Higher risk of complications.

Myringotomy (Option B): This involves creating a small incision in the tympanic membrane to drain middle ear fluid, commonly used in otitis media with effusion.

Myringoplasty (Option C): This is a surgical repair of a small tympanic membrane perforation, without involving the ossicles.

Tympanoplasty (Option D): This is a more extensive procedure that repairs the tympanic membrane along with ossicular reconstruction if needed.

questions.text: What lies posterior to the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Eustachian tube
 

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the inferior turbinate.
  • The structure located approximately 1.25 cm posterior to the inferior turbinate is the opening of the Eustachian tube.

Important Structures in the Nasopharynx Related to the Lateral Wall of the Nose:

  • Lateral Wall Continuation: The lateral wall of the nose extends beyond the turbinates into the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.
  • Eustachian Tube (ET):
    • Located 1.25 cm posterior and slightly inferior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.
    • Mnemonic: Behind the Inferior turbinate is ET (E for Inferior).
  • Sphenopalatine Foramen: (Option C)
    • Located 1 cm posterior and slightly inferior to the posterior end of the middle turbinate.
    • Connects the nasopharynx laterally with the sphenopalatine (pterygopalatine) fossa.

Odontoid (Option A): The odontoid process (dens) is part of the C2 vertebra in the cervical spine and is unrelated to nasal or nasopharyngeal structures.

 

Agger nasi (Option D): The agger nasi is an anterior ethmoidal air cell, located anterior to the middle turbinate, not posterior to the inferior turbinate.

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body (chuna) in the eye and complaints of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step in management for this patient?

choices.text:
Antibiotic eye drops
B) Ascorbic eye drops
C) Irrigation of the eye with normal saline
D) Steroids
Irrigation of the eye with normal saline

questions.solution:
• Chemical injury to the conjunctiva and cornea is a severe ocular emergency that must be treated immediately.
  • The first and the most crucial step in treating chemical injuries is copious eye irrigation by double eversion of the lid with normal saline.
  • Deliver a minimum of 2 liters of water in 20-30 minutes or until pH is restored.

Management of Alkali Burns in the Eye:

Initial Evaluation and Emergency Response

  • Immediate Irrigation:
    • Continue irrigation during transport to the hospital until ocular surface pH normalizes to 7.0–7.2.
    • Borate buffer (e.g., Cederroth Eye Wash) may be more effective than saline or water.
  • Monitor pH:
    • Check ocular pH with narrow-range strips (6–8) every 15–30 minutes to confirm stabilization.

Ophthalmic Examination: Perform a full exam after pH normalization:

 

Treatment Based on Severity (Grade I–IV):

Grade I (Mild Injuries):

  • Treatment:
    • Topical antibiotic ointments (e.g., bacitracin, erythromycin).(Option A ruled out)
    • Preservative-free artificial tears for lubrication.
    • Topical steroids (e.g., prednisolone acetate) for 1 week to reduce inflammation. (Option D ruled out)
    • Cycloplegic agents (e.g., cyclopentolate) for comfort.

 

Grades II–IV (Moderate to Severe Injuries):

  • Anti-inflammatory Measures:
    • Hourly topical prednisolone acetate in the first week, tapered after day 10.
    • Long-acting cycloplegics (e.g., atropine) for pain relief.
    • Oral tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline) to inhibit matrix metalloproteinases and reduce corneal melting risk.
    • High-dose vitamin C (topical/oral) to prevent corneal ulceration.
  • Antibiotics:
    • Topical broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., fluoroquinolones) to prevent superinfection.
  • IOP Management:
    • Use aqueous suppressants to control elevated IOP.
  • Amniotic Membrane:
    • Early placement of amniotic membrane (e.g., Prokera) for grades II–IV injuries to support epithelial healing.

 

Surgical Management

  • Debridement: Remove necrotic corneal and conjunctival epithelium with sponges or surgical instruments.
  • Persistent Epithelial Defects: Use amniotic membranes for healing (sutured or Prokera).

 

Ascorbic eye drops (Option B) promote collagen synthesis and improve wound healing but it is not the initial step.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the likely cause of this condition?

choices.text:
Subarachnoid hemorrhage
B) Retinal detachment
C) Vitreous hemorrhage
D) Branched retinal artery occlusion

questions.solution:
Pathological Myopia

Definition

Pathological/degenerative/progressive myopia is a rapidly progressive error that starts in childhood at 5-10 years of age and results in high myopia (>-6D) during early adult life.

Etiology
  • Rapid axial growth of the eyeball outside normal biological variations
  • Genetic factors (major role)
    • More common in women than men
    • Autosomal dominant pathological myopia
    • Heredity-
      • Familial, more common in women and in certain races
      • Autosomal Dominant - linked to genes 18p11.31 and 12q21-23
      • Sex-linked recessive - high myopia (>6D)
  • General growth process (minor role)
    • nutritional deficiency
    • endocrine disturbances

Symptoms
  • Defective vision with considerable failure in visual function
  • Muscae volitantes (floaters)
  • Difficulty in night vision in very high myopes with degenerative changes

Signs
  • Prominent eyeballs, often appear elongated
  • Exophthalmos, especially in unilateral cases
  • Cornea is large
  • The anterior chamber is deep
  • Pupils are slightly large and react sluggishly to light
  • Fundus examination reveals:
    • The optic disc appears large and pale
    • Characteristic myopic crescent
    • Tigroid fundus
    • Myopic crescent (temporal to disc margin)

Complications
  • Retinal detachment (Option B)
  • Complicated cataract
  • Choroidal hemorrhage and neovascularization
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma (associated condition)
  • Degenerative changes in the retina and choroid:
    • Chorioretinal atrophy at the macula

 

  • Foster-Fuchs spots

 

  • Lattice degeneration

 

  • Total retinal atrophy
  • Posterior staphyloma

 

  • Degenerative changes in vitreous:
    • Liquefaction
    • Vitreous opacities
    • Posterior vitreous detachment

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Option A) causes subhyaloid hemorrhage.

Vitreous hemorrhage (Option C) is caused by blunt force trauma and is not commonly associated with high myopia

Branched retinal artery occlusion (Option D) presents with a cherry red spot in the retina.

questions.text: Identify the fracture in the given diagram:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chevallet fracture
 

Explanation:

A Chevallet fracture runs vertically across the nasal septum.

 

Nasal fractures: Nasal fractures constitute about 40% of all facial fractures and are often accompanied by other facial injuries. Prompt management is crucial to prevent cosmetic and functional deformities.

 

Classification:

  • Nature of Injury: Most fractures result from lateral forces (>66%), with frontal impacts causing fewer injuries.
  • Extent of Deformity: A five-point grading system assesses lateral deviation
    • Grade 0: No deviation
    • Grade 1: Deviation <50% of nose width
    • Grade 2: Deviation 50%-100% of nose width
    • Grade 3: Deviation >100% of nose width
    • Grade 4: Bones almost touching the cheek
  • Pattern of Fracture: Fractures are categorised into three classes based on severity and treatment requirements:
 

Class I

(Chevallet Fracture)

Class II

(Jarjavay Fracture)

(Option B)

Class III

(Naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture)

Cause

Blows from below

Impacts directed from the front

High-velocity trauma

Fracture Line

Vertical fracture from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

Horizontal fracture starting just above the anterior nasal spine, running backwards just above the junction of septal cartilage and vomer.

Involves external buttresses of the nose and ethmoid labyrinth.

Pig-like appearance with foreshortened, saddled nose.

Clinical Relations:
  • Assess for nasal obstruction and deformity.
  • Significant deformity might only develop later, especially in children.
  • Check for deviation greater than half the width of the nose, which may indicate a septal fracture.
  • Requires reduction of both nasal and septal fractures.
  • Look for signs of more severe injuries, such as CSF leaks, multiple dural tears, and potential cerebral herniation.
  • Evaluate for orbital and skull base involvement.
 


 

Classification of Fractures of the maxilla:

 

 

Le Fort I

(Option C)

Le Fort II

Le Fort III

Also known as

Guerin’s fracture or Transverse fracture

Pyramidal fracture

Craniofacial disjunction

Fracture line

Runs above and parallel to the palate, crossing the lower nasal septum, maxillary antra, and pterygoid plates.

Passes through the nasal root, lacrimal bone, orbital floor, upper maxillary sinus, and pterygoid plates

 

Note: can cause infraorbital nerve injury.

Traverses the root of the nose, ethmoid-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral orbital wall, frontozygomatic and temporozygomatic sutures, and the upper pterygoid plates.

Characteristic feature

Hanging palate and hanging teeth

Hanging maxilla

Complete detachment of the facial bones from the cranial bones

CSF Rhinorrhea

Absent

May be present

High risk of CSF Rhinorrhea

 

Simple fracture (Option D): A simple fracture refers to a non-displaced, closed fracture with minimal soft tissue damage, which does not specifically describe the fracture shown in the diagram.

questions.text: All of the following are functions of the superior oblique muscle except?

choices.text:
Adduction
B) Abduction
C) Depression
D) Intorsion

questions.solution:
Actions of muscles on the eyeball:

Mnemonic SIN- Superior rectus/ Superior oblique assist in INtorsion

RAD- Rectus muscles help in ADduction

 

Superior rectus (SR)

Medial rectus (MR)

Inferior rectus (IR)

Lateral rectus (LR)

Superior oblique (SO)

Inferior oblique (IO)
  • Elevation
  • Adduction
  • Intorsion

Adduction
  • Depression
  • Adduction
  • Extorsion

Abduction
  • Depression (Option C)
  • Abduction (Option B)
  • Intorsion (Option D)
  • Elevation
  • Abduction
  • Extorsion

questions.text: Which of the following is a life-threatening nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bilateral Complete RLN Palsy
 

Explanation:

  • This condition leads to both vocal cords being fixed in a median or paramedian position, causing severe airway obstruction.
  • Patients experience stridor and dyspnea, making this the most life-threatening form of recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury.
  • Emergency management often requires tracheostomy or vocal cord lateralization surgery.

questions.text: All of the following are features of oculomotor nerve palsy except?
questions.solution:
• Limited abduction (inability to move the eye outward) is a feature of abducens nerve palsy.
  • This movement is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI).

 

Functions of muscle supplied by oculomotor nerve:

Superior rectus (SR)

Medial rectus (MR)

Inferior rectus (IR)

Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS)

Inferior oblique (IO)
  • Elevation
  • Adduction
  • Intorsion

Adduction (Option A ruled out)
  • Depression
  • Adduction
  • Extorsion

Elevation of superior eyelid (Option D ruled out)
  • Elevation
  • Abduction
  • Extorsion

 

Oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III)

Type

Motor

Origin

Midbrain (Oculomotor sulcus on the medial aspect of the cerebral peduncle).

Course

 

Components

1. Oculomotor nucleus (somatic component):

General somatic efferent (GSE) fibres emerge from this site and supply -

  • Superior division:
  • Levator palpebrae superioris
  • Superior rectus
  • Inferior division:
  • Medial rectus
  • Inferior rectus
  • Inferior oblique
 

2.Edinger-Westphal nucleus (parasympathetic component) (Option C ruled out):

General visceral efferent (GVE) fibres arise from this site and supply:

  • Sphincter pupillae- causes pupil constriction
  • Ciliaris

 

Note:

  • The nerve fibers innervating the pupillary muscles are located superficially in the nerve trunk and pial blood vessels supply these fibers.
  • The main trunk of the fibers is supplied by the vasa vasorum.
  • Diabetic and hypertensive microangiopathy will affect the vasa vasorum and thus spare the pupillary fibers.
  • Hence, pupil-sparing 3rd nerve lesions are seen with ischemic lesions such as diabetes, hypertension, or arteriosclerotic disease.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person?

choices.text:
Orbital varix
B) Thyroid eye disease
C) Retinoblastoma
D) Cavernous hemangioma

questions.solution:
Thyroid Eye disease Clinical Features :

Clinical Features

Details

Lid Signs

Dalrymple's Sign

Upper lid retraction causing a staring appearance (90% of cases).

Von Graefe's Sign

Lid lag when the globe moves downward (50% of cases).

Enroth's Sign

Puffy, oedematous swelling of the eyelids.

Gifford's Sign

Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid.

Stellwag's Sign

Infrequent blinking.

Joffroy's Sign

Poor forehead wrinkling on looking up.

Kocher’s sign

Increased lid retraction with visual fixation (staring look)

Conjunctival Signs

Deep Injection

Pronounced redness.

Chemosis

Swelling of the conjunctiva.

Pupillary Signs

Less significant; may show unequal dilatation of pupils.

Ocular Motility Defects

Mobius's Sign

Convergence weakness.

Restrictive Myopathy

Limited movement in the direction opposite to the affected muscle.

Exophthalmos

Both eyes are often affected with possible unilateral proptosis.(Option B)

 

Orbital varix (Option A) causes intermittent proptosis.

Retinoblastoma (Option C) does not cause proptosis.

Cavernous hemangioma (Option D) causes proptosis but it is not the most common cause.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought to the outpatient department (OPD) with symptoms of photophobia and watering of the eyes. Which of the following is not a cause of this condition?

choices.text:
Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction
B) Congenital entropion
C) Congenital glaucoma
D) Congenital distichiasis

questions.solution:
The hallmark of congenital distichiasis is an extra row of eyelashes that typically emerge from the openings of the meibomian glands along the posterior margin of the eyelid. It doesnot necessarily touch the cornea like entropion therefore its less likely to cause lacrimation and photophobia among the given options

Distichiasis - Extra row of eyelash

 

Clinical features
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Photophobia, in cases of corneal irritation
  • Irritation
  • Pain
  • Lacrimation, in cases of corneal irritation
  • Reflex blepharospasm and photophobia (if the cornea is abraded)
  • Conjunctival congestion

Complications
  • Recurrent corneal abrasions
  • Superficial corneal opacities
  • Corneal vascularization
  • Non-healing corneal ulcer

Treatment
  • Epilation
  • Electrolysis
  • Cryoepilation
  • Surgical correction

Options A, B, and C: All of these conditions present with photophobia and watering of the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the retina are correctly marked?

choices.text:
1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Outer nuclear layer; 3-Inner plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer
B) 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer
C) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-RPE
D) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Outer plexiform layer; 3-Inner nuclear layer; 4-RPE
1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer

questions.solution:
Histology of Retina:

 

 

Layers of the Retina:

 

Layer

Description

1. Pigment Epithelium

Outermost layer with a single pigmented cell layer; adheres to Bruch's membrane; supports neurosensory retina, and reduces reflection.

Subretinal Space: This is the layer between the Pigment epithelium and the layer of Photoreceptors.

2. Rods and Cones Layer

Contains the outer segments of photoreceptors (rods and cones, which are the first-order neurons); rods detect low-light vision, cones manage color and detailed vision.

3. External Limiting Membrane

A porous membrane allows processes from rods and cones to pass through.

4. Outer Nuclear Layer
(Henle’s layer)

Contains the nuclei of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones).

5. Outer Plexiform Layer

Includes connections between rods, cones, bipolar cell dendrites, and horizontal cells.

6. Inner Nuclear Layer

Made up of the cell bodies of bipolar cells (which are the second-order neurons), horizontal cells, amacrine cells, and Müller cells; and also contains retinal capillaries.

7. Inner Plexiform Layer

Houses synaptic connections between bipolar cell axons, ganglion cell dendrites, and amacrine cell processes.

8. Ganglion Cell Layer

Contains ganglion cell bodies, which serve as third-order neurons; midget cells synapse with a single bipolar cell, and polysynaptic cells synapse with multiple.

9. Nerve Fiber Layer

Composed of ganglion cell axons that form the optic nerve after passing through the lamina cribrosa.

10. Internal Limiting Membrane

The innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous; is formed by the terminal expansions of Müller cells, serving as a basement membrane.

 

The Neuroglial cells, particularly the vertical Müller cells, bind the retina's neural elements. These cells provide structural support and nourish the retinal tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about macular opacity?

choices.text: Iris and pupillary margin are not visible

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Iris details are visible

 

Explanation:

Macular opacity refers to an opacity in the lens or cornea that affects the passage of light and vision. The extent to which the iris and pupil are visible depends on the density and location of the opacity.

  • In macular opacity, the central part of the lens is affected, which significantly impairs central vision and causes a "shadowing" effect in the visual axis.
  • As a result, only the pupillary margin is visible, while details of the iris may be obscured due to the opacity.

 

Iris and pupil are visible (Option A): If both the iris and pupil were completely visible, it would suggest the absence of significant central opacity, which contradicts the question.

 

Iris details are visible (Option C): If iris details were visible, it would imply minimal or no opacity, which is incorrect for macular opacity.

 

Iris and pupillary margin are not visible (Option B): This would be true for total opacity (e.g., mature cataract or dense corneal opacity), but macular opacity allows limited peripheral visualization.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
• Diabetic retinopathy is a progressive microvascular complication of diabetes, which can lead to proliferative changes, causing fibrovascular proliferation and subsequent tractional retinal detachment (TRD).
  • This occurs due to contraction of fibrovascular membranes over the retina, leading to vitreoretinal traction and retinal elevation.

 

Complications of Diabetic Retinopathy:

1. Macular Edema:

  • The most common cause of vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is leakage from dilated capillaries.
  • Clinically significant macular edema (CSME):
    • Retinal thickening at the center of the macula.
    • Retinal thickening and/or adjacent hard exudates at or within 500 µ of the center of the macula.
    • An area of retinal thickening greater than or equal to one disc area, any part of which is within 1 disc diameter of the center of the macula.
  • Types: Focal or Diffuse macular edema

  • Diagnosis:
    • Slit-lamp Biomicroscopy: Loss of foveal reflex and macular thickening
    • Fluorescein Angiography Identifies leakage and also diagnoses ischemic maculopathy.

 

  • Treatment:
  1. Anti-VEGF Therapy: Bevacizumab, ranibizumab or aflibercept.
    • Laser treatment should be deferred for 6 months after commencement of anti-VEGF injection.
  2. Intravitreal Triamcinolone acetonide: Reduce macular edema and improve visual acuity.
  3. Photocoagulation:
    • Focal Photocoagulation: Treatment of choice for focal diabetic macular edema (DME) not involving the center of the fovea using diode or argon burns.
    • Grid Photocoagulation: Considered in recalcitrant cases unresponsive to anti-VEGF agents or intravitreal steroids. Burns are applied to macular areas of diffuse retinal thickening, treating no closer than 500 µ from the foveola and 500 µ from the optic disc.

 

 

2. Vitreous Hemorrhage (VH):

  • Seen as blood floating in the vitreous, occluding the view of the retina.
  • Secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is a cause of severe vision loss in diabetic patients.
  • In PDR, fibrovascular tissue lies flat on the retina or attaches to the posterior vitreous, leading to vitreous traction, retinal separation, and vessel rupture. This is the most common cause of VH in adults.

 

3. Retinal Detachment:

  • PDR causes scars to form in the back of the eye. When the scars pull the retina away from the back of the eye, it's called tractional retinal detachment.

 

4. Neovascular Glaucoma:

  • PDR causes abnormal blood vessels to grow out of the retina and block fluid from draining out of the eye, leading to neovascular glaucoma.
  • Can cause vision loss and blindness.

 

5. Rubeosis Iridis:

  • Neovascularization of iris, is when blood vessels develop on the anterior surface of the iris in response to retinal ischemia.
  • Prone to spontaneous hyphema as the blood vessels are fragile.
  • Treatment: Panretinal photocoagulation with or without intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF.

 

Posterior staphyloma (Option A): Posterior staphyloma is associated with pathologic myopia, not diabetic retinopathy. It involves progressive thinning and outward bulging of the sclera, primarily in high myopia.

 

Retinoschisis (Option B): Retinoschisis refers to the splitting of the retinal layers, commonly seen in degenerative retinoschisis or X-linked retinoschisis, rather than as a complication of diabetic retinopathy.

 

Progressive myopia (Option D): Progressive myopia is associated with axial elongation of the eyeball, typically seen in high myopia, rather than diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: In Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA), how do microaneurysms appear?

choices.text: Hyperfluorescent branching-like structure in the vessel

questions.solution:
• Microaneurysms are the earliest clinically detectable lesions in diabetic retinopathy and appear as small, round dilations of retinal capillaries.
  • In Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA), they exhibit hyperfluorescence due to leakage of fluorescein dye from these abnormal capillaries.
    • Microaneurysms initially appear as hyperfluorescent dots in early-phase FFA due to accumulation of fluorescein dye.
    • In later phases, leakage may lead to diffuse hyperfluorescence in severe cases.

 

Fundus Fluorescein Angiography

 

Principle: Based on the detection of fluorescent light emitted by fluorescein dye in circulation.

  • Absorption & Emission Wavelengths:
    • Irradiating light: 420–490 nm.
    • Emitted fluorescence: 510–530 nm.
  • Retinal pigments and red blood cells can absorb fluorescent light, masking deeper structures. Pigment migration allows visibility of deeper layers.

 

Diagnostic uses:

  • Diabetic Retinopathy: Reveals neovascularization, and assesses vascular tree integrity.
  • Fundus Disorders: Identifies depth of pathological involvement.
  • Optic Nerve Pathologies: Useful in detecting optic nerve issues such as papilloedema.
  • Neovascularization of Iris: Detects leakage from iris vessels, an early sign of rubeosis.

Normal Study

 

Hypofluorescent dots (Option A): Microaneurysms do not appear hypofluorescent. Hypofluorescent lesions are usually blockages (e.g., hemorrhages, pigment deposits) or vascular occlusions.

 

Hypofluorescent line (Option C): Hypofluorescent lines are seen in conditions like vascular occlusions (e.g., branch retinal artery occlusion).

 

Hyperfluorescent branching-like structure in the vessel (Option D): This pattern is seen in neovascularization, not microaneurysms.

questions.text: What is the normal artery-to-vein ratio at the optic disc margin?
questions.solution:
The normal artery-to-vein (A:V) ratio at the optic disc margin is approximately 2:3 in a healthy eye. This ratio is clinically important in assessing retinal vascular changes.

  • A significantly reduced A:V ratio suggests worsening microvascular disease and increased risk of retinal complications.
  • Hypertension can reduce the A:V ratio (e.g., 1:3 or 1:4) due to arteriolar narrowing.
  • Diabetes mellitus may also cause changes, but typically with venous dilatation and beading.

questions.text: What is a common ocular finding in pterygium?
questions.solution:
• A pterygium is a fibrovascular growth extending from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, often associated with UV exposure and chronic irritation.
  • The most common visual disturbance caused by a pterygium is astigmatism, due to its pulling effect on the cornea, leading to corneal distortion and irregular refraction.

 

Eye pain (Option A): Pterygium can cause irritation, foreign body sensation, and redness, but severe pain is not a primary feature. Pain occurs only if there is inflammation or ulceration.

 

Macular edema (Option B): Pterygium affects the cornea and conjunctiva, but it does not involve the retina or macula. Macular edema is seen in conditions like diabetic retinopathy or retinal vein occlusion.

 

Purulent discharge (Option C): Pterygium is a non-infectious degenerative condition, so it does not cause purulent discharge. Discharge may be seen in bacterial conjunctivitis or dacryocystitis.

 

Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

Pseudopterygium
 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.

 
  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process
  • Pterygium like lesion
  • Due to cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth
 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons
  • Seen at any age
  • Caused by
    • Trauma
    • Chronic conjunctivitis
    • Thermochemical burn




 

Pathology

 

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

  
 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane
  


 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflammed pterygium

 
  • Non-progressive
  • Can be at any quadrant of the corneal limbus
  • Located away from the horizontal
  • Attached to the cornea due to scar tissue
  • Adhered to the adjacent lid
  • Always stationary

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.

 
  • A probe can be passed under the neck.

Management of pterygium:






 

Management

Best left alone

 

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia







 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique:
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or
    • An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation for Best disease?

choices.text:
EOG
B) ERG
C) Multifocal ERG
D) Visual evoked potential

questions.solution:
Electro-oculography (EOG) is the gold standard diagnostic test for Best disease.

 

Best disease/ Best Vitelliform Macular Dystrophy (BVMD), also known as juvenile-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy, is the second most common macular dystrophy after Stargardt disease.

  • Caused by mutations in the BEST1 gene located on chromosome 11q13.
  • Bestrophin, the protein produced by this gene, functions as a transmembrane ion channel in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).
  • Inherited in an autosomal dominant (AD) pattern.
  • Usually begins in childhood

 

Clinical Features:

  • Stages of the disease include:
    • Pre-vitelliform: abnormal EOG, normal fundus in asymptomatic patients.
    • Vitelliform: a characteristic "egg yolk or sunny-side up" macular lesion. The lesions can vary in size and developmental stage between the two eyes.

 

  • Pseudohypopyon: partially regressed lesion.
  • Vitelliruptive: Lesion fragments, visual acuity declines - “scrambled egg appearance”.

  • Atrophic: Pigment disappears, leading to RPE atrophy.
  • Visual acuity - stable early on but declines in adulthood due to complications like choroidal neovascularization (CNV), scarring, or geographic atrophy.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Fundus Autofluorescence (FAF): hyper autofluorescence yellowish material.
  • Fluorescein Angiography (FA): hypofluorescence due to lesion masking.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): hyperreflective material beneath and within the RPE.
  • Electro-oculography (EOG): Severely subnormal across all stages (Arden index <1.5).
  • Hallmark- normal electroretinogram (ERG) but abnormal electrooculogram (EOG). (Option B ruled out) (Option A)
    • Best disease progresses through five stages, starting with the "egg-yolk" vitelliform lesion and potentially leading to choroidal neovascularization (CNV).
    • Asymptomatic carriers may show a reduced Arden ratio on EOG, making it useful for family screening.

 

Multifocal ERG (Option C): Multifocal ERG assesses macular function and can show localized dysfunction, but it is not the definitive test for Best disease.

 

Visual evoked potential (Option D): Visual evoked potential (VEP) evaluates optic nerve conduction and is mainly used for optic neuritis, demyelinating disorders, and optic neuropathies. It does not help in diagnosing Best disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about viscoelastic substances?

choices.text:
Cause mechanical injury to corneal endothelium
B) Prevents Anterior Chamber from collapsing during crucial steps like capsulorrhexis and IOL placement
C) It is inert and can be left behind after surgery
D) Silicone oil, perfluoropropane, and sodium hexafluoride are most commonly used substances
Prevents Anterior Chamber from collapsing during crucial steps like capsulorrhexis and IOL placement
It is inert and can be left behind after surgery
Silicone oil, perfluoropropane, and sodium hexafluoride are most commonly used substances

questions.solution:
Viscoelastic substances are ophthalmic agents used in anterior segment surgeries like cataract surgery (phacoemulsification) to maintain anterior chamber stability, protect intraocular tissues, and facilitate intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.

 

Cause mechanical injury to corneal endothelium (Option A): Viscoelastic substances are protective, not damaging, to the corneal endothelium. Some high-viscosity viscoelastics (e.g., Healon GV) can increase intraocular pressure if not completely removed, but they do not cause direct mechanical injury.

 

It is inert and can be left behind after surgery (Option C): Viscoelastic substances are not inert and must be removed at the end of surgery to prevent postoperative intraocular pressure (IOP) elevation. Residual viscoelastics can obstruct aqueous outflow, leading to IOP spikes.

 

Silicone oil, perfluoropropane, and sodium hexafluoride are most commonly used substances (Option D): Silicone oil, perfluoropropane (C3F8), and sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) are not viscoelastic substances; they are tamponade agents used in retinal surgeries (e.g., retinal detachment repair).

  • Commonly used ophthalmic viscoelastic devices (OVDs) include:
    • Sodium hyaluronate (Healon, ProVisc)
    • Hydroxypropyl methylcellulose (HPMC)
    • Chondroitin sulfate-based OVDs (Viscoat)

questions.text: A factory worker presented with a history of chuna (lime) exposure in both eyes a few hours ago. What is the first immediate management?

choices.text:
Take history
B) Copious irrigation of eyes
C) Check vision in both eyes
D) Check IOP and plan for surgery
Check IOP and plan for surgery

questions.solution:
• Chemical eye injuries, particularly alkali burns (such as chuna, calcium hydroxide, or lime), are ophthalmic emergencies.
  • Immediate and aggressive irrigation is the first and most critical step to minimize ocular damage.

 

Chemical Injuries
  • Eye injuries caused by chemicals range from mild irritation to vision loss.
  • Sources of Injury
    • Domestic: Ammonia, detergents, cosmetics
    • Agriculture: Fertilizers, insecticides
    • Laboratory: Acids, alkalis
    • Assaults & Warfare: Acid attacks, chemical weapons
    • Self-inflicted: Malingering or mental health conditions
  • Alkali vs. Acid Burns
    • Alkali: More severe, deeper penetration due to saponification, hygroscopic nature, and soluble compounds formation.
    • Acid: Less severe, protein coagulation forms a protective barrier.

Clinical Stages
  • Acute: Conjunctival swelling, corneal epithelial loss, iris inflammation, possible corneal sloughing and staphyloma.
  • Reparation: Epithelial regeneration, corneal vascularization, iris inflammation subsides.
  • Complications: Symblepharon, recurrent ulcers, cataracts, secondary glaucoma.

Emergency Management
  • Immediate irrigation: Use water or saline for at least 20-30 minutes or until the eye’s pH is restored. A minimum of 2 liters should be used. (Option B)
  • Mechanical removal: Gently remove any chemical particles with a cotton swab, particularly in lime burns.
  • Necrotic tissue removal: Carefully excise dead conjunctiva and corneal epithelium using a cotton swab.

Healing & Complication Prevention
  • Topical antibiotics: Use broad-spectrum antibiotics like moxifloxacin to prevent infection.
  • Topical steroids: Control inflammation and anterior uveitis. Use cautiously after two weeks to avoid hindering collagen production.
  • Cycloplegics: Alleviate pain and dilate the pupil with agents like atropine.
  • Ascorbic acid: Promote wound healing and collagen synthesis using topical and systemic Vitamin C.
  • Lubricants: Use preservative-free artificial tears to keep the eye moist and support healing.
  • Autologous serum: Use serum eye drops to provide essential growth factors for healing.
  • Sodium citrate: Stabilise neutrophils and reduce collagenase activity with topical sodium citrate.
  • Doxycycline: Inhibit collagenase activity with oral doxycycline.
  • Symblepharon Prevention:Use a glass shell or sweep a glass rod in the fornices (spaces between the eyelid and eyeball) twice daily to prevent adhesions.

Complication Management
  • Secondary glaucoma: Control intraocular pressure with beta-blockers like timolol or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors such as acetazolamide.
  • Limbal stem cell deficiency: Consider amniotic membrane or limbal stem cell transplantation.
  • Pseudopterygium: Surgically remove abnormal conjunctival growth and consider autografting or amniotic membrane transplantation.
  • Corneal opacity: Consider keratoplasty or keratoprosthesis for severe corneal damage.

Implications

Chemical injuries can cause permanent vision loss, physical disfigurement and psychological impact despite treatment.

 

Take history (Option A): Taking history is important but not the priority in an emergency. Every second matters in chemical burns, and delaying irrigation can worsen corneal damage.

 

Check vision in both eyes (Option C): Checking vision can be done after irrigation, but delaying decontamination increases ocular morbidity.

 

Check IOP and plan for surgery (Option D): Checking intraocular pressure (IOP) and planning for surgery is important after initial management. Alkali burns can cause secondary glaucoma, but irrigation takes precedence over any diagnostic steps.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby, born preterm at 33 weeks of gestation, is brought by parents with complaints of a white pupillary reflex for 2 weeks. CT revealed calcification of the globe in both eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in a preterm infant with calcification of the globe on CT scan is most likely indicative of retinoblastoma, most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.

The key features pointing to this diagnosis are:

  1. Age of presentation: Retinoblastoma typically occurs in young children, usually before 5 years of age.
  2. Leukocoria: This is the most common presenting sign of retinoblastoma, often described as a white pupillary reflex.
  3. Fundus examination: A white, elevated mass in the retina is characteristic of retinoblastoma.

The most specific histopathological feature of retinoblastoma is Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, which are rosettes with a central lumen as shown in the diagram below.

 

Histopathology and Diagnostic modalities for Retinoblastoma

 

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific)- These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes - These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Genetic Testing

RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

 

Retinopathy of Prematurity (Option A): While ROP is common in preterm infants, especially those born before 32 weeks gestation, it typically presents with abnormal blood vessel development in the retina.

  • Leukocoria in ROP is usually due to retinal detachment or scarring, not calcification.
  • ROP is stage-based and does not typically show calcifications on CT unless complicated by retinal detachment.

 

Glaucoma (Option C): Congenital glaucoma may cause enlarged corneas and optic nerve damage, but it does not usually present with white pupillary reflex or calcification.

 

Congenital Cataract (Option D): Congenital cataracts can also cause leukocoria, but they typically do not show calcification on CT. Cataracts are characterized by lens opacity and not calcification within the globe.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of bilateral sudden painless loss of vision?
questions.solution:
• Diabetic retinopathy often develops in stages, with initial mild symptoms that may progress to sudden vision loss due to complications.
  • Bilateral sudden painless loss of vision can be caused by diabetic retinopathy, particularly in its proliferative form, where there is a sudden onset of vision loss due macular edema, or retinal detachment.
  • Diabetic retinopathy affects both eyes and can lead to significant vision impairment if left untreated.

 

Clinical Features of Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR):

  • Includes all features of preproliferative diabetic retinopathy or severe NPDR: Multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion along with neovascularization.

 

  • Neovascularization (2 types):
    • Neovascularization of the Disc (NVD): Arises within 1 disc diameter of the optic nerve from the optic nerve head.
    • Neovascularization Elsewhere (NVE): Arises more than 1 disc diameter from the optic nerve, along the large vessels.
    • Appears adjacent to areas of capillary closure and the accompanying fibrous tissue varies in extent.
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Irregular expanding hyperfluorescence.
  • Severe Vision Loss: Result in vision as poor as hand movements or worse due to severe vitreous hemorrhage or retinal detachment.
  • Fibrovascular Tissue Formation:
    • Formed due to condensation of connective tissue around the new vessels.
    • Lie flat on the retina or attach to the posterior vitreous face.
    • Can lead to vitreous traction, retinal separation, and blood vessel tearing.
    • The most common cause of vitreous hemorrhage in adults.
  • Rubeosis Iridis: Neovascularization of iris.
  • Neovascular glaucoma: Occurs due neovascularization of anterior segment angle.

 

Acute congestive glaucoma (Option A): Acute congestive glaucoma is typically associated with painful loss of vision and is more often unilateral. The condition involves a sudden increase in intraocular pressure, causing symptoms such as severe eye pain, nausea, and vomiting.

 

Keratoconus (Option C): Keratoconus can lead to progressive vision loss due to the distortion of the cornea, but it usually presents gradually, not suddenly, and typically affects one eye more than the other initially.

 

Iridocyclitis (Option D): Iridocyclitis (anterior uveitis) is usually associated with pain, photophobia, and redness in the affected eye. It does not cause sudden, painless loss of vision in both eyes.

questions.text: Which of the following is the common cause for diarrhea and dehydration in children:
questions.solution:
The symptoms of watery diarrhoea, vomiting, and fever, especially in a young child, strongly suggest rotavirus infection, a leading cause of pediatric gastroenteritis. Rotavirus is distinctively wheel-shaped, making it the expected appearance in stool analysis for this clinical presentation.

Rotavirus

  • Leading cause of childhood diarrhoea; belongs to the Reoviridae family (the only family with double-stranded RNA).

Structure:

 

  • Size: 60–80 nm, icosahedral symmetry with a triple-layered, wheel-shaped capsid.
  • Genome: Segmented dsRNA (11 segments).
  • Proteins:
    • Structural (VP1–VP7, except VP5); VP6 is group-specific.
    • VP7 (outer capsid) and VP4 (spikes) induce neutralizing antibodies.

Classification:

  • Traditional: Seven groups (A–G), with Group A causing most human diarrhoea.

Epidemiology:

  • The major cause of pediatric gastroenteritis worldwide is outbreaks, which are common in areas with poor sanitation and seasonally in temperate zones.

Pathogenesis:

  • Transmission: Fecal-oral route.
  • Action: Infects small intestine enterocytes, causing secretory diarrhoea.
  • NSP4 protein acts as an enterotoxin, altering epithelial function.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Incubation: 1–3 days.
  • Manifestations: Vomiting, watery diarrhoea, fever, and abdominal pain. Severe dehydration risk in children.

Diagnosis:

  • Specimen: Stool collected early in the illness.
  • Tests:
    • Immunoelectron microscopy (IEM): Wheel-shaped appearance.
    • Antigen detection: ELISA, latex agglutination.
    • RT-PCR: Most sensitive method.
    • G serotype and P genotype detection via RNA typing.

Vaccines:

  • Rotavac: Live attenuated G9P[10] strain; three oral doses at 6, 10, and 14 weeks.
  • Rotarix: Live attenuated G1P[8] strain; two doses at 6 and 10 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following hepatitis virus is spread by contaminated water?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)

Family:

  • Picornaviridae family
  • Genus: Hepatovirus
  • Also known as Enterovirus-72
  • Single serotype and six genotypes (I, II, III affecting humans)

 

Genotype

Common Locations

I

Worldwide (most prevalent genotype)

II

Found in specific regions (less common)

IIIa

Predominant in India and some Asian countries

 

Viral Morphology:

  • Small, non-enveloped virus
  • Icosahedral symmetry
  • Single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome (+ssRNA)
  • Encodes four capsid proteins (VP1–VP4)

 

Transmission:

  • Fecal-oral route, especially in areas with poor sanitation
  • Spreads through direct contact, contaminated food or water, fomites, or person-to-person contact with inadequate hygiene
  • Rare transmission through blood transfusion and sexual contact
  • In India, over 90% of individuals are seropositive by age 10, indicating widespread early exposure

 

Epidemiology:

  • Similarities with poliovirus (fecal-oral transmission)
  • Seasonal trends, peaking during warmer months due to increased exposure to contaminated food

 

Cultivability:

Can be cultivated in specific cell cultures, such as human or primate diploid cell lines (unlike most hepatitis viruses)

questions.text: Which of the following option is wrong about Ascaris lumbricoides?

choices.text: Unembryonated fertilized egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil.

questions.solution:
Ascaris lumbricoides does not cause recital prolapse.

 

Life Cycle of Ascaris
  • Host: Humans only.
  • Infective Form: Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.
  • Transmission: Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water. (Option C)

 

Life Cycle Phases

Migratory Phase
  • L2 larvae hatch, molt to L3, penetrate the intestine and travel to the lungs via the heart.
  • In the lungs, they molt to L4, migrate to the pharynx, and are swallowed back into the intestine.

Intestinal Phase
  • L4 larvae become adult worms in the small intestine.
  • Females lay fertilized eggs in feces; unfertilized eggs may also be laid.

Development in Soil
  • Fertilized eggs become infective embryonated (L2 larvae) in 2 weeks under suitable conditions.
  • Unfertilized eggs disintegrate and are non-infective.
  • Embryonated eggs can survive for up to 15 years due to a thick eggshell and ascaroside, a resistant lipoprotein.

Pathogenesis and Clinical Features
  • Caused by the host immune response, larval migration, adult worm obstruction, and nutritional deficiencies.
  • Incubation: 60–70 days.
 

Pulmonary Phase
  • Symptoms appear within two weeks post-ingestion: cough, chest discomfort, and fever.
  • Severe cases may lead to Loeffler’s syndrome, characterized by eosinophilic pneumonia and transient lung infiltrates.
 

Intestinal Phase
  • Most infections are asymptomatic, but malnutrition and growth retardation can occur, particularly in children <5 years.
  • Complications include intestinal obstruction, perforation, intussusception, or volvulus in older children.

Extraintestinal Complications

Larger worms may obstruct the biliary tree, causing biliary colic or pancreatitis.

Allergic Reactions

Reactions such as fever, urticaria, angioedema, and conjunctivitis may arise due to toxins released by adult worms.

questions.text: Covid-19 can be prevented through all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ivermectin is not used in the treatment of COVID-19.

SARS-CoV-2

 

  • Type: Virus, classified as a coronavirus.
  • Size: Approximately 120 nm with helical symmetry.
  • Components:
    • Nucleocapsid: Positive-sense single-stranded RNA (~30 kb) surrounded by nucleocapsid protein (N).
    • Envelope: Lipoprotein structure with embedded proteins, host-derived.
  • Structural Proteins:
    • Spike Protein (S): Facilitates attachment to host cells; contains two subunits:
      • S1 Subunit: Contains receptor-binding domain (RBD) for host cell attachment.
      • S2 Subunit: Mediates virus-cell membrane fusion.
    • Membrane Glycoprotein (M): Most abundant, provides shape to the virus.
    • Envelope Protein (E): Transmembrane protein with ion channel activity.
  • Non-structural Proteins: Include enzymes like RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) crucial for viral replication.

 

Pathogenesis of COVID-19

Host Cell Entry
  • Binding: Spike glycoprotein (S) attaches to angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 (ACE-2) receptors on lung type II alveolar cells.
  • Cleavage: Host proteases (e.g., TMPRSS2) cleave the spike protein, facilitating viral entry via the endosomal pathway.

Initial Inflammatory Response
  • Influenza-like Illness (ILI): Infection of the pharyngeal epithelium initiates ILI.

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
  • Damage to Alveolar Cells: Impaired type II alveolar cells decrease pulmonary surfactant, causing alveolar collapse and fluid retention.
  • Cytokine Storm: Increased immune cytokine release leads to:
    • Tissue damage and necrosis.
    • Impaired gas exchange and hypoxia.
    • Endothelial damage and microvascular thrombosis.
    • Pulmonary oedema and ground-glass opacities on imaging.
    • Fibrosis and respiratory failure.

Multiorgan Failure
  • Elevated cytokines may harm other organs, resulting in sepsis, septic shock, and acute kidney/cardiac injury.

Risk Factors for Severe Disease
  • Demographics: Age > 60 years.
  • Comorbidities: Diabetes, hypertension, COPD, CKD and cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is the test used for antibiotic sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (AST) helps clinicians choose appropriate antibiotics by determining which drugs are effective against the specific bacteria causing the infection. AST is conducted only on pathogenic bacteria isolated from clinical specimens, not on commensal bacteria.

 

MIC is defined as the lowest concentration of an antibiotic that prevents visible growth of the microorganism in a standardized growth medium.

Minimal Inhibitory Concentration (MIC)
  • The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits the growth of the pathogen in the medium.

Minimal Bactericidal Concentration (MBC)
  • The lowest concentration of antibiotic that kills the bacteria in a medium.

Methods
  • Dilution method
  • Disc diffusion method
  • E-Test (combo of first two methods)
  • Automated methods

 

Clinical significance of MIC:

  • If MIC > breakpoint value, then there is resistance
  • If MIC < breakpoint value, then there is sensitivity

 

The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that kills the bacteria (Option C): This definition describes the minimal bactericidal concentration (MBC), not the MIC.

 

Learning Objective:

  • Minimal inhibitory concentration(MIC): The lowest concentration of the antibiotic inhibits the pathogen's growth in the medium.
  • Minimal bactericidal concentration(MBC): The lowest concentration of antibiotic that kills the bacteria in a medium.

questions.text: Choose the correct sterilization method for wire loop used in bacterial cultue.

choices.text: Heat until the wire becomes red

questions.solution:
Wire loop is heated until the wire becomes red in colour, indicating sterilisation.

 

Sterilisation technique

Control method

1. Hot air oven

c. Bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis spores

2. Autoclave

d. Geobacillus stearothermophilus spores

3. Membrane filtration

b. Serratia marcescens

4.Ionizing Radiation

a. Bacillus pumilus

 

These control methods are biological indicators used to check the effectiveness of the sterilisation method.

 

  • Spores of bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis are used as a control method for hot air ovens and ethylene oxide sterilisation (used mainly for heart-lung machines).
  • Spores of geobacillus stearothermophilus are used as a control method for autoclave and plasma sterilisation.
  • Bacillus globigi is also used as a control method for ethylene oxide sterilisation.
  • Serratia marcescens and Brevundimonas diminuta are used as control methods for membrane filters.

questions.text: A gardener with lymphogranulomatous lesions presented to the OPD, Identify the organism shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Sporothrix schenckii in the yeast phase is often described as cigar-shaped, which helps differentiate it from other fungi.

 

Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features

Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.

Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.

Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.

Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
 
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.
 

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

 

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common foot infection caused due to walking barefoot?
questions.solution:
Madurella mycetomatis is a common fungal agent associated with eumycetoma and is characterized by the presence of thick-walled grains and hyphae in microscopic examination.

Mycetoma (Madura Foot)

  • Definition: Chronic granulomatous infection with subcutaneous masses, draining sinuses, and grains in exudates
  • Types:
    • Eumycetoma (fungal)
    • Actinomycetoma (bacterial) 

 

 

Clinical Presentation

  • Initial Lesion:
    • Painless nodule; may be asymptomatic for years
  • Progression:
    • Leads to swelling, ulceration, and pus discharge from sinuses containing grains
  • Complications:
    • Severe deformities, osteomyelitis, potential amputation due to extensive tissue damage

Microscopic Examination

Type

Causative Agents

Microscopic Features

Eumycetoma

Madurella mycetomatis, Curvularia lunata, Scedosporium spp., Acremonium spp.

 

Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white).

 

Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils.

Actinomycetoma

Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia spp.

Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology.

 

Diagnostic Techniques

  • Biopsy and Culture:
    • Tissue biopsy for visualization of pathogens.
    • Culturing exudates for specific organism identification.
    • Special stains to differentiate fungal and bacterial infections.
  • Imaging Studies:
    • X-rays and MRI to assess bone involvement in advanced cases.

Treatment

Type

Treatment Approach

Eumycetoma

Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates.

Actinomycetoma

Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to grow Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
LJ medium used to grow tuberculosis.

 

TB lab investigations:

Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
  • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
  • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
  • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
  • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
  • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
  • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

questions.text: Which among the given is a gram positive cocci in chains causing necrotising fascitis?
questions.solution:

Complications

Rash, fever, strawberry tongue

Penicillin, erythromycin

Rheumatic fever, septicemia

Impetigo- Non-bullous

Clinical presentation, culture of lesions

Topical mupirocin, oral antibiotics

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Erysipelas

Penicillin, erythromycin

Bacteremia, septicemia

Cellulitis

Necrotizing Fasciitis

Severe pain, swelling, fever, rapid spread of infection

questions.text: A 2-year old child with history of diarrhoea presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, hematuria. Which of the following can be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Escherichia coli 0157:H7 presents with diarrhoea presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, hematuria.

 

Types of E. coli

Type of E. coli

Clinical Features

Toxins Produced

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)

Watery diarrhea, Abdominal cramps, Low-grade fever, Nausea and vomiting

Most common cause of traveller's diarrhea

Causes watery diarrhea through

attachment via CFA (colonization factor antigen) and toxin production (heat-labile toxin ↑cAMP, heat-stable toxin ↑cGMP).

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC)

Watery diarrhea (especially in infants), Fever, Vomiting, Dehydration

None (mechanism involves attaching and effacing lesions)

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)

Bloody diarrhea, Severe abdominal cramps, Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

Shiga-like toxins/Verocytotoxin

Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC)

Watery diarrhea followed by dysentery-like symptoms, Fever, Severe abdominal pain

None (mechanism involves cell invasion and intracellular multiplication)

Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC)

Persistent watery diarrhea (duration > 14 days), Abdominal pain, Nausea, Low-grade fever

Plasmid-encoded toxin (PET)

I"stacked-brick" pattern of bacterial aggregation when adhering to HEp-2 cells.

Diffuse-adhering E. coli (DAEC)

Watery diarrhea (usually mild), Abdominal cramps, Low-grade fever

None (mechanism involves diffuse adherence to epithelial cells)

 

Clinical Features of E. coli Infections

  1. Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)
    • E. coli accounts for a significant majority of UTIs.
    • Approximately 5-7% of pregnant women may have asymptomatic bacteriuria, which can lead to symptomatic infections later.
    • P pili-positive E. coli strains are generally uropathogenic.
  2. Diarrhea
    • Various types of E. coli can lead to different forms of diarrhea, ranging from watery to bloody.
  3. Pyogenic Infections
    • E. coli can cause peritonitis and abscesses.
    • It is also an important cause of neonatal meningitis.
  4. Septicemia
    • Bloodstream invasion can lead to septic shock and systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).

Granules
