questions.text: All of the following are cold sterilization methods except?
questions.solution:
Autoclave is heat sterilization of 121•*15min*15psi.

 

 

  • An autoclave is a sterilisation technique that uses moist heat at a temperature > 100oC.
  • The autoclave (steam steriliser) works on the principle of steam production under pressure.
  • When this steam meets a cooler surface, it condenses, transferring its heat to that surface. The process continues until the surface temperature matches that of the steam.
  • The resulting condensed water provides moist heat, effectively killing microbes on the materials by protein denaturation.
  • Its temperature settings are 121oC for 15 minutes at 15 psi pressure.
  • Materials that can be sterilised include linen, surgical instruments(non-sharps only), laboratory ware, pharmaceuticals, suture material except catgut(cold sterilisation) and culture media except egg and serum containing media(inspissation).
  • Sterilisation control indicator - Geobacillus stearothermophilus

 

Types of Autoclaves in Healthcare:

  • Laboratory autoclaves
  • Hospital dressing sterilisers
  • Instrument sterilisers
  • Rapid cooling sterilisers

questions.text: DOC for fasciola hepatica?
questions.solution:
Triclabendazole is DOC for fasciola hepatica.

 

Fasciola hepatica


Fasciola hepatica, commonly known as the liver fluke, is a parasitic trematode (flatworm) that primarily infects the livers of various mammals, including humans. It causes the disease fascioliasis, leading to liver damage, biliary obstruction, and inflammatory reactions.

 

Morphology

Adult Fluke:

 

 

  • Shape: Leaf-shaped, flat, and broad.
  • Size: Approximately 2-3 cm in length and 1 cm in width.
  • Color: Typically brown or grey.
  • Distinctive Features:
    • Cone-shaped anterior end.
    • Two suckers, an oral sucker at the front and a ventral sucker close to it, used for attachment to host tissues.
    • The fluke’s body is covered by a tegument (a protective outer layer) with spines aiding in attachment.

 

Eggs:

 

 

  • Size: Large, oval, and approximately 130-150 µm in length.
  • Color: Yellowish-brown.
  • Characteristics:
    • Each egg has an operculum (a lid-like structure) at one end, which opens to release the miracidium (the larval stage).
    • Eggs are unembryonated when passed out in feces.

 

Life Cycle

 

 

  1. Eggs in Water
  • Eggs are expelled in the feces of infected mammals (definitive hosts).
  • Under suitable environmental conditions, miracidia are released from eggs after 9–15 days.
  1. Infection of Snails (Intermediate Host)
  • Miracidia penetrate specific freshwater snails, such as Lymnaea spp.
  • Inside the snail, they progress through stages: sporocyst, redia, and eventually cercaria.
  1. Release and Encystment
  • Cercariae exit the snail and encyst on aquatic vegetation, transforming into metacercariae, the infective stage.
  1. Infection of Mammals (Definitive Host)
  • Mammals, including humans, become infected by consuming contaminated water or vegetation with metacercariae.
  • In the duodenum, metacercariae excyst, penetrate the intestinal wall, migrate to the liver, and lodge in the bile ducts, maturing into adult flukes.

 

Clinical Presentation

Acute Phase (Invasive or Hepatic Stage):

  • Duration: Begins about 2-3 weeks post-infection and may last for several months.
  • Symptoms:
    • Fever, right upper quadrant abdominal pain.
    • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and occasionally jaundice.
    • Nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
    • Eosinophilia (elevated eosinophil count in blood).

Chronic Phase (Biliary Stage):

  • Duration: Occurs months to years post-infection.
  • Symptoms:
    • Biliary colic, obstructive jaundice, and cholangitis (inflammation of the bile ducts).
    • Gallbladder symptoms, liver abscesses, and secondary bacterial infections in severe cases.
    • Possible fibrosis of the bile ducts with prolonged infection.

 

Investigations

  1. Serology:
    • ELISA for detection of anti-Fasciola antibodies (sensitive in both acute and chronic infections).
    • Immunoblotting can also confirm the diagnosis.
  2. Stool Examination:
    • Microscopic detection of eggs in stool samples; however, eggs are typically not present in the acute phase and may be difficult to detect in chronic cases.
  3. Imaging:
    • Ultrasound: Useful in detecting hepatobiliary abnormalities such as bile duct dilation or liver abscesses.
    • CT/MRI: May show liver lesions or track the migration of larvae in the liver.
  4. Blood Tests:
    • Eosinophilia is common in the acute phase.
    • Liver function tests: Elevated liver enzymes, especially in chronic disease.

 

Management

Antiparasitic Treatment:

  • Triclabendazole: The drug of choice, effective against both adult and larval stages. Dosage: Oral dose of 10-12 mg/kg, with a repeat dose after 12 hours if needed.

Alternative Medications:

  • Bithionol: Sometimes used if triclabendazole is unavailable.

questions.text: TRUE about cryptococcus
questions.solution:
Cryptococcus occurs when CD4<350

 

 

  • The India ink stain (A type of negative stain) is specifically used to visualize the capsule surrounding Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF samples.
  • A clear halo around the yeast cells indicates the presence of the capsule, which is an important virulence factor.
  • Urease test positive
  • Maltese cross appearance under polarising microscope

  • Cryptococcus Spp.

    Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

    Capsule

    Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis .

    Serotypes

    A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

    B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

    Virulence factors
    • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.
    • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
    • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

    Risk of infection

    Immunocompromised States:

    • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

    Geographic Location:

    • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

    Environmental Exposure:

    • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.
     

    Management of cryptococcosis

    Microscopy

    • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
    • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

    Culture
    • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
    • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
    • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

     

    Antigen detection tests

    Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

    Treatment

    • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
    • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
    • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
    • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: CD4 T-cell activation is done by?
questions.solution:
CD4 T-cell activation is done by MHC II.

 

Feature

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expression

Found on almost all nucleated cells

Found mainly on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as macrophages, dendritic cells, and B-cells

Antigen Source

Presents intracellular antigens (e.g., viral or tumor proteins)

Presents extracellular antigens (e.g., bacterial peptides)

Interacts With

CD8+ T-cells (cytotoxic T-cells)

CD4+ T-cells (helper T-cells)

Main HLA Genes

HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C

HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, HLA-DR

Structure

Consists of one α (heavy) chain and β2-microglobulin;

peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and α2

Consists of α and β chains; peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and β1 domains

Function

Identifies and helps eliminate infected or malignant cells by presenting endogenous antigens to CD8+ T-cells

Activates immune response by presenting exogenous antigens to CD4+ T-cells

Peptide Length

Presents shorter peptides (8-10 amino acids)

Presents longer peptides (10-30 amino acids)

 

The antigen is presented by MHC Class I molecules to CD8+ T-cells, leading to cytotoxic T-cell-mediated destruction (Option A): MHC Class I molecules present intracellular antigens to CD8+ T-cells, not CD4+ T-cells. MHC I is not primarily involved in antibody-mediated autoimmune diseases like myasthenia gravis, which involve MHC Class II.

 

MHC Class I molecules are found only on professional antigen-presenting cells, which present the antigen to helper T-cells (Option C): MHC Class I molecules are found on all nucleated cells, not just APCs. Additionally, MHC I interacts with CD8+ T-cells rather than helper T-cells (CD4+). The statement here mischaracterizes both the distribution and the function of MHC Class I molecules.

 

MHC Class II molecules are present on all nucleated cells and help in presenting intracellular antigens (Option D): MHC Class II is restricted to antigen-presenting cells, not all nucleated cells, and presents extracellular antigens, not intracellular ones. In autoimmune reactions, extracellular antigens are generally presented by MHC II to CD4+ T-cells, which is key to the autoantibody production pathway in myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Field test for malaria?
questions.solution:
Hrp 2/Card test is quick and easy test which is used as field test for malaria.

 

  • The gold standard test used for the diagnosis of malaria is microscopy using the Romanowsky stain.
  • This method allows direct visualisation of malaria parasites within red blood cells, providing information about the species, parasite density, and stage of development.
  • It is highly specific and widely used, especially in resource-limited settings.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF MALARIA

Microscopy (Gold standard)
  • Thick smear - for rapid detection of malarial parasite
    • Quantification is done under an oil immersion lens
      • + - 1 to 10 parasites per 100-thick film field
      • ++ - 11 to 100 parasites per 100 thick film field
      • +++ - 10 to 10 per thick film field
      • ++++ - more than 10 per thick film field
    • At least 200 oil immersion fields should be examined before a film is declared negative.
    • It can be used for the detection of malarial parasites as low as 20 parasites / μL
 
  • Thin smear - for determination of plasmodium species

 
  • Stains used - Romanowsky stain (Leishman, Giemsa or JSB stain)

Quantitative buffy coat test
  • RBCs with parasites are less dense; thus, concentrate just below the buffy coat of WBC on top of the RBC column
  • Acridine orange is used to induce fluorescence on the parasite, giving a fluorescent greenish-yellow appearance on a red background
  • Microscopic examination of a smear made using the buffy coat is done.

Kawamoto fluorescence microscopy

  • Fluorescent dye like acridine orange or benzothiocarboxy purine is used to stain the parasite inside the RBC
  • Parasite DNA is stained fluorescent green, and cytosol RNA is stained red
  • The slide is examined under the fluorescent microscope
  • Used for mass screening in field laboratory

Rapid antigen detection test

  • Immunochromatography is done using monoclonal antibody directed against the parasite antigen

Parasite F test

  • Monoclonal antibody is used to detect histidine-rich protein 2 (HRP-2), which is produced by asexual stages of plasmodium falciparum
    • High sensitivity and specificity
    • Can detect low parasitemia (40 parasite / μL of blood)
    • Can detect only the asexual stage of plasmodium falciparum

Dual antigen test
  • Detects Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) and Plasmodium falciparum histidine-rich protein (PfHRP-2)
  • pLDH is produced by trophozoites and gametocytes of all plasmodium spp.
  • PfHRP-2 is produced only by the asexual stage of Plasmodium falciparum.

Molecular method

  • PCR: Used for species determination and detection of drug resistance.
  • DNA probe: Highly sensitive and can detect less than 10 parasites / μL of blood.

questions.text: Which of the following does not distinguish Psoriasis from other arthropathies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diarrhoea

Explanation:

Diarrhea is not a distinguishing feature of psoriatic arthritis; it is more commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)-related arthritis.

CASPAR Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA):

To classify a patient as having PsA, they must have inflammatory joint disease (affecting joints, spine, or entheses) plus ≥3 of the following 5 criteria:

  1. Evidence of Psoriasis (Any one of the following):
    • Current psoriasis
    • Personal history of psoriasis
    • Family history of psoriasis
  2. Psoriatic nail dystrophy (Option C ruled out)
  3. Negative Rheumatoid Factor (RF)
  4. Dactylitis (Current or past history) (Option B ruled out)
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

Enthesitis (Option C): which is inflammation of tendons and ligaments, though not part of CASPAR criteria for PsA, is commonly found in PsA.

 

Note: Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative polyarthritis with erosive arthritis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a great toe infection. She had a significant discoloration with a subungual hyperkeratosis that caused surface changes. She was suspected of onychomycosis. Which is the topical drug given in toenail onychomycosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tavaborole
 

Explanation:

  • Tavaborole is a topical oxaborole antifungal specifically approved for onychomycosis of the toenails.
  • It inhibits fungal leucyl-tRNA synthetase, disrupting protein synthesis.
  • Onychomycosis is the fungal infection of the toenail (Onymychosis) or Tinea Unguium.
  • Clinically, onychomycosis presents with various manifestations, including
    • Discoloration of the nails (yellow, brown, or white),
    • Thickening of the nail plate,
    • Subungual hyperkeratosis (build-up of keratin debris under the nail),
    • Onycholysis (separation of the nail plate from the nail bed),
    • Nail dystrophy (deformation of the nail)
  • Diagnosis: typically involves microscopic examination using KOH and fungal culture of nail clippings.
  • Treatment:
    • Oral antifungals such as terbinafine and itraconazole are often preferred.
    • Nail lacquers such as ciclopirox (applied daily) olamine and amirolfine (applied weekly) are also used as topical agents to treat onychomycosis.

The table below describes the types of onychomycosis

Distal lateral subungual onychomycosis

Most common

Primarily affecting the distal & lateral portions of the nail

Proximal subungual onychomycosis

Seen in individuals with HIV

The proximal portion of the nail plate

Superficial white onychomycosis

  

Characterized by the presence of white, crumbly material on the surface of the nail, which can be easily scrapped off

Total dystrophic onychomycosis

  

Characterized by extensive involvement of the nail plate, leading to complete destruction & deformity of the nail

Itraconazole (Option A): Oral antifungal – Used for onychomycosis but given systemically, not topically.

Griseofulvin (Option C): Oral antifungal – Primarily used for dermatophytosis; less effective for toenail infections.

Caspofungin (Option D): Echinocandin antifungal – Used for systemic fungal infections like invasive candidiasis, not for onychomycosis.

questions.text: Which organism is not associated with urethritis in men?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gardnerella vaginalis

Explanation:

 

Gardnerella vaginalis is primarily associated with bacterial vaginosis (BV) in women and does not commonly cause urethritis in men.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option A):

  • A gram-negative diplococcus that causes gonococcal urethritis, characterized by purulent discharge and dysuria.

 

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option B):

  • A flagellated protozoan causing non-gonococcal urethritis, often presenting with mild discharge and dysuria.
  • It is detected by wet mount microscopy or NAAT.

 

Mycoplasma genitalium (Option C):

  • A small, cell wall-lacking bacterium responsible for persistent or recurrent non-gonococcal urethritis.
  • It is difficult to culture and is diagnosed using NAAT.

questions.text: What is the rate of increase in head circumference in infants at the first 3 months of age?
questions.solution:
At birth, head circumference is around 33-35 cm. It increases approximately by 2 cm per month for the first 3 months, by 1 cm per month between 3 and 6 months, and by 0.5 cm per month for next 6 months.

Maximum head circumference is measured from occipital protuberance posteriorly to the supra orbital ridge anteriorly using cross tape method.

 

  • At birth, head circumference is more than chest circumference by 2.5 cm
  • At age of 1 year head circumference is equal to chest circumference
  • After 1 year head circumference is lesser than chest circumference

questions.text:
A 5-year-old child presents with symptoms of mild to moderate dehydration. You are evaluating the clinical signs to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following combinations is true for some dehydration in this child?
 


	Decreased urine output
	Lethargy
	Delayed skin pinch
	Sunken eyeballs
questions.solution:
Signs of some dehydration include increased heart rate and decreased urine output, indicating a depletion in intravascular space. Additional symptoms may include irritability, restlessness, sunken eyes, no tear production, dry mucous membranes, and slightly delayed skin pinch test (<2 sec).

 

Whereas, lethargy is not seen in some dehydration; rather, it is a feature of severe dehydration.

 

Assessment and Classification of Dehydration in Children:

 

Sign/Symptom

No Dehydration

Some Dehydration

Severe Dehydration

Mental status

Alert

Irritable/restless

Lethargic/unconscious

Loss of body weight

<3%

3- 9%

>9%

Thirst

Normal

Increased

Unable to drink

Eyes

Normal

Slightly sunken

Very sunken

Tears

Present

Decreased

Absent

Mouth

Moist

Dry

Parched

Skin turgor

Normal (Immediate recoil)

Slow recoil (2-3sec)

Very slow recoil (>3sec)

Capillary refill

Normal (<2sec)

Prolonged (2-3sec)

Prolonged (>3sec)

Urine output

Normal

Decreased

Minimal

 

Treatment of Dehydration in Children:

Rehydration:

  • Plan A: For no dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool
    • < 2 years: 50-100 ml of ORS administered.
    • 2-10 years: 100-200 ml of ORS administered.
    • >10 years: As much ORS as a child wants.
  • Plan B: For some dehydration. The amount of ORS administered is 75ml/kg of body weight
  • Plan C: For severe dehydration. Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as IV fluids.

Age

First 30 ml/kg in

Next 70 ml/kg in

Total 100 ml/kg in

<12 months

1 hour

5 hours

6 hours

>12 months

30 min

2.5 hours

3 hours






 

Nutrition:

  • Continue breastfeeding
  • Reintroduce age-appropriate diet early
  • Avoid fatty foods and simple sugars

Zinc Supplementation:

  • <6 months: 10 mg/day
  • >6 months: 20 mg/day

Medications:

  • Antibiotics: Use judiciously, mainly for severe bacterial cases
  • Ondansetron (for vomiting)
  • Avoid antimotility agents

Probiotics:

  • It may be beneficial, especially for rotavirus

 

ORS Composition (WHO standard):

Constituent

mmol/L

Sodium

75

Glucose

75

Potassium

20

Chloride

65

Total osmolarity

245

questions.text: Which of the following is the ideal maintenance fluid for pediatric patients?
questions.solution:
• The preferred fluid for fluid correction in pediatric patients is 5% dextrose and N saline (DNS). Moreover, a maintenance dose of potassium, with 1ml of KCl per 100ml, is also added to the solution.
  • DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is used in children as a maintenance fluid because:
  • Prevents Hypoglycemia: Provides around 17 calories/ 100ml of 5%D as energy, crucial for children with higher metabolic rates. It also prevents ketone production and minimises protein degradation.
  • Maintains Fluid and Electrolyte Balance: Sodium chloride in DNS preserves extracellular fluid volume and prevents dehydration.
  • Isotonic Solution: Stabilizes intravascular volume without causing fluid shifts.

 

Hypotonic fluids like N/2 and N/4 saline (Option A, C, D) can cause hyponatraemia and hemolysis. Hence Isotonic fluids with 5% dextrose are preferred as maintenance fluids in children

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought with watery eyes and photophobia. All of the following conditions can be the cause of these symptoms, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Congenital NLD blockage

Explanation:

Symptoms in the stem:

  • Watery eyes (epiphora)

  • Photophobia

In a 3-month-old, the key is photophobia — this suggests corneal irritation or raised intraocular pressure.

Congenital nasolacrimal duct (NLD) blockage causes epiphora (watery eyes) but NO photophobia, since cornea is unaffected.

Congenital glaucoma (Option A):

  • Classic triad: epiphora, photophobia, blepharospasm.

  • Due to increased IOP causing corneal edema.

  • Causes watery eyes + photophobia.

Congenital entropion (Option C): Inward turning of eyelids → lashes rub cornea → epiphora + photophobia.

Herpes simplex keratitis (Option D): Even in infants, this viral infection of the cornea can cause significant inflammation and ulceration. The corneal irritation results in redness, pain, watery eyes, and severe photophobia

questions.text: 10-year-old child, treated with antibiotics for follicular tonsillitis, presents with periorbital edema. Blood work reveals eosinophilia, and urine microscopy shows WBC casts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of eosinophilia along with WBC casts in the urine of a patient after consuming a course of antibiotics indicates a potential diagnosis of allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN).

 

Pyelonephritis (Option A), Glomerulonephritis (Option C), and IgA nephritis (Option D) do not exhibit eosinophilic casts in the urine.

 

Causes of Eosinophiluria:

  • Atheroembolic kidney disease
    • Acute kidney injury due to fragmentation of atherosclerotic plaque while performing coronary angiography causes fragments to get trapped in the renal artery.
    • Renal function tests are deranged, post coronary angiography, and there is the presence of purpura all over the body of the patient.
    • Development of gangrene of toes post angiography.
  • Allergic interstitial nephritis
    • Acute kidney injury secondary to antibiotic intake
  • Schistosomiasis

questions.text:
Which of the following are the components of Downe’s score?


	Respiratory rate
	Feeding
	Grunting
	Cyanosis
questions.solution:
Downe’s score is used to quantify respiratory distress in the term neonate.

Respiratory rate, grunting, and cyanosis are components of Downe’s score. Scoring is done every half an hour and charted.

 

Feeding (Options A, C and D) is not a component of Downe's score.

 

Components of Downe’s score

Downe’s score (for term neonates)

0

1

2

Cyanosis

Absent

Present in room air

Present at FiO ≥ 40%

Air entry

Normal

Decreased

Barely audible

Respiratory rate

<60/min

60-80/min

>80/min

Grunt

Absent

Audible only with

a stethoscope

Audible without a stethoscope

Retractions

None

Mild

Severe

Interpretations:

  • Maximum score = 10; Minimum score = 0
  • Severe respiratory distress in a term baby 7 score

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11

 

Explanation:

  • HLA-DQ6 and HLA-DQ11 are not associated with celiac disease.
  • In contrast, HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 are the primary genetic markers found in almost all individuals with celiac disease.
  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion in genetically predisposed individuals.
  • It primarily affects the proximal small intestine, with the duodenum most commonly involved.
  • In some cases, it extends to the jejunum, causing more severe symptoms.

Pathophysiology:

  • Genetics: HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 are associated with celiac disease.
  • Immune Response: Gluten ingestion triggers inflammation in the small intestine

Symptoms:

  • Gastrointestinal: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, vomiting, steatorrhea.
  • Extra-intestinal: Fatigue, skin rashes (dermatitis herpetiformis), weight loss, anemia, joint pain, headaches, peripheral neuropathy.
  • In Children: Delayed growth, irritability, poor weight gain, bone issues due to malabsorption.

Diagnosis:

1. Serological Testing:

  • Tissue Transglutaminase (tTG) Antibodies: Most sensitive and specific test. (Option A ruled out)
  • Anti-Endomysial Antibodies (EMA)
  • Anti-Gliadin Antibodies (AGA): Less specific. (Option B ruled out)

2. Histological Confirmation:

  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is the gold standard.
  • Histological Changes:
    • Villous Atrophy: Flattened villi.
  • Crypt Hyperplasia: Increased crypt cells.
  • Intraepithelial Lymphocytosis: Elevated lymphocytes.

3. Histological Grading (Modified Marsh Classification): (Option C ruled out)

 

Type

Definition

0

Normal duodenal biopsy

I

Normal mucosal architecture with increased intraepithelial lymphocytes

II

Hyperplastic crypts, but near normal Villi

IIIa

Hyperplastic crypts with partial villous atrophy

IIIb

Hyperplastic crypts with subtotal villous atrophy

IIIc

Hyperplastic crypts with total villous atrophy

 

Treatment:

  • Gluten-Free Diet: Lifelong, strict adherence is the only treatment.
  • Gluten-containing foods (BROW): Barley, Rye, Oats, Wheat.

Complications:

  • Malnutrition: Due to impaired absorption.
  • Osteoporosis: From poor calcium and vitamin D absorption.
  • Intestinal Lymphoma and Small Bowel Cancer: Rare but serious.
  • Increased Risk of Autoimmune Disorders: Such as Type 1 diabetes and autoimmune thyroid disease.

 

Feature

Coeliac Sprue

Whipple's Disease

Tropical Sprue

Description
  • Autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten.
  • Systemic infectious disease caused by Tropheryma whipplei.
  • Malabsorption disorder seen in tropical regions.
  • Cause often unknown, possibly infectious.

Etiology
  • Genetic predisposition (HLA-DQ2/DQ8).
  • Environmental trigger: gluten (present in wheat, barley, rye) ingestion and an immune response to gliadin, a protein in gluten.

Infection with Tropheryma whipplei, found in soil and sewage.
  • Possibly due to bacterial, fungal or coronavirus infection.

Clinical Features

Affects mainly proximal small intestine.

 

Intestinal Features:

  • Chronic diarrhea or steatorrhea.
  • Malabsorption: weight loss, vitamin deficiencies.
  • Abdominal pain, bloating.
 

Extraintestinal Features:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis (in some cases).

Affects mainly distal small intestine.

 

Intestinal Features:

  • Chronic diarrhea.
  • Malabsorption, weight loss.
  • Abdominal pain and bloating.
 

Extraintestinal Features:

  • Arthralgia (joint pain).
  • Fever.
  • Lymphadenopathy.
  • Neurological symptoms (cognitive impairment, seizures, ataxia in advanced stages, oculomasticatory myorhythmia).
  • Uveitis
  • Cardiac involvement (rare).

Affects entire small intestinal

 

Intestinal Features:

  • Chronic diarrhea.
  • Malabsorption, weight loss.
  • Abdominal pain, bloating.
 

Extraintestinal Features:

  • Anemia (often megaloblastic).

Histological Findings
 
  • Loss or flattening of intestinal villi (villous atrophy).
  • Hyperplastic crypts (crypt elongation).
  • Increased infiltration of lymphocytes, especially CD8+ T cells.
  • Increased plasma cells, lymphocytes, macrophages in lamina propria.
 
  • Villous blunting and atrophy.
  • Dense infiltration of lamina propria by macrophages containing PAS-positive granules.
  • Foamy macrophages laden with Tropheryma whipplei in various tissues (e.g., lymph nodes, CNS, synovial fluid).
 
  • Villous atrophy.
  • Crypt hyperplasia.
  • Increased inflammatory cells (similar to Celiac disease but without gliadin-specific immune response).

Investigations

Biopsy

Serologic Tests:

  • Most sensitive and most common antibody test: Anti-Tissue Transglutaminase Antibodies (Anti-tTG) - IgA and IgG
  • Most specific antibody test: Anti-Endomysial Antibodies (EMA) - IgA.
  • Anti-Deamidated Gliadin Peptide (DGP) Antibodies - IgA and IgG.
  • Anti-Gliadin Antibodies (AGA) - IgA and IgG.

Biopsy

PCR for Tropheryma whipplei DNA.

Immunohistochemistry for Tropheryma whipplei.

Biopsy

Response to Treatment: Antibiotic response helps confirm diagnosis.

Management
  • Lifelong gluten-free diet.
  • Nutritional supplementation: iron, folate, calcium, vitamin D.
  • Indications for steroids:
    • Refractory disease for 6-12 months
    • Celiac crisis
    • Lymphoma
  • Monitoring for complications

Prolonged antibiotic therapy:

  • Initially IV ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks.
  • Followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a year.
  • Tetracycline for 6 months.
  • Folate supplementation.
  • Some recommend a gluten-free diet.

Complications
  • Osteoporosis.
  • Malignancy (e.g., small bowel lymphoma).
  • Infertility.
  • Neurological complications (rare).
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Untreated disease can be fatal due to multi-organ involvement.
  • Relapses are common (especially CNS).
  • Nutritional deficiencies can lead to osteoporosis, cachexia.
  • Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12, folate).
  • Persistent malabsorption.
  • Possible relapse and chronic diarrhea.

questions.text: A patient presented with a blood pressure of 220/120 mmHg in an altered sensorium. He also had an episode of vomiting and a history of weakness on the left side of his body. Which of the following is incorrect regarding hypertensive management in this case?

choices.text: In hemorrhagic stroke, reduce the BP to less than 160/100 mmHg with antihypertensives to prevent rebleed
In hemorrhagic stroke, aggressive use of IV antihypertensive if SBP > 220
In the ER, multiple blood pressure readings should be taken before starting antihypertensive therapy
In ischemic stroke, BP should be reduced to <140/90 mmHg immediately

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) In ischemic stroke, BP should be reduced to <140/90 mmHg immediately

 

Explanation:

  • In ischemic stroke, BP should not be reduced to <140/90 mmHg immediately.
  • The correct management includes reducing the BP to <185/110 mmHg before administering thrombolytic therapy.
  • Lowering BP too aggressively could compromise cerebral perfusion, potentially worsening the ischemia and increasing infarct size.

 

Hemorrhagic Stroke:

  • BP should be lowered to <160/100 mmHg with antihypertensives to reduce the risk of rebleeding (Option A).
  • If SBP > 220 mmHg, aggressive use of IV antihypertensives is recommended (Option B).

 

Ischemic Stroke:

  • BP should only be reduced to <185/110 mmHg before thrombolysis.
  • If the BP is above this threshold and thrombolysis is considered, lowering it is necessary, but a reduction to <140/90 mmHg can worsen cerebral perfusion.

 

Emergency Management:

  • In a hypertensive emergency, multiple BP readings should be taken to ensure accurate assessment before starting antihypertensive therapy (Option C).
  • This is important to avoid over- or under-treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Renal failure

 

Explanation:

  • Renal failure, while it can occur as a consequence of microvascular injury in TTP, is not a defining feature of the disease.
  • Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) is a rare hematological disorder characterized by:
    • Thrombocytopenia (Option A)
    • Thrombosis (Option B)
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (Option C)

 

TTP vs HUS

 

Feature

Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)

Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome (HUS)

Etiology

Deficiency or antibodies to ADAMTS13 leading to platelet aggregation

Diarrhea associated with

E. coli O157:H7 or shigella

Features

Pentad

1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)

2. Thrombocytopenia (severe)

3. Renal failure,

4. Neurologic findings

5. Fever

Triad

1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)

2. Thrombocytopenia

3. Renal failure

Age Group
  • More common in adults
  • More common in children

Association
  • Often women, especially those with HIV or during pregnancy
  • Preceded by diarrhea, especially hemorrhagic diarrhea

Renal Failure
  • Not a predominant feature
  • Renal failure is a hallmark, especially in children

ADAMTS13 Activity
  • <10% ADAMTS13 activity is diagnostic
  • ADAMTS13 activity is normal, except in rare cases (Atypical HUS)

Common Precipitating Factors
  • Idiopathic
  • Infections (HIV)
  • Medications (Ticlopidine, Cyclosporine)
  • Pregnancy
  • Often follows GI infections
  • Atypical HUS has genetic/ complement involvement

Treatment
  • Plasma exchange (mainstay)
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Supportive care
  • Dialysis (in severe cases)

Relapse Rate
  • 25-45% relapse
  • Relapses can occur, but less frequent than TTP

questions.text: What is the mutation seen in Sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glu → Val (6)

 

Explanation:

  • Sickle cell anemia is a genetic disorder caused by a missense mutation in the β-globin gene.
  • This mutation replaces the normal glutamic acid (Glu) at position 6 of the β-globin chain with valine (Val).

 

  • This Glu → Val substitution leads to the formation of hemoglobin S (HbS), which tends to polymerize when deoxygenated, causing the red blood cells to become sickle-shaped.
  • These sickle-shaped cells are rigid and prone to breaking, leading to anemia and other complications.

 

Pathophysiology of Sickle cell anemia

  • HbS Polymerisation:
    • A single-nucleotide polymorphism in the β-globin gene results in the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the sixth position in the β-globin chain.
    • This mutation leads to the formation of mutated hemoglobin (HbS).
    • After deoxygenation, HbS molecules polymerize to form bundles.
    • These polymer bundles cause erythrocytes to adopt a sickle shape and also promote hemolysis of erythrocyte, releasing cell-free Hb into circulation.
  • Vaso-occlusion:
    • Sickled erythrocytes impair blood flow and aggregate with neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells, causing stasis.
    • Leads to ischemia-reperfusion (I-R) injury.
  • Endothelial Dysfunction:
    • Oxygenated Hb (Fe²⁺) depletes endothelial nitric oxide (NO), forming nitrate (NO₃⁻) and methemoglobin (Fe³⁺).
    • Free radicals are generated by NADPH oxidase, xanthine oxidase (XO), and uncoupled endothelial NO synthase (eNOS) contribute to endothelial damage and dysfunction.
    • Methemoglobin (Fe³⁺) breaks down, releasing cell-free heme, which is a major erythrocyte damage-associated molecular pattern (DAMP).
  • Sterile Inflammation:
    • Cell-free heme or ischemia-reperfusion injury triggers sterile inflammation by:
      • Generating reactive oxygen species (ROS).
      • Activating Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4).
      • Inducing neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs).
      • Releasing DAMPs, DNA, and other unidentified factors.
    • This activates the inflammasome pathway, releasing IL-1β.
    • Sterile inflammation enhances the adhesiveness of neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells.
    • This creates a cycle that promotes further vaso-occlusion.

questions.text: A female patient with type 1 DM and hypothyroidism presented with chronic oral mucocutaneous candidiasis for 5 years. She is diagnosed with autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) DM type-1 association is high

 

Explanation:

  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM) is commonly associated with APS Type 2, it is less frequently seen in APS Type 1.
  • Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome (APS) Type 1 is also known as APECED (Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy, Candidiasis, and Ectodermal Dystrophy).
  • APS Type 1 is more associated with conditions like hypoparathyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

 

Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome (APS)

  • Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome iis a group of autoimmune disorders characterized by the immune system mistakenly attacking multiple endocrine glands, leading to hormonal imbalances.
  • It is classified into two main types

Feature

APS Type 1 (APECED)

APS Type 2 (Schmidt Syndrome)

Genetic Cause

Mutation in AIRE gene (Autoimmune Regulator)

Associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4 alleles

Inheritance Pattern

Autosomal recessive

Polygenic, complex inheritance

Age of Onset

Childhood onset (Option B ruled out)

Adulthood onset (20-40 years)

Clinical Features

Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, hypoparathyroidism, addison’s disease (Options C & D ruled out)

Addison’s disease, autoimmune thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus

Other Associated Conditions

Hypogonadism, alopecia, pernicious anemia, autoimmune enteropathy, keratoconjunctivitis

Vitiligo, myasthenia gravis, pernicious anemia, celiac disease

Endocrine Glands Affected

Parathyroid, adrenal, gonads, pancreatic islets, thyroid

Adrenal, thyroid, pancreatic islets

Diagnosis

Genetic testing for AIRE mutation, endocrine function tests

Endocrine function tests, autoantibody screening

Management

Hormone replacement (calcium & vitamin D for hypoparathyroidism, hydrocortisone for Addison’s), antifungal treatment for candidiasis

Hormone replacement (thyroxine for hypothyroidism, insulin for diabetes, corticosteroids for adrenal insufficiency)

Prognosis

Progressive, can be life-threatening without early treatment

Chronic but manageable with lifelong hormone therapy

APECED: Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy-Candidiasis-Ectodermal Dystrophy

questions.text: All of the following are examples of HAGMA (High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis) except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diarrhea

 

Explanation:

  • Diarrhea is associated with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) due to excessive loss of bicarbonate through the gastrointestinal tract.
  • DKA (Diabetic Ketoacidosis), AKI (Acute Kidney Injury), and inborn errors of metabolism are examples of HAGMA, as they involve the accumulation of unmeasured acids in the blood, leading to an increased anion gap.

 

ABG Analysis

 

Parameter

Metabolic Acidosis

Metabolic Alkalosis

Respiratory Acidosis

Respiratory Alkalosis

Primary Disturbance

↓ HCO₃⁻ (Bicarbonate)

↑ HCO₃⁻ (Bicarbonate)

↑ PaCO₂ (Hypoventilation)

↓ PaCO₂ (Hyperventilation)

ABG Parameters

pH

↓ (Acidemia)

↑ (Alkalemia)

↓ (Acidemia)

↑ (Alkalemia)

HCO₃⁻ (Bicarbonate)

↓

↑

Normal or ↑

Normal or ↓

PaCO₂ (Carbon dioxide)

Normal or ↓

Normal or ↑

↑

↓

Compensation Mechanism

Respiratory: Hyperventilation (↓ PaCO₂)

Respiratory: Hypoventilation (↑ PaCO₂)

Renal: ↑ HCO₃⁻ reabsorption, ↑ H⁺ excretion

Renal: ↓ HCO₃⁻ reabsorption, ↓ H⁺ excretion

Compensation Status

Compensated

Normal pH, ↓ HCO₃⁻, ↓ PaCO₂

Normal pH, ↑ HCO₃⁻, ↑ PaCO₂

Normal pH, ↑ PaCO₂, ↑ HCO₃⁻

Normal pH, ↓ PaCO₂, ↓ HCO₃⁻

Decompensated

↓ pH, ↓ HCO₃⁻, inadequate ↓ PaCO₂

↑ pH, ↑ HCO₃⁻, inadequate ↑ PaCO₂

↓ pH, ↑ PaCO₂, inadequate ↑ HCO₃⁻

↑ pH, ↓ PaCO₂, inadequate ↓ HCO₃⁻

Common Causes

↑ Anion Gap: (Options A, C & D)

  • DKA
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)
  • Inborn errors of metabolism
 

Normal Anion Gap:

  • Diarrhea
  • Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA)
  • Vomiting
  • Diuretics
  • Antacid overuse
  • COPD
  • Respiratory depression
  • Airway obstruction
  • Anxiety
  • Pain
  • Fever
  • High altitude

Clinical Features
  • Kussmaul breathing
  • Confusion
  • Hypotension
  • Muscle cramps
  • Tetany
  • Hypokalemia
  • Headache
  • Confusion
  • Dyspnea
  • Dizziness
  • Numbness
  • Tetany

Anion Gap Formula:

Anion Gap = [(Na⁺) - (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻)]

  • Na⁺ = Sodium concentration (mEq/L)
  • Cl⁻ = Chloride concentration (mEq/L)
  • HCO₃⁻ = Bicarbonate concentration (mEq/L)

Normal AG: 8–12 mEq/L. AG > 12 indicates high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

  • A high anion gap may indicate metabolic acidosis due to conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, or renal failure.
  • A low anion gap can be seen in hypoalbuminemia or the presence of abnormal proteins.

Winter's formula

It is used to estimate the expected compensatory bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) level in metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap (HAGMA).

(Expected bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) = 24 + (1.5 × anion gap) - 8]

questions.text:
LMN (Lower Motor Neuron) lesions are associated with which of the following?


	Decrease in muscle tone
	Spastic paralysis
	Babinski positive
	Fasciculations
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 4

 

Explanation:

Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) lesions result from damage to the motor neurons in the anterior horn of the spinal cord or cranial nerve nuclei, leading to the following hallmark features.

  • Decreased muscle tone (hypotonia)
  • Fasciculations
  • Muscle atrophy
  • Absent Babinski reflex
  • Absent or reduced reflexes (hyporeflexia)
  • Flaccid paralysis

 

UMN vs LMN lesion

Category

Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) Lesion

Lesion Location

Motor cortex, connection from motor cortex to facial nucleus in pons

Facial nucleus, anywhere along CN VII

Affected Side

Contralateral

Ipsilateral

Muscles Involved

Lower muscles of facial expression

Upper and lower muscles of facial expression

Forehead Involvement

Spared, due to bilateral UMN innervation

Affected

Other Symptoms

Variable; depends on size of lesion

Incomplete eye closure (dry eyes, corneal ulceration), hyperacusis, loss of taste on anterior tongue

 

Motor Neuron Signs

UMN Lesion

LMN Lesion

Weakness

+

+

-

questions.text:
In hemolytic anemia, which of the following statements are true?


	Indirect Van den Bergh test is positive.
	Serum conjugated bilirubin is raised.
	Serum transaminases are raised.
	Urobilinogen is high.
	GGT is elevated.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 4

 

Explanation:

In hemolytic anemia, excessive destruction of red blood cells leads to the following changes

 

  • Indirect Van den Bergh test is positive (1): Hemolysis causes increased levels of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin.
    • The indirect Van den Bergh test measures this rise, making it a hallmark of hemolytic anemia.
  • Urobilinogen is high (4): Increased hemoglobin breakdown leads to more bilirubin being converted into urobilinogen in the intestines, resulting in elevated urinary urobilinogen.
  • Serum conjugated bilirubin is raised (2): Hemolysis results in an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, not conjugated bilirubin, which is associated with liver or biliary tract conditions.
  • Serum transaminases are raised (3): Raised transaminases (ALT, AST) are markers of liver damage, not hemolysis.
  • GGT is elevated (5): Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) elevation is specific to liver and biliary tract pathology and is unrelated to hemolysis.

 

Feature

Prehepatic Jaundice

Hepatic Jaundice

Posthepatic (Obstructive) Jaundice

Etiology
  • Hemolysis (e.g., hemolytic anemia, malaria)
  • Sickle cell disease
  • G6PD deficiency
  • Liver diseases (e.g., viral hepatitis, cirrhosis, alcoholic liver disease)
  • Liver tumors
  • Drug-induced liver injury
  • Bile duct obstruction (e.g., gallstones, pancreatic cancer, cholangiocarcinoma, strictures, tumors)

Mechanism
  • Increased breakdown of red blood cells
  • Excessive bilirubin production
  • Impaired bilirubin conjugation and excretion due to liver dysfunction
  • Blocked bile flow
  • Accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in bloodstream

Clinical Features
  • Yellowing of skin and sclera
  • Anemia
  • Fatigue
  • Splenomegaly
  • Yellowing of skin and sclera
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Pruritus
  • Yellowing of skin and sclera
  • Pale stools
  • Dark urine
  • Pruritus
  • Hepatomegaly

Bilirubin

Elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin

Elevated unconjugated and conjugated (direct) bilirubin
  • Elevated conjugated (direct) bilirubin

Liver Enzyme Values
  • AST, ALT: Normal or slightly elevated
  • ALP: Normal
  • GGT: Normal
  • AST, ALT: Markedly elevated
  • ALP: Elevated
  • GGT: Elevated
  • AST, ALT: Mildly elevated
  • ALP: Markedly elevated
  • GGT: Elevated

Prothrombin time (PT)

Normal Prolonged PT

Prolonged PT

Prolonged PT

Urine

Normal or slightly dark urine due to excess urobilinogen

Dark urine (due to increased conjugated bilirubin)
  • Dark urine (due to conjugated bilirubin)
  • Pale stools (due to reduced bile excretion)

 

Van den Bergh test:

Purpose: Differentiates between conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin in serum.

Principle: Based on diazotization reaction: Bilirubin reacts with diazotized sulfanilic acid to form a colored complex.

Reagents Used: Diazotized sulfanilic acid, methanol (for indirect reaction)

 

Types of Reactions:

Reaction Type

Findings

Bilirubin Type

Clinical Significance

Direct (Positive within seconds)

Immediate pink-red color in aqueous solution

Conjugated (Water-soluble)

Seen in obstructive jaundice, hepatocellular jaundice

Indirect (Delayed or requires methanol)

Pink-red color appears only after adding methanol

Unconjugated (Water-insoluble)

Seen in hemolytic jaundice, Gilbert syndrome, Crigler-Najjar syndrome

Biphasic (Both direct and indirect reaction present)

Color change seen both in aqueous and after methanol addition

Mixed (Conjugated + Unconjugated)

Seen in hepatic jaundice (e.g., viral hepatitis, cirrhosis)

questions.text: A patient has undergone an acute renal allograft transplantation. What would indicate its rejection?

choices.text: Rise of creatinine by more than 10% is suggestive of acute rejection.
Rise of creatinine by more than 5% is suggestive of acute rejection.
Serum creatinine does not rise in acute renal allograft rejection.
Any rise in serum creatinine will be suggestive of acute renal allograft rejection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Any rise in serum creatinine will be suggestive of acute renal allograft rejection.

 

Explanation:

  • After renal allograft transplantation, serum creatinine is one of the earliest and most sensitive indicators of graft dysfunction.
  • A rise in serum creatinine, even if small or unexplained, necessitates further investigation to rule out acute rejection.

 

Acute Renal Allograft Rejection

  • Acute renal allograft rejection occurs when the recipient's immune system identifies the transplanted kidney as foreign, leading to cellular or antibody-mediated immune responses that cause kidney inflammation and damage.

 

Clinical Presentation:

  • Typically occurs weeks to months post-transplant, but can occur later if immunosuppression is reduced.
  • Symptoms may include reduced urine output, graft tenderness, fever, and malaise, though not always present.
  • Any unexplained increase in creatinine should raise suspicion for acute rejection.

 

Types of Acute Rejection:

  • Cellular Rejection (T-cell Mediated): T-cells attack the graft, causing inflammation and tissue damage.
  • Antibody-Mediated Rejection (AMR): Antibodies attack the donor endothelial cells, leading to endothelial injury and microvascular thrombosis.

Confirmatory Investigation:

  • Renal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing acute rejection and determining the type of rejection.
  • Biopsy findings:
    • Cellular rejection: T-cell infiltration and inflammation.
    • AMR: Endothelial damage and microvascular inflammation.

Treatment:

  • Cellular rejection: Treated with increased immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., steroids, ATG).
  • AMR: Requires treatments like plasmapheresis, IVIG, or rituximab.

 

Type of Rejection

Hyperacute Rejection

Acute Rejection

Chronic Rejection

Acute Cellular Rejection

Acute Antibody-Mediated Rejection

Description
  • Occurs immediately after transplant.
  • Mediated by preformed antibodies against graft endothelial cells.
  • Occurs within days to weeks after transplant.
  • Mediated by CD8+ T cells and CD4+ T cells.

Antibodies bind to graft endothelial cells, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • Develops over months to years.
  • Mediated by T cells.

Timing

Minutes to hours after transplant.

Days to weeks after transplant.

Days to months after transplant.

Months to years after transplant.

Type of Hypersensitivity Reaction

Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity)

Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity)

Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity)

Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity)

Immunologic Mechanism
  • Pre-existing antibodies activate complement.
  • Causes endothelial injury and thrombosis.
  • CD8+ T cells destroy graft cells.
  • CD4+ T cells induce inflammation.
  • Antibodies against graft antigens activate complement.
  • Leads to graft inflammation.

T cell-mediated response causes graft fibrosis and dysfunction.

Treatment
  • No treatment.
  • Requires graft removal.

Immunosuppressive therapy (steroids, antithymocyte globulin).

Plasmapheresis, IVIG, rituximab, steroids.
  • No definitive treatment.
  • Supportive care and immunosuppression.

questions.text:
A lady presents with recurrent bluing of her hands, stretching of her skin, difficulty swallowing, and lung lesions. What is the pattern of ANA and the diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anti-centromere pattern, CREST

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of recurrent bluing of hands (Raynaud's phenomenon), skin tightening (sclerodactyly), difficulty swallowing (esophageal dysmotility), and lung lesions is consistent with systemic sclerosis (SSc), particularly the limited cutaneous form known as CREST syndrome.
  • In CREST syndrome, anti-centromere antibodies (ACA) are characteristically present, producing a centromere-staining pattern on ANA testing, as given in the image.

 

CREST Syndrome is characterized by the following features:

C: Calcinosis cutis (calcium deposits in the skin).

R: Raynaud’s phenomenon (episodic vasospasm leading to bluing of the hands).

E: Esophageal dysmotility (causing difficulty swallowing).

S: Sclerodactyly (tight, shiny skin of the hands).

T: Telangiectasias (dilated capillaries visible on the skin).

 

ANA Immunofluorescence Patterns in Autoimmune Diseases

 

Pattern

Image

Description

Clinical Associations

Centromeric


 

Fine, discrete speckling of the centromere of chromosomes
  • Systemic Sclerosis (especially limited form, CREST syndrome)
  • Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD).

Nucleolar

(Option B)


 

Large, prominent nucleoli within the cell nucleus
  • Systemic Sclerosis (particularly in patients with interstitial lung disease)
  • Polymyositis
  • Sjögren's Syndrome.

Homogeneous

(Option D)

Smooth, uniform staining of the entire nucleus
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
  • Drug-induced lupus
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA).

Peripheral/Rim


 

Intense staining of the nuclear membrane or periphery

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), highly suggestive of SLE, especially with associated anti-dsDNA antibodies.

Speckled

(Option A)


 

Fine or coarse speckling throughout the nucleus
  • SLE
  • Sjogren’s Syndrome
  • Scleroderma
  • Polymyositis
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis
  • Mixed Connective Tissue
 

Speckled pattern can be nonspecific.

questions.text: A known case of ulcerative colitis is not responding to an anti-TNF alpha agent. Which JAK inhibitor is preferred for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tofacitinib

 

Explanation:

  • Tofacitinib is a oral JAK inhibitor that works by inhibiting the JAK-STAT pathway, which regulates cytokine-mediated inflammation.
  • It is approved for the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, particularly in patients who are refractory or intolerant to anti-TNF agents like infliximab or adalimumab.

 

  • Tofacitinib is a JAK 1/3 inhibitor and blocks the production of inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-6 and interferons.
  • It is effective for inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.

 

  • Side effects include an increased risk of infections, venous thromboembolism, and lipid elevation, requiring careful patient selection and monitoring.

 

Vedolizumab (Option A) is an anti-integrin monoclonal antibody targeting α4β7 integrin, used to treat moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

 

Ozanimod (Option C) is an FDA-approved sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P1) receptor modulator for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, reducing lymphocyte migration to the gut.

 

Leflunomide (Option D) is a pyrimidine synthesis inhibitor primarily for rheumatoid arthritis treatment.

questions.text: In children with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), all are true except?

choices.text: Areflexia of the affected limb is a mandatory diagnostic criteria
Plasmapheresis is not preferred in refractory cases
Intravenous immunoglobulin is the first line of management
Albuminocytological dissociation in CSF is characteristic

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Plasmapheresis is not preferred in refractory cases

 

Explanation:

  • Plasmapheresis is actually preferred in refractory cases of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), especially when the condition does not improve after initial treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG).
  • The standard treatment for GBS involves the use of either IVIG or plasmapheresis, depending on the patient's condition and response to initial therapy.

 

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)

  • Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system.
  • It often leads to ascending paralysis, starting from the lower limbs and spreading upwards.
  • GBS is considered a neurological emergency due to its potential to cause respiratory failure, autonomic dysfunction, and death without timely treatment.
  • Incidence: GBS occurs in 1–2 cases per 100,000 individuals annually.
  • Preceding Infections: In about two-thirds of AIDP cases, a preceding infection triggers an autoimmune response. Common infections include:
    • Campylobacter jejuni
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
    • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
    • Zika virus
    • Influenza
  • These infections lead to molecular mimicry, where the immune system attacks nerve structures, particularly the myelin sheath, causing demyelination.

Variants of Guillain-Barré Syndrome:

Variant

Description

Autoantibodies

Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)

Most common in Europe and North America, marked by segmental demyelination.

IgG Anti-GM1, IgG Anti-GQ1b

Axonal Variants (AMAN/AMSAN)

More prevalent in China and Japan, often linked with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

IgG Anti-GM1

Miller Fisher Syndrome

Characterized by a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia, the best-recognized variant.

Anti-GQ1b

 

Autoantibodies in Guillain-Barré Syndrome:

  • Diversity: GBS patients exhibit a range of autoantibodies targeting nerve cells and structures.
  • Common Antibodies: The most common are anti-ganglioside antibodies, which appear in up to 50% of GBS cases.
  • Prognostic Implications: The presence of anti-GM1 antibodies correlates with poorer clinical outcomes, especially in pure motor variants and Miller Fisher Syndrome.

Clinical Features:

Motor Symptoms
  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs, causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia
  • Difficulty handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis or bulbar palsy leading to respiratory failure within hours, Ventilatory support required in 30% of cases

Sensory Symptoms
  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Loss of proprioception
  • Pain in neck/shoulders similar to over-exercised muscles

Autonomic Symptoms
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure
  • Arrhythmias
  • Neurogenic shock

 

Diagnostic Findings:

Category

Findings

Lumbar Puncture

Elevated CSF protein (100-1000 mg/dL) with normal WBC count (albuminocytologic dissociation)

CSF Timing

Normal findings (<48 hours), protein rise seen by 7 days

Electrodiagnostic Testing

Prolonged F-wave latencies, indicating demyelination (early in AIDP)

 

Brighton Criteria for Diagnosis of GBS:

Mnemonic: FAME

Flaccid Bilateral Weakness

Areflexia (Option A)

CytoAlbuminologic dissociation (Elevated CSF protein, normal WBC) (Option D)

Monophasic Illness (Symptoms develop over 12 hours to 28 days)

Electrodiagnostic findings consistent with demyelination

 

Treatment:

  • IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) (Option C):
    • First-line treatment.
    • It modulates the immune response and helps reduce inflammation.
  • Plasmapheresis (Plasma Exchange):
    • ​​​​​​​Equally effective as IVIG.
    • It removes harmful antibodies from the blood; preferred in refractory cases.
  • Glucocorticoids:
    • Not useful in GBS treatment, as they do not improve outcomes.

questions.text: As per KDIGO, which of the following falls under G3b?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 30-44

 

Explanation:

  • This range corresponds to Stage 3b of CKD, which is classified as a moderate to severe decrease in kidney function, with GFR between 30-44 mL/min/1.73m².

According to the Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) classification for chronic kidney disease (CKD):

  1. GFR: A GFR of 50 mL/min falls into Stage 3 CKD (G3a), defined as 30–59 mL/min.
  2. Albuminuria: An albuminuria level of 12 mg/g is categorised as A1 (normal to mildly increased), which is <30 mg/g.

Combining these classifications:

questions.text:
A 46-year-old diabetic patient presented with fever, malaise, and a productive cough. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Patchy infiltrates as seen in pyogenic pneumonia
Interstitial infiltrates as seen in Mycoplasma pneumonia
Hilar lymphadenopathy with infiltrates as seen in malignancy
Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the upper segment of the lower lobe and posterior segment of the upper lobe

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Patchy infiltrates as seen in pyogenic pneumonia

 

Explanation:

  • Patchy infiltrates are more characteristic of atypical pneumonia, such as Mycoplasma pneumonia or viral infections.
  • Pyogenic (community-acquired) pneumonia more commonly presents with lobar consolidation rather than patchy infiltrates.

 

Interstitial infiltrates in Mycoplasma pneumonia (Option B): Mycoplasma pneumonia typically presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy with infiltrates in malignancy (Option C): Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in malignancies such as lung cancer, though it is not relevant to the acute presentation in this case.

 

Aspiration pneumonia distribution (Option D): Aspiration pneumonia commonly affects the upper segment of the lower lobe and posterior segment of the upper lobe due to gravitational factors when the patient is supine.

questions.text: A patient presented with uveitis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis. Which of the following is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HLA-B27

 

Explanation:

The combination of uveitis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and other spondyloarthropathies, which are strongly associated with HLA-B27.

 

Ankylosing Spondylitis

 

Clinical Features

General Features

Spine and Joint involvement

Extra-articular manifestations
  • Inflammatory back pain: Gradual onset, worse with inactivity, improves with movement and is often associated with early morning stiffness.
  • Fatigue: A common and significant symptom.
  • Postural changes: Loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, and forward stooping of the neck.
  • Enthesitis: Inflammation at tendon or ligament attachment sites, often mistaken for fibromyalgia.
  • Peripheral joint involvement: Affects large joints like hips, knees, and shoulders and is usually asymmetrical.
  • Sacroiliac joint involvement: B/L and asymmetrical; pain may radiate to the buttocks or posterior thighs.
  • Reduced spinal mobility: Limited movement in the lumbar region due to inflammation and pain, often accompanied by muscle spasms.

 
  • Anterior uveitis: Most common extra articular manifestation. Presents with sudden unilateral eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity, often preceding joint symptoms.
  • Anaemia, prostatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, aortic valve disease, and very rare cases of amyloidosis or upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis
  • Osteoporosis: This can lead to vertebral fractures, especially with spinal fusion.


 

Investigations of Ankylosing Spondylitis

Tests

X-rays

MRI

  • HLA-B27: The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a strong indicator of AS. The prevalence of AS in the general population is less than 0.5%.
  • Inflammatory Markers: Elevated ESR and CRP levels may indicate active disease.
  • Faecal Calprotectin: Helps screen for associated inflammatory bowel disease.

Show characteristic changes in sacroiliac joints, such as:

  • Blurred cortical margins
  • Erosions and sclerosis
  • "Pseudowidening" of joint space (early stages)
  • Joint space narrowing and fusion (later stages)
  • Bamboo spine - Vertebral body fusion by syndesmophytes
  • Dagger sign - Calcification appears as a single radiodense line vertically running down the spine on frontal radiographs.
  • Investigation of choice – more sensitive than X-rays for detecting early inflammatory changes.
  • Can reveal bone marrow oedema, enthesitis, synovitis, and erosions.

 

HLA Types & Conditions Associated

 

HLA Type

Associated Conditions

HLA-A1
  • Reiter's syndrome
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis

HLA-A2
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Autoimmune hepatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Melanoma

HLA-B8
  • Celiac disease
  • Autoimmune hepatitis
  • Addison's disease
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis

HLA-B27
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Reiter's syndrome (Reactive arthritis)
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Crohn's disease
  • Ulcerative colitis
  • Acute anterior uveitis

HLA-B35
  • Ulcerative colitis
  • Psoriasis
  • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Subacute thyroiditis

HLA-B51

(Option C)
  • Behçet’s disease
  • Uveitis

HLA-B5

(Option D)
  • Behçet’s disease

HLA-B57

(Option B)
  • Slower progression of HIV infection

HLA-DR1
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Vasculitis
  • Pemphigus vulgaris

HLA-DR2
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • Narcolepsy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Goodpasture's syndrome
  • Leprosy

HLA-DR3
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Graves' disease
  • Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Sjögren's syndrome
  • Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

HLA-DR4
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Juvenile arthritis
  • Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (Type 1 diabetes)
  • Giant cell arteritis
  • Pemphigus vulgaris

  • Graves' disease

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with hematuria. Which of the following are seen in glomerular hematuria?

 

Statements:


	Brown-colored urine
	Dysuria absent
	Crystals present
	Edema rare
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

Glomerular hematuria presents with brown-colored urine due to RBC breakdown, absence of dysuria as it is not due to lower urinary tract infection, and edema may occur in nephritic syndrome, but is not rare; however, crystals are not a feature of glomerular hematuria.

 

Glomerular Hematuria

Glomerular hematuria occurs due to damage to the glomerular filtration barrier, leading to the leakage of red blood cells (RBCs) into the urine.

 

Causes:

  • Glomerulonephritis (Post-streptococcal, IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis, membranoproliferative GN)
  • Small Vessel Vasculitis (ANCA-associated vasculitis, Goodpasture’s syndrome)
  • Hereditary Conditions (Alport syndrome, Thin basement membrane disease)

 

Features

  • Color: Cola-colored or smoky brown urine
  • Dysmorphic RBCs (acanthocytes, Mickey Mouse cells)
  • Proteinuria: Often present, especially if associated with nephritic syndrome
  • Presence of RBC casts (diagnostic of glomerular origin)
  • Clots absent (distinguishes from non-glomerular hematuria)

 

Serum Markers: Often associated with increased serum creatinine.

questions.text: A male patient presents with oral ulcers and ulcers in the anal canal. He is diagnosed with Behçet's disease. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?

choices.text: Ulcer over the dorsum of the penis
It is more similar to Crohn's disease than ulcerative colitis
Pathergy test positive is a criterion of ISG diagnostic criteria

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulcer over the dorsum of the penis

 

Explanation:

Ulcers over the dorsum of the penis are not typically associated with Behçet’s disease, which more commonly presents with genital ulcers on the scrotum or glans penis, rather than the dorsum.

 

  • Behçet’s Disease is a chronic, multisystemic vasculitis characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and systemic involvement.
  • It is an immune-mediated disorder that primarily affects small and medium-sized blood vessels.

 

Behcet’s Disease- Pathogenesis and Clinical Features

Category

Features

Clinical Significance

Pathogenesis
  • T-cell mediated immunity
  • Th1 cell activation
  • Elevated cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α)
  • Neutrophilic vasculitis
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • Auto-inflammatory rather than autoimmune
  • Affects vessels of all sizes
  • Treatment targets inflammation

Mucocutaneous
  • Oral ulcers (97-99%)
  • Genital ulcers (>80%)
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Pathergy reaction
  • Often initial presentation
  • Oral ulcers heal without scarring
  • Genital ulcers leave scars

Major Organ Involvement
  • B/L uveitis (>50%) (Option C)
  • Vascular (25%)
  • Neurologic (5-10%)
  • Arthritis (non-erosive)
  • More severe in males
  • Ocular disease can cause blindness
  • Vascular involvement can be fatal
  • Presents similar to IBD (Crohn's disease > Ulcerative colitis) (Option B)

Behcet’s Disease- Diagnosis and Management

Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria (ITR-ICBD)

Two Points Each:

  • Genital aphthosis
  • Ocular lesions
 

One Point Each:

  • Oral aphthosis
  • Skin lesions
  • Vascular manifestations
  • Positive pathergy (Option D)

≥3 points needed for diagnosis

Laboratory Findings
  • Non-specific inflammation markers
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • ESR, CRP elevation
  • Leukocytosis

Helps rule out other conditions

Required Investigations
  • Ophthalmologic examination
  • Pathergy test
  • Skin biopsy if needed
  • Imaging, based on symptoms

Confirms involvement and monitors complications

Treatment

Mucocutaneous Treatment
  • Colchicine 1-2mg/day
  • Topical steroids
  • Topical sucralfate

Refractory: Systemic steroids, azathioprine

Ocular Treatment
  • Anterior: Topical steroids
  • Posterior: Steroids + azathioprine

Refractory: TNF inhibitors

Major Organ Involvement
  • Vascular: High-dose steroids + cyclophosphamide
  • Neurologic: High-dose steroids + immunosuppression

Requires aggressive therapy and monitoring

questions.text:
A female patient comes to the ER with palpitations and syncopal attacks following exercise. She has had similar episodes in the past. An ECG was performed as follows. What is the most probable diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of palpitations, syncope following exercise, and a suggestive ECG pattern are characteristic of Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD), a condition that often leads to arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, particularly in young, athletic individuals.
  • Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD) is an inherited cardiac disorder characterized by the progressive replacement of the right ventricular myocardium with fibrofatty tissue, leading to arrhythmias, particularly ventricular tachycardia and sudden cardiac death.
  • It primarily affects the right ventricle but can involve the left ventricle as well.

 

Etiology

  • Mutations in genes encoding desmosomal proteins (e.g., PKP2, DSP, DSG2, JUP).

 

Clinical Features

  • Palpitations
  • Syncope
  • Exercise-induced arrhythmias
  • Sudden cardiac death, Particularly in young, athletic individuals.

 

Diagnostic Findings

Electrocardiogram (ECG):

  • Ventricular arrhythmias, especially ventricular tachycardia.
  • Epsilon waves on ECG (specific to ARVD).

 

Echocardiography: May show right ventricular dilation and dysfunction.

Cardiac MRI: Shows fibrofatty infiltration of the right ventricle.

Family history: Key in diagnosing genetic basis.

 

Diagnostic Criteria

Based on the Task Force Criteria, which include:

 

  • ECG abnormalities, arrhythmias, imaging findings, and histological evidence.
  • Pathological criteria: Fibrofatty infiltration of the right ventricle.

 

Management

  • Antiarrhythmic drugs
  • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD): For preventing sudden cardiac death in high-risk patients.
  • Heart transplantation: In severe cases with progressive heart failure.

 

Uhl's disease (Option A): Also affects the right ventricle but lacks the hallmark epsilon waves and T-wave inversions.

 

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Option C): More commonly presents with asymmetric septal hypertrophy and deep Q waves, not epsilon waves.

 

Brugada’s Syndrome (Option D): Characterized by ST-segment elevation in V1–V3, not epsilon waves.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of MEN type II syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pancreatic adenoma

 

Explanation:

Pancreatic adenoma is a part of MEN1 syndrome, not MEN2.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) is a group of genetic syndromes (Autosomal dominant) characterised by the development of tumours in multiple endocrine glands.

  • Diagnostic criteria for MEN:
    • Clinical features of 2 or more associated tumours
    • Notable Family history
    • Confirmation by genetic analysis.

 

Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia
 

MEN Type I

MEN Type II

MEN Type III

MEN Type IV

Cause
  • Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation
  • Also called Wermer’s syndrome
  • Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene
  • Also called Sipple’s syndrome

Also called MEN II B, it is a variant of Type 2 MEN

Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene

Tumors

Included

Parathyroid adenoma

(most common)

  • It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism (↑ PTH and ↑ Ca)

Parathyroid adenoma (most common, and calcium can be normal)

Medullary carcinoma thyroid (most common)

(Option A)

Parathyroid adenoma (Presents as hypercalcemia)

Pancreatic adenoma

(Option D)

  • Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

Pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure.

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

  • Calcitonin is the tumor marker present

Reproductive tract tumors

  • Testicular tumors
  • Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix)

Associated conditions
  • Angioﬁbroma
  • Collagenoma
  • Adrenocortical tumor
  • Carcinoid tumors/Argentaﬃnoma
  • Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%)
  • Congenital aganglionosis,
  • Hirschsprung disease
  • Marfanoid habitus

(Option B)

  • Medullated corneal nerve ﬁbers
  • Mucosal neuromas

(Option C)

  • Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae

Occasionally with

  • Renal tumor
  • Adrenal tumor

questions.text: All are hereditary causes of thrombosis except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PNH

 

Explanation:

  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare acquired condition marked by clonal expansion of hematopoietic stem cells lacking GPI anchor proteins and is not a hereditary cause of thrombosis.
  • PNH blood cells are deficient in three GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity:
    • CD55 (decay-accelerating factor)
    • CD59 (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis)
    • C8-binding protein.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • It results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.
  • Clinical features:
    • It causes intravascular haemolysis and anaemia
    • Haemoglobinuria (red-brown colour) (most noticeable in early morning urine)
    • Hypoplastic bone marrow failure, aplastic anaemia and myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Management
    • Transfusion
    • Folate supplements
    • Prophylaxis or treatment of thrombosis
    • Anti-complement C5 monoclonal antibody.

 

Protein S deficiency (Option B) is a genetic disorder that increases the risk of abnormal blood clotting (thrombosis).

  • Protein C and its co-factor protein S are vitamin K-dependent natural anticoagulants involved in switching off coagulation factor activation (factors Va and VIIIa) and thrombin generation.
  • Deficiency can lead to deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and other thrombotic events.

 

Antithrombin deficiency (Option C) is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder that heightens the risk of abnormal blood clotting (thrombosis).

  • Antithrombin (AT) is a serine protease inhibitor (SERPIN) that inactivates activated coagulation factors IIa, IXa, Xa, and XIa.
  • A deficiency in AT can result in deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and other thrombotic events.
  • Heparins and fondaparinux enhance AT activity to exert their therapeutic effects.

 

Homocystinuria (Option D) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CBS gene, leading to cystathionine β-synthase deficiency that results in the accumulation of homocysteine and methionine in the blood. Symptoms include lens dislocation (ectopia lentis), intellectual disability, seizures, skeletal abnormalities similar to Marfan's syndrome, osteoporosis, thrombosis, and hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: Most common cause of inherited coagulopathy is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Explanation:

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common cause of inherited coagulopathy among the given options.

 

Hypercoagulability

  • It refers to an increased tendency of the blood to clot, usually due to changes in coagulation factors.
  • Types:
    • Primary disorders (genetic)
    • Secondary disorders (acquired)
  • Among inherited causes, point mutations in the factor V and prothrombin genes are the most common.

 

Primary disorders (Genetic)

Secondary disorders (Acquired)

Common

  • Factor V mutation
    • A single-nucleotide mutation (autosomal dominant inheritance) in the factor V gene makes factor V resistant to cleavage and inactivation by protein C.
  • Prothrombin mutation
    • A single nucleotide change (G20210A) in the 3′-untranslated region of the prothrombin gene is linked to hypercoagulability.
 

Rare

  • Antithrombin III deficiency (Option B)
  • Protein C deficiency (Option C)
  • Protein S deficiency (Option D)
 

Very rare

  • Fibrinolysis defects
  • Homozygous homocystinuria (deficiency of cystathionine β-synthetase)

Strong Risk Factors for Thrombosis

  • Prolonged bed rest or immobilization
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Tissue injury (surgery, fracture, burn)
  • Cancer
  • Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
 

Other Risk Factors for Thrombosis

  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Hyperestrogenic states (pregnancy and postpartum)
  • Oral contraceptive use
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Smoking

questions.text: A patient presents with a hand lesion, and the histopathology of the lesion is provided. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: It originates from the peripheral nerve
Verrocay bodies are seen in light microscopy
It is malignant and often metastasizes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It is malignant and often metastasizes

Explanation:

The described scenario, featuring a hand lesion and histopathological findings of encapsulated tissue with areas of dense cellularity and loose myxoid regions, suggests a diagnosis of Schwannoma.

 

  • Schwannomas are benign tumours exhibiting Schwann cell differentiation and originate directly from peripheral nerves. (Option A)
  • It is associated with NF2 mutations on chromosome 22, producing merlin. (Option C)
  • Most common location: Cerebellopontine angle
  • Microscopically, they are comprised of:
    • Antoni A area: Dense eosinophilic areas containing spindle cells are arranged into intersecting fascicles, leading to nuclei palisading. The resulting structures with central “nuclear-free zones” are called Verocay bodies. (Option B)
    • Antoni B area: Loose, hypocellular areas where a myxoid extracellular matrix spreads apart the spindle cells.

  • It typically shows immunoreactivity to S-100.
  • Clinical features:
    • Cause symptoms by local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures (e.g., brainstem or spinal cord).
    • Mostly occurs at the cerebellopontine angle (attached to the vestibular branch of the 8th nerve).
    • Presents with tinnitus and hearing loss
    • Sensory nerves are involved (trigeminal nerve and dorsal roots).
    • They can arise in association with large nerve trunks or as soft tissue lesions (extradural)

Management: Surgical removal is curative.
