questions.text: A young child presents with bleeding gums and bruising for the past two weeks. Bone marrow biopsy and flow cytometry have been performed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ALL: B Phenotype

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation, along with histopathological and flow cytometry findings, confirms a diagnosis of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) with a B-cell phenotype based on the following results:
  • Histopathological examination reveals lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm.


  • Flow cytometry analysis:
    • Image B: The lymphoblasts (indicated by red dots) expressing terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and the B-cell marker CD22.
    • Image C: The cells test positive for two other markers, CD10 and CD19, commonly found on pre-B lymphoblasts.

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

ALL is an acute-onset blood and bone marrow malignancy of B and T lymphoblasts characterised by the uncontrolled proliferation of abnormal and immature lymphocytes

Clinical features

  • Age: 2-8 years (Fast disease progression), adults: > 50 years.
  • Weight loss, Night sweats
  • Anemia: Easy fatigability and pallor
  • Bleeding: Epistaxis, easy bruising.
  • Leucocytopenia: Recurrent infections
  • Bone Marrow proliferation: Bone pain, sternal tenderness
  • Hepatosplenomegaly, Lymphadenopathy
  • CNS leukemia: Raised ICP, vomiting, and 6th nerve palsy
  • T cell tumors: Mediastinal and testicular mass.

Diagnosis

CBC is the first investigation performed while suspecting ALL:

  • Hemoglobin (Hb): Decreased, indicating normocytic normochromic anemia.
  • Hyperleukocytosis: TLC >100,000/µL can lead to leukostasis (more common in AML than ALL) with >20% Blasts.
  • Elderly Presentation: TLC often remains low throughout ALL.
  • Thrombocytopenia may be present.
 

Peripheral smear:

The smear shows a high percentage of lymphoblasts, which are larger than normal lymphocytes and have a high nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio. They often have a scant amount of cytoplasm and may exhibit nucleoli.

 

Bone Marrow aspiration shows blasts >20%.

  • It is also used to classify morphological types into L1, L2, and L3 in the FAB classification system.
 

FISH- Fluorescent in situ hybridization shows translocation of genes/chromosomes.

  • t(9:22) - ALL associated with the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • t(8:14) - Associated with Burkitt's leukemia
  • t(4:11)
  • t(1:19)
 

Flow cytometry:

  • CD10, also known as common acute lymphoblastic leukaemia antigen (CALLA), is a cell surface marker commonly used in the classification and diagnosis of leukaemias and lymphomas, particularly acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL).
  • B cell type - CD19+, CD79a+. (Option C)
  • T cell type - CD3+ (Option D ruled out)

 

Acute myeloid leukaemia (Option A) is a malignancy of hematopoietic progenitors caused by oncogenic mutations that prevent differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts. These blasts have delicate chromatin, two to four nucleoli, and more cytoplasm than lymphoblasts, often containing peroxidase-positive azurophilic granules. Auer rods, needle-like azurophilic granules, are also commonly present.

CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia) (Option B) is characterised by lymph node infiltration with small lymphocytes featuring condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm, along with larger activated lymphocytes forming proliferation centres, which are pathognomonic for CLL/SLL. The blood shows small lymphocytes and smudge cells, while the bone marrow, spleen, and liver are typically involved to varying degrees.

questions.text: Epithelial-mesenchymal transition induced by which pair of transcription factors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) SNAIL & TWIST

 

Explanation:

  • Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is induced by the transcription factors SNAIL and TWIST.
  • It is a process where epithelial cells lose their polarity and cell-cell adhesion, gaining migratory and invasive properties to transform into mesenchymal stem cells, multipotent stromal cells.
  • t is hypothesized that E-cadherin (transmembrane glycoproteins that mediate the homotypic adhesion of epithelial cells) expression is transiently silenced through this process.
  • It is controlled by the transcription factors SNAIL and TWIST.
  • There is downregulation of epithelial markers (e.g., E-cadherin) and also upregulation of mesenchymal markers (e.g., vimentin and smooth muscle actin).

 

TF IIA & TF IIB (Option A) are essential general transcription factors that are key to the initiation of transcription by RNA polymerase II. TFIIA contributes to transcriptional regulation by modulating the initiation process and ensuring correct gene expression. TFIIB is responsible for forming the transcription initiation complex and facilitating the transition from initiation to elongation.

 

Cathepsin & MMP 8 (Matrix Metalloproteinase-8) (Option B) are enzymes that degrade proteins in the extracellular matrix, playing key roles in tissue remodelling and inflammation. Cathepsins aid in wound healing and immune responses but can contribute to cancer metastasis and inflammation. Elevated MMP-8 is linked to diseases like periodontal disease, arthritis, and cancer, where it contributes to tissue damage and remodelling.

 

STAT-5 & HIF-1 alpha (Option D) are transcription factors. STAT-5, activated by cytokine receptors, regulates cell survival, differentiation, and immune responses and is key in hematopoiesis and cancers like leukaemia. HIF-1 alpha responds to low oxygen levels, activating genes for angiogenesis, metabolism, and erythropoiesis, and plays a critical role in tumour growth in hypoxic environments.

questions.text:
Match the following with the appropriate disorder.

 


	
		
			
			A. Autosomal recessive
			
			
			
				Kennedy disease

Explanation:

 

Autosomal recessive

Cystic fibrosis

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are correctly associated with their respective inclusion bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Malakoplakia - Michaelis Gutmann bodies

 

Explanation:

Michaelis Gutmann bodies are seen in Malakoplakia.

 

Disease

Inclusion bodies

Rabies

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites usually devoid of inflammation.


 

Parkinson’s disease

Lewy bodies

  • These are single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions that often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo.
  • They are composed of fine filaments, densely packed in the core but loose at the rim; these filaments are composed of α-synuclein.

 

Multiple myeloma

The globular inclusions are referred to as Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) or Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).

Malakoplakia

Michaelis Gutmann bodies: Laminated mineralized concretions resulting from calcium deposition in enlarged lysosomes.

questions.text: All of the following are included under diagnostic criteria of severe acute malnutrition except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Height for age


Explanation:

Height for age is not included under diagnostic criteria of severe acute malnutrition

 

Definition of Severe acute malnutrition:
In a child between 6 months to 5 years of age, the presence of any 1 or more of the following:

  • Weight for ;-3 Z score or <70% of expected (Option B ruled out), or
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC): <11.5 cm (Option D ruled out), or
  • Symmetric bipedal edema: of nutritional origin (Option C ruled out)

Definition of SAM (Severe Acute Malnutrition) - can have any of the 3 criteria.

 

Learning Objective:
 

WHO Classification of Malnutrition

Moderately underweight

Weight-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDS.

Severely underweight

Weight-for-age is < -3 SDS.

Moderately wasted

Weight-for-length/height is between -2 and -3 SDS.

Severely wasted

Weight-for-length/height is < -3 SDS.

Moderate Acute Malnutrition
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDS.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm.

Severe Acute Malnutrition:
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is less than -3SDS.
  • MUAC is less than 11.5 cm.
  • The presence of bilateral pitting oedema.

Moderately Stunted (Moderate Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDS.

Severely Stunted (Severe Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height-for-age is < -3 SDS.

questions.text: In children diagnosed with congenital heart disease, NADA’s criteria include all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increased Troponin T

Explanation:

Increased Troponin T (Option B) is not included under NADA’s criteria


Nada’s criteria: (used for clinical diagnosis of congenital heart disease)

 

Major

Minor

Systolic murmur grade III or more

Systolic murmur grade I or II

Diastolic murmur (Option A ruled out)

Abnormal second heart sound

Cyanosis

Abnormal ECG

Congestive cardiac failure (Option D ruled out)

Abnormal X-ray (Option C ruled out)
 

Abnormal Blood pressure


Presence of one major or 2 minor criteria is needed to indicate the presence of CHD.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding neonatal cholestasis?

choices.text: Kasai procedure should be done within 90 days
HIDA scan is an investigation of choice
Biliary atresia is the most common cause
Liver biopsy rules out other causes

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Kasai procedure should be done within 90 days

 

Explanation:

Kasai procedure should ideally be performed within the first 60 days of life, not 90 days. Delaying it beyond 60 days significantly decreases its success rate and heightens the likelihood of needing a liver transplant.

 

Neonatal cholestasis

Neonatal cholestasis is an abnormal accumulation of conjugated bilirubin (CB) due to impaired formation or flow of bile. Conjugated bilirubin exceeding 1 mg/dL is strongly suggestive of it.

 

Causes of neonatal cholestasis:

 

Category

Condition

Surgical (Extrahepatic)
  • Biliary atresia (EHBA) (Most common) (Option C)
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Cholelithiasis
  • Inspissated bile secretion
  • Spontaneous perforation of the bile duct
  • Nonsyndromic paucity of bile ducts
  • Congenital hepatic fibrosis/Caroli disease
  • Neonatal sclerosing cholangitis

Medical (Hepatocellular)
  • Idiopathic neonatal hepatitis
  • Prematurity
  • Viral infections (CMV, TORCH, HIV, etc.)
  • Bacterial infections (sepsis, UTI, syphilis, tuberculosis)
  • Hypothyroidism/ Hyperthyroidism/ Hypopituitarism
  • Galactosemia
  • Alagille syndrome
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • α1-antitrypsin deficiency
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Tyrosinemia
  • Fructosemia
  • Neonatal hemochromatosis
  • Gaucher disease
  • Wolman disease

 

Extra-Hepatic Biliary Atresia (EHBA)

Definition:

  • Biliary atresia not associated with cyst formation.
  • Also known as Non-Cystic Obliterative Cholangiopathy.
  • Characterized by complete obliteration of extrahepatic bile ducts and intrahepatic ducts at the hilum.

Symptoms:

  • Typically appear by 2 to 6 weeks of age
    • Jaundice (yellowish coloration of skin and sclera)
    • Abnormally pale stools
    • Dark urine

Association with other Anomalies:

  • The most common is polysplenia or asplenia
  • Other associated malformations include absent inferior vena cava, cardiac anomalies, situs inversus, intestinal malrotation, duodenal atresia, anomaly of the portal vein, renal anomalies, and choledochal cyst.

Investigations:

  1. Liver Function Tests:
    • Increased conjugated bilirubin.
    • Markers of cholestasis:
      • 5' nucleotidase
      • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
      • GGT (Gamma-glutamyl transferase):
        • Normal: Up to 40 U/L
        • 4x elevation: Intrahepatic causes
        • 10x elevation: Extrahepatic causes
        • Exception: Low in PFIC type I and II
  2. Ultrasound:
    • High-frequency USG (HUS) for neonatal cholestasis.
    • Used as initial investigation
    • Fasting USG is the gold standard when biliary atresia is suspected.
    • Characteristic findings:
      • Triangular cord sign (hyperechoic areas indicating fibrous/atretic bile duct)
      • Non-visualized gallbladder/microgallbladder/gallbladder ghost
  3. Radionucleotide Study:
    • HIDA Scan (Option B) is investigation of choice (Hepatobiliary scan with Tc labelled imino-di-acetic acid):
      • Used as a screening test.
      • Decreased tracer excretion due to obstruction
    • Phenobarbitone loading/priming (5 days) to improve tracer uptake
    • Used as a screening test, not specific
  4. Best Investigation:
    • Liver biopsy (Option D): Confirms diagnosis.

Surgical Management:

  1. Algorithm:
    • Exploratory laparotomy
    • Per Operative cholangiogram
    • Temporary procedure: Kasai procedure/hepaticojejunostomy
    • Definitive management: Liver transplantation
  2. Kasai Procedure:
    • Temporary procedure
    • Creates communication between liver and jejunum for bile drainage
    • Also known as hepaticojejunostomy
    • Should be performed within 8 weeks after birth

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of the closure of ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increase in Oxygen

 

Explanation:

An increase in oxygen concentration increases the constriction of the smooth muscles of ductus arteriosus, leading to the closure of it. Ductus arteriosus is a structure connecting the aorta and pulmonary artery in fetal circulation ,which closes after delivery of the fetus.

 

Changes in Fetal Circulation Following Birth:

 

Parameter/Structure

Change

Cause

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance (PVR)

Decreases

(Option C)

Mechanical expansion of the lungs and increased arterial PO2 lead to a rapid decrease in PVR.

Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR)

Increases

The removal of the low-resistance placental circulation results in an increase in SVR.

Ductus Arteriosus Shunt

Reverses and eventually closes.

As PVR becomes lower than SVR, the shunt through the ductus arteriosus reverses from right-to-left to left-to-right.

High arterial PO2 leads to the constriction and eventual closure of the ductus arteriosus, which later becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

Foramen Ovale

Closes

Increased pulmonary blood flow to the left atrium raises left atrial volume and pressure, leading to the functional closure of the foramen ovale.

Ductus Venosus

Closes

The removal of the placenta from circulation results in the closure of the ductus venosus.

Left ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Increases

The left ventricle's wall thickness and mass increase as it adapts to the high-resistance systemic circulation.

Right ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Decreases


 

The right ventricle's wall thickness and mass decrease as it adapts to the low-resistance pulmonary circulation.

Left Ventricular Output

Increases

The left ventricle now must deliver the entire systemic cardiac output, which is almost a 200% increase compared to fetal conditions.

Right Ventricular Output

Increases

Opening of pulmonary vasculature results in increased right ventricular output.

 

Time frame of closure of shunts following birth:

Shunt

Functional Closure

Anatomical closure

Remnant

Ductus Arteriosus

10-15 hrs after birth

2 -3 weeks after birth

Ligamentum arteriosum

Foramen ovale

3rd month

1 year after birth

Fossa ovalis

Ductus venosus

Immediately after birth

3-7 days after birth

Ligamentum venosum.

 

  • CO2 and catecholamines have no role in ductal closure (Option B, D).

questions.text: A 3-year-old was diagnosed with croup. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Influenza virus

 

Explanation:

Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is an upper respiratory tract infection that causes barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness due to inflammation of the larynx and trachea. It is most commonly caused by the parainfluenza virus, followed by the influenza virus. Among the given options, the influenza virus is the most appropriate choice.


 

Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup): Viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions

 

Causative Agent
  • Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases.
  • Other Viruses:
    • Influenza A and B,
    • Adenovirus,
    • Respiratory syncytial virus,
    • Measles.

Age Group
  • Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life.

Initial Symptoms

These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms.

  • Upper respiratory tract infection
  • Rhinorrhea
  • Pharyngitis
  • Mild cough
  • Low-grade fever

Progressive Symptoms

  • Barking cough
  • Hoarseness
  • Inspiratory stridor
  • Fever may reach 39- 40°C (102.2-104°F) or be absent
  • The child prefers to sit up in bed or be held upright
  • Symptoms worsen at night, recur over days and resolve within a week

Physical Examination Findings
  • Hoarse voice
  • Coryza
  • Inflamed pharynx
  • Slightly increased respiratory rate
  • Hypoxia and low oxygen saturation seen only in complete airway obstruction

Diagnosis

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray PA view of neck: Steeple sign, which is characteristic of subglottic narrowing

 

Treatment

  • Mainstay of Treatment: Focus on airway management and hypoxia treatment (O2).
  • Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine
  • Corticosteroids (dexamethasone):
    • Decrease edema in laryngeal mucosa
    • Oral steroids beneficial in mild croup
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

 

Hemophilus influenza (Option A) is associated with epiglottitis, not croup.

 

Streptococcus pneumonia (Option B) is associated with pneumonia, otitis media, or meningitis, but not croup.

 

Diphtheria (Option D) is associated with diphtheria, which presents with a pseudomembrane in the throat and can lead to airway obstruction, but it is distinct from croup.

questions.text: Copies cross, tells stories, and goes to the toilet alone. What is the age of the child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4 years

2 years (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about breastmilk jaundice?

choices.text: Most of the children require phototherapy
Exclusive breastfeeding with total bilirubin >10mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Exclusive breastfeeding with total bilirubin >10mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth


Explanation:
Approximately 2-4% of term neonates who are exclusively breastfed may have total serum bilirubin (TSB) levels exceeding 10 mg/dL beyond the third or fourth week of life. They are diagnosed to have breast milk jaundice.

  • Breast milk jaundice (BMJ) should be considered in these infants if the jaundice is of the unconjugated type (not causing staining of nappies) and other causes of prolonged hyperbilirubinemia, such as insufficient feeding, ongoing hemolysis, blood extravasation, G6PD deficiency, and hypothyroidism, have been excluded.
  • Breast milk contains elevated levels of beta-glucuronidase, which deconjugates bilirubin that has been conjugated by the liver and excreted into the intestine (Option D ruled out).
  • Most of these infants do not develop dangerously high TSB levels and typically do not require treatment (Option B ruled out).
  • Mothers can safely continue breastfeeding their infants, as there is no need to discontinue breastfeeding (Option A ruled out) for either the diagnosis or treatment of BMJ.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Biliary atresia

Explanation:

  • Biliary atresia is not a characteristic feature of cystic fibrosis. While cystic fibrosis can cause liver damage and biliary cirrhosis due to obstructed bile ducts, biliary atresia is a separate congenital condition where there is a complete absence or abnormality of the bile ducts, leading to severe liver damage and jaundice.
  • Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7q31.2 (m/c mutation is ΔF508), leading to a defective CFTR protein.

 

Pathophysiology of Cystic Fibrosis:

 

CFTR Protein Dysfunction
  • Defective chloride transport across epithelial cells
  • Increased sodium absorption
  • Decreased water movement leading to dehydrated mucous surfaces

Respiratory System
  • Thick, viscous mucus leads to airway obstruction and bacterial colonization
  • Chronic infection and inflammation
  • Bronchiectasis, atelectasis, and respiratory failure

Gastrointestinal System
  • Thick secretions block pancreatic ducts leading to enzyme insufficiency
  • Malabsorption of fats and proteins
  • Meconium ileus in neonates
  • Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome (DIOS)

Hepatobiliary System
  • Bile duct obstruction leading to biliary cirrhosis

Sweat Glands
  • Impaired chloride reabsorption leading to salty sweat

Reproductive System
  • Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility.
  • Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility.

Clinical Features of Cystic Fibrosis

 

System

Clinical Features

Respiratory
  • Chronic productive cough
  • Recurrent respiratory infections
  • Nasal polyps (Option A ruled out)
  • Bronchiectasis

Gastrointestinal
  • Greasy stools (steatorrhea)
  • Failure to thrive
  • Rectal prolapse
  • Malabsorption
  • Meconium ileus in newborns (Option C ruled out)

Genitourinary

Infertility in males (due to congenital absence of vas deferens),

delayed puberty

Others

Digital clubbing, Bleeding diathesis (Option D ruled out), salt loss syndromes (hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis)

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with a history of epistaxis and recurrent rectal bleeding. The parents also reported a history of bleeding from the umbilicus since birth. Laboratory investigations revealed normal prothrombin time (PT), normal thrombin time, normal activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), normal platelet count, and normal function. Urea clot solubility test was positive. What is the most likely deficient factor in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Factor XIII

 

Explanation:

The given clinical feature is characteristic of Factor XIII (FXIII) deficiency / Laki lorand factor deficiency. It is a rare bleeding disorder that presents with symptoms spanning from delayed umbilical cord separation to intracranial hemorrhage.

  • FXIII plays a pivotal role in stabilizing clots and facilitating the cross-linking of the fibrin polymer, thereby ensuring effective hemostasis
  • The acquired FXIII deficiency typically arises from factors such as hyperconsumption, hemodilution, and decreased synthesis and is more prevalent than the congenital form.
  • In rare instances, individuals with acquired FXIII deficiency may generate autoantibodies targeting FXIII subunits.


Factor XI deficiency (Option B) and Factor XII deficiency (Option D) causes prolonged Activated partial prothrombin time (aPTT) but Prothrombin time (PT) will be normal.


Factor X deficiency (Option C) causes both prolonged Prothrombin time (PT) and

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

questions.text:
Which of the following indicates the primary failure of recovery in an admitted patient with severe acute malnutrition?

A. Failure to regain appetite by day 4

B. Failure to start to lose edema by day 4
C. Presence of edema by day 10

D. Weight gain of less than 5gm/kg/day from day 20
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A, B, C

Explanation:
In an admitted patient with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), primary failure to respond is indicated by the following:

  • Failure to regain appetite by day 4 (Point A)
  • Failure to start to lose edema by day 4 (Point B)
  • If edema still present on day 10 (Point C)
  • Weight gain of less than 5gm/kg/day from day 10, not from day 20 (Point D) (Option B, C and D)

Day of admission is counted as day 0

 

Learning Objective:
 

SAM- Nutritional Rehabilitation Phase and Discharge

Nutritional Rehabilitation

Entry to Rehabilitation Phase:

  • Indicated by reduced or minimal oedema and a return of appetite.

Transition Process:

  • Duration: Over 3 days to prevent refeeding syndrome.
  • Method: Replace F75 with an equal volume of F100 for 2 days.
  • Gradual Increase: Increase feed volume by 10 mL at each feeding until some feed remains uneaten (around 200 mL/kg/day).

Post-Transition Feeding:

  • Feeds: Provide unlimited amounts of high-energy, high-protein milk formula like F100 (100 kcal and 3 g protein per 100 mL), ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF), or modified family foods with similar energy and protein content. (Option C)
  • Calories and Protein: Offer 150-220 kcal/kg/day and 4-6 g protein/kg/day.
  • Supplements: Continue potassium, magnesium, and micronutrients. Add iron at 3 mg/kg/day.
  • Breastfeeding: Encourage continued breastfeeding if applicable.

RUTF
  • Standard ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) usually contains milk powder, sugar, peanut butter, vegetable oil, vitamins, and minerals.
  • It has a long shelf life and low moisture content- preventing the growth of pathogens.

When using RUTF:

  • Begin with small, frequent meals of RUTF, aiming for 8 meals per day initially and then reducing to 5–6 meals per day. If the child cannot consume the full RUTF portion at each meal, supplement with F-75 to complete the meal until they can eat the full amount of RUTF.
  • If the child is unable to consume at least half of the recommended RUTF amount within 12 hours, discontinue RUTF and provide F-75 instead. Reintroduce RUTF after 1–2 days and continue this approach until the child can consume sufficient RUTF.
  • If the child is still breastfeeding, offer breast milk before each RUTF feeding.

Discharge criteria
  • All medical issues, including oedema, are resolved for 2 weeks
  • They have completed parenteral antibiotic treatment and the infant is clinically stable and alert.
  • The infant is either breastfeeding effectively or feeding well.
  • The weight gain is satisfactory, such as being above the median of WHO growth velocity standards or gaining more than 5g/kg/day for at least 3 consecutive days.
  • Before discharge, check and provide any missing vaccinations and routine interventions as needed. Ensure that mothers or caregivers are connected with appropriate community follow-up and support.

questions.text: Early-onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia occurring before which gestational age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 34 weeks

Explanation:

Early-onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia that occurs before 34 weeks of gestation.
 

Preeclampsia:

  • Types of Preeclampsia:
    • Early-Onset Preeclampsia:
      • Occurs at <34 weeks gestation.
      • Etiology: Defective placenta due to altered trophoblast invasion and placental ischemia.
      • Features: Placental infarcts, arterial sclerosis, and hypoperfusion.
    • Late-Onset Preeclampsia:
  • Occurs at ≥34 weeks gestation.
  • Etiology: Healthy placenta interacting with maternal factors, causing microvascular damage and endothelial dysfunction.
  • Features: Maintained placental perfusion; managed expectantly until 37 weeks if stable.
  • Clinical Presentations:
    • New-onset headache unresponsive to medication.
    • Visual disturbances.
    • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, often with nausea or vomiting.
    • Shortness of breath.
    • Worsened swelling beyond baseline pregnancy-related symptoms.
  • Physical Findings:
    • Elevated blood pressure:
      • SBP ≥140 mmHg or DBP ≥90 mmHg on two measurements at least 4 hours apart.
      • Severe hypertension: SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg.
    • Edema: Dependent (lower extremities) or independent (face, hands).
    • Lung examination for pulmonary disturbances.
    • Tenderness in the right upper quadrant or epigastric area.
  • Laboratory Tests:
  • Proteinuria: Urine dipstick ≥2+, 24-hour collection ≥300 mg, or protein/creatinine ratio ≥0.3.
  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count <100 K/mm³.
  • Impaired Liver Function: Liver enzymes >2 times the upper limit of normal.
  • Renal Insufficiency: Serum creatinine ≥1.1 mg/dL or double baseline levels.
  • Management:
    • Antihypertensive Therapy:
      • For severe hypertension (SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg):
  • IV Medications: Labetalol, hydralazine.
  • Oral Medications: Immediate-release nifedipine.
  • For maintenance:
    • PO Medications: Labetalol, extended-release nifedipine, or clonidine.
  • Seizure Prophylaxis:
    • First-Line: IV magnesium sulfate.
    • Alternatives (if contraindicated): Levetiracetam or benzodiazepines for seizure treatment.
  • Definitive Treatment: Delivery of the fetus is the only definitive cure.
  • Delivery Timing:
    • Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia without Severe Features: Deliver at 37 weeks.
    • Severe Features at ≥34 weeks: Delivery after maternal stabilization.
    • Severe Features <34 weeks: Expectant management with close monitoring and antenatal steroids for fetal lung maturation if stable.

questions.text: Dr. Priya is conducting a talk on the screening of cervical cancer with a Pap smear. She works in a clinic in a low-resource setting, and she was planning to screen a woman in her 20s. Which of the following is true regarding cervical cancer screening guidelines in her workplace?

choices.text: Co-testing (pap and Hr HPV) every 5 years starting at 25 years
Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 years
Hr HPV testing every 5 years starting at 30 years
Pap smear every 5 years starting at 21 years

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 years

Explanation:

Cervical cancer screening guidelines recommend starting a pap smear at age 21 and repeating it every 3 years in a low-resource setting.

 

ACOG Protocol for Cervical Cancer Screening:

Population

Recommendation

Aged less than 21 years

No screening

Aged 21-29 years

Cytology alone every 3 years

Aged 30-65 years

Any one of the following:

  • Cytology alone every 3 years
  • FDA-approved primary hrHPV testing alone every 5 years
  • Cotesting (hrHPV testing and cytology) every 5 years

Aged greater than 65 years

No screening after adequate negative prior screening results

Hysterectomy with removal of the cervix

No screening in individuals without a history of high-grade cervical precancerous lesions or cervical cancer


 

WHO Cervical Cancer Screening Guidelines:

Population

Strategy

Screening Test

Starting Age

Screening Interval

General population of women

Screen and Treat

or

Screen, Triage and Treat

HPV DNA as primary test

30 years

Every 5 to 10 years

Women living with HIV

Screen, Triage, and Treat only

HPV DNA as primary test

25 years

Every 3 to 5 years


 

Co-testing (Pap and Hr HPV) every 5 years starting at 25 years (Option A) is recommended for women aged 25 and older, typically in higher-resource settings where both Pap smear and HPV testing are accessible.
 

Hr HPV testing every 5 years starting at 30 years (Option C) is recommended for women aged 30 and older, as younger women tend to clear HPV infections on their own and are less likely to develop cervical cancer from HPV.
 

Pap smear every 5 years starting at 21 years (Option D) is not standard; Pap smears are typically done every 3 years starting at age 21 according to most guidelines.

questions.text: 26-year-old P1L1 presents with abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on the oral tablet Warfarin 3mg OD. On examination, 14 weeks of abdominal mass were felt. On USG, an 8 X 6 cm unilocular cyst with a reticular pattern was observed in the left ovary. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Repeat USG after 6-12 weeks

Explanation:

The patient presents with abdominal pain, a history of mitral valve replacement, and an ovarian cyst with a reticular pattern on ultrasound, suggesting a benign ovarian cyst. The next line of management is to repeat USG after 6-12 weeks to monitor for any changes, as many unilocular cysts resolve spontaneously.
 

Functional Ovarian Cysts:

  • Arise from ovarian follicles during follicle maturation and ovulation.
  • Types:
    • Single Cysts: Most common, often a single follicular or corpus luteum cyst.
    • Multiple Cysts: Can occur in conditions like:
      • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
      • Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
      • FSH-secreting pituitary adenomas
  • Features:
    • Functional cysts are typically 3–7 cm, and those larger than 10 cm or persistent for more than 3 months may require further investigation for malignancy.
    • Related to hormonal variations.
    • Filled with clear fluid (unless hemorrhage occurs).
    • Benign, often asymptomatic
    • Typically resolve on their own
  • Management:
    • Observation: Most cysts resolve spontaneously within 4-6 months.
      • Follow-up: Regular ultrasound after 6-12 weeks to monitor persistent or enlarging cysts.
      • Symptomatic Treatment: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) may be prescribed for pain or irregular menses.
      • Surgery: Indicated for cysts larger than 10 cm, persistent, or symptomatic (e.g., pain, torsion).
         

Measure CA 125 levels (Option A): Elevated CA 125 can indicate ovarian cancer but is often raised in benign conditions like menstruation, endometriosis, or pelvic inflammatory disease. It is primarily useful in postmenopausal women with suspected malignancy.

Surgical intervention (Option C): Immediate surgery is unnecessary for a simple ovarian cyst. Surgery is typically considered if the cyst persists, grows, or causes acute symptoms like torsion or rupture.


MRI pelvis (Option D): Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for ovarian cysts. MRI is typically used for complex or uncertain cases, which is not necessary here.

questions.text: When is delayed cord clamping recommended?

choices.text: Term and preterm babies, irrespective of birth weights
Vigorous term and preterm babies requiring resuscitation
Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation
All term babies born at 37 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weights

Explanation:

Delayed cord clamping is done in term and preterm babies, irrespective of birth weight.

Delayed Umbilical Cord Clamping:

 

Timing

Recommended delay: At least 30-60 seconds after birth for vigorous term and preterm infants (per ACOG).

Benefits for Term Infants
  • Increased Hemoglobin Levels: Higher levels at birth.
  • Improved Iron Stores: Better reserves during the first several months of life.
  • Positive Developmental Impact: Potential improvement in neurodevelopmental outcomes.

Benefits for Preterm Infants
  • Improved Circulation: Enhanced transitional circulation to support physiological adaptation.
  • Higher RBC Volume: Better blood volume establishment.
  • Reduced Complications:
    • Lower rates of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC).
    • Reduced incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH).
  • Decreased Need for Blood Transfusions: Fewer transfusions required in neonatal care.

Maternal Safety
  • No significant increase in postpartum hemorrhage or blood loss.
  • No differences in postpartum hemoglobin levels or the need for maternal transfusion.

questions.text: A couple presents with infertility even after 2 years of unprotected intercourse. The seminal analysis reveals a volume of 2 ml, concentration of 40 million/ml, progressive motility of 55%, and morphology of 45 %. The wife's hormone levels were normal, with bilateral spillage of dye from both fallopian tubes on HSG. What percentage of couples can be attributed to unexplained infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 25%

Explanation:

The couple has normal semen analysis, ovulation, and tubal patency, suggesting unexplained infertility in approximately 25% of such cases.

 

Unexplained infertility refers to infertile couples with normal ovulation, tubal patency, and semen analysis. Its prevalence ranges from 22-28%.


Semen Analysis and Normal Values:

  • First investigation for infertility in males.
  • Performed after 1 year of unprotected intercourse without conception or earlier if there are known risk factors for infertility.
  • Abstain: 2-7 days.
  • Analysis: Within 1 hour on the liquefied semen (takes 20-30 min).

 

Parameters

Normal (Normozoospermia)

(WHO 2021 Guidelines)

Volume

> 1.4 ml

pH

7.2-8.0

Concentration

At least 16 million/ ml

Total count

39 million/ejaculate

Total Motility

42% or more

Progressive motility

30% or more

Morphology (most important)

4% or more

Pus cells (WBC)

1-2 million/ml

Viability

54% or more

 

Note:

  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OATZ) means all parameters are subnormal, as seen in varicocele and smoking.
  • The most important parameters in sperm analysis are Morphology > Motility > Concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy?

choices.text: Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks
Peripheral resistance to insulin leading to hyperinsulinemia
Increased plasma volume and RBC mass

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks

Explanation:

In pregnancy, an increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks is not a physiological change.
 

Blood Pressure in Pregnancy:

  • Declines early in pregnancy, reaching a nadir at 24-26 weeks; diastolic pressure decreases more than systolic.
  • Positional Changes: BP is lower in lateral positions compared to sitting or supine positions.
  • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: Uterus compresses great vessels, causing significant hypotension in some women.

 

Blood Volume in Pregnancy:

  • Hypervolemia: Blood volume increases by 40-45% above nonpregnant levels by 32-34 weeks of gestation. In some cases, blood volume nearly doubles.
  • Plasma and Erythrocyte Mass:
    • Plasma volume increases more than erythrocyte mass.
    • Erythrocyte volume increases by ~450 mL due to moderate bone marrow erythroid hyperplasia and elevated plasma erythropoietin levels. (Option D)
  • Hemoglobin and Hematocrit: Hemoglobin concentration decreases slightly, averaging 12.5 g/dL at term.

 

Metabolic Changes in Pregnancy:

  • Glucose Levels: Characterized by mild fasting hypoglycemia, postprandial hyperglycemia, and hyperinsulinemia. (Option B)
  • Insulin Sensitivity: Reduced by 30-70% in late pregnancy due to:
    • Hormones: Progesterone, cortisol, placentally derived growth hormone, and prolactin.
    • Cytokines: Tumor necrosis factor and leptin.
  • Postprandial Glucose: Elevated due to insulin resistance and augmented hepatic gluconeogenesis.
  • Fasting State: (OptionC)
    • Lower glucose and amino acids.
    • Higher free fatty acids, triglycerides, and cholesterol.
    • Ketonemia develops rapidly during prolonged fasting.

questions.text: Instrument-assisted delivery is not indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cephalo pelvic disproportion

Explanation:

Cephalo pelvic disproportion is not an indication for instrument-assisted delivery.
 

Instrumental delivery

Indications

Contraindications
  • Fetal head at +2 station or below, along with
    • Maternal exhaustion (Option B)
    • Prolonged second-stage labor (Option C)
    • Nonreassuring fetal heart rates and premature placental separation. (Option A)
 
  • Maternal reasons for Operative Vaginal Delivery involve conditions that limit effective pushing or require rapid delivery, such as
    • Severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Neurological diseases
    • Serious cardiac disorders.
  • Mentoposterior position or face presentation
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Preterm delivery
  • Intrauterine death
  • After coming head of Brech
  • Bony deformities of the fetus, such as osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Coagulopathy in the fetus.

questions.text: In the context of labor and delivery, what does "restitution" refer to?

choices.text: Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck
Movement of the head by 1/8th of the circle due to torsion
Stretching of the vulval outlet by the head
External rotation after delivery of shoulder

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck

Explanation:

Restitution is the passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck.
 

Restitution:

  • It is the repositioning of the fetal head attitude immediately after delivery, returning it to normal alignment with the body.
  • It involves visible external movement of the fetal head to correct the torsion of the neck sustained during internal rotation. The direction of this movement is opposite to that of internal rotation (45°).
  • This movement allows the head to align with the shoulders, with the occiput pointing towards the maternal thigh of the corresponding side where it originally lies.
  • As restitution occurs, the fetal head reaches a transverse position, and the fetal body aligns its bisacromial diameter (the distance across the shoulders) with the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic outlet.
  • As a result, one shoulder moves anteriorly, positioning behind the symphysis, while the other shoulder moves posteriorly.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT part of AMTSL?

choices.text: Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction
Administration of oxytocin after shoulder delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bimanual compression

Explanation:

Bimanual compression is not a part of AMTSL.
 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL):

  • AMTSL is a set of practices aimed at enhancing uterine contractions to facilitate placental delivery and prevent primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Key Steps:
    • Administration of Uterotonic Medication: (Option D)
  • A uterotonic drug, such as oxytocin, is administered within one minute of the baby's birth or immediately after the delivery of the anterior shoulder.
  • Significance: This is the most critical step in promoting uterine contractions and reducing bleeding.
  • Delayed Cord Clamping:
    • The umbilical cord is clamped and cut 1–3 minutes after the baby is delivered.
    • Purpose: Optimizes neonatal blood volume and reduces the risk of anemia.
  • Controlled Cord Traction (CCT): (Option B)
    • The placenta is delivered using a modified technique (Brandt-Andrews method), involving gentle pulling on the cord while supporting the uterus.
    • Benefit: Helps prevent uterine inversion and ensures safe placental delivery.
  • Assessment of Uterine Tone:
    • Intermittently check the uterine fundus to confirm adequate tone and contractility.
    • Routine uterine massage (Option A) is no longer universally recommended but may be performed if needed.

questions.text: A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge and a normal cervix. The whiff test is positive. What is this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bacterial vaginosis

Explanation:

The positive whiff test with malodorous discharge in the female is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial Vaginosis (BV):

  • A polymicrobial condition characterized by an alteration in normal vaginal flora.
  • Minimal inflammatory response; few leukocytes in vaginal fluid.
  • Pathogenesis:
  • Decreased lactobacilli, leading to increased pH and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria.
  • Common bacteria: Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus spp., Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis.
  • Not sexually transmitted.
  • Symptoms:
  • 50% are asymptomatic.
  • Vaginal discharge: white, milky, non-viscous, and adherent.
  • Minimal vulval irritation.
  • Amsel's Criteria (Diagnostic Features):
  • White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • Discharge with pH >4.5.
  • Fishy odor on adding 10% KOH (whiff test).
  • Presence of clue cells on wet mount.

  • Reduced lactobacilli and increased pathogenic bacteria.
  • Complications:
    • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
    • Chorioamnionitis
    • Premature rupture of membranes (PROM)
    • Preterm labor
  • Treatment:
  • Metronidazole (DOC):
    • 400 mg twice daily for 7 days (effective in 85%).
    • A single 1 g dose cures only 45%.
  • Clindamycin:
    • 2% cream locally (85% effective).
    • Oral 300 mg daily for 7 days.
  • Alternatives:
    • Ampicillin, cephalosporin, tetracycline, doxycycline, or sulfa drugs.

 

Candida (Option A) causes thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge, itching, and presents with pseudohyphae and yeast cells on KOH mount, but not a fishy odor or positive whiff test.

 

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option C) causes frothy, greenish-yellow discharge with itching, burning, and motile trichomonas on wet mount, but lacks a fishy odor and positive whiff test.

 

Physiological cause (Option D) results in clear, odorless discharge that varies with the menstrual cycle and does not have a fishy odor or a positive whiff test.

questions.text: An athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH 2, LH 0.3, and TSH 1.2. Prolactin 20ng/ml. What is the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Explanation:

The low FSH and LH levels with a history of low BMI in an athlete indicate reduced GnRH production, consistent with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
 

Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism (HH):

  • It results from hypothalamic or pituitary dysfunction, leading to inadequate gonadotropin secretion.
  • Classification:
    • Congenital HH:
      • Anosmic HH (e.g., Kallmann syndrome): Associated with impaired or absent sense of smell; MRI may show absent or abnormal olfactory bulbs.
      • Congenital Normosmic Isolated HH: Normal sense of smell.
    • Acquired HH: May result from tumors, trauma, weight loss, excessive exercise, stress, systemic illness, or medications.
  • Clinical Characteristics:
    • Androgen deficiency: Decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, muscle weakness, and increased adiposity.
    • Impaired or delayed pubertal sexual maturation.
    • Depressed mood, decreased vitality, reduced bone density, and infertility.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Low testosterone and low levels of pituitary hormones (LH and FSH).
    • Low serum levels of estradiol.
    • Stimulated intravenous GnRH test may help confirm the diagnosis.
    • MRI for anosmic HH may reveal anomalies in olfactory structures.
  • Management:
    • Hormonal Therapy: Used to stimulate sexual development and regularize menstrual cycles in cases of congenital HH.
    • Cause-Specific Therapy: Targeted treatment for acquired causes based on the underlying condition.
    • Fertility Treatment: Ovulation induction using GnRH or gonadotropins.

 

Primary ovarian failure (Option A) is marked by irregular or absent menstrual cycles, with elevated FSH and decreased estradiol levels indicating a primary ovarian defect. This condition typically results in sterility, which does not align with the patient’s suppressed FSH and LH levels in this case.

 

Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism (Option C) is associated with ovarian failure leading to high FSH and LH due to a lack of negative feedback from the ovaries. It is not relevant here as the patient’s gonadotropin levels are suppressed, not elevated.

 

Normogonadotropic Normogonadism (Option D) implies normal hypothalamic-pituitary function, with FSH and LH levels in the normal range. Amenorrhea in such cases is often due to PCOS or other structural or systemic causes, none of which align with the suppressed gonadotropins seen in this patient.
